text: <Species>Plant heme oxygenases (HOs) regulate biosynthesis of phytochrome which accounts for photo-acceptance and -morphogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Recent studies have demonstrated that plant HOs also regulate many other physiological processes including response to environmental stimuli.</Species>

<Species>To elucidate the mechanism by which HOs regulate plant adaptation to heavy metal exposure, three novel HOs genes were isolated from rapeseed (Brassica napus) and their expression patterns were analysed.</Species>

text: <Species>Alignment of deduced protein sequences revealed that the three BnHOs share high identity with their corresponding orthologos (AtHO1-3) from Arabidopsis.</Species>

text: <Species>To investigate whether the BnHO regulates plant tolerance to Hg toxicity, we constructed B. napus transgenic plants overexpressing BnHO-1.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Under Hg stress, the transgenic plants had 1.41-1.59 folds higher biomass than the untransformants.</Species>
<Species>However, overexpression of BnHO-1 resulted in less accumulation of Hg in some lines of transformants than in untransformants.</Species>
<Species>The transgenic plants show lower abundance of reactive oxygen species and attenuated oxidative injury compared with the untransgenic plants.</Species>

text: <Species>Neutralizing antibody-resistant hepatitis C virus cell-to-cell transmission.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Hepatitis C virus (HCV) can initiate infection by cell-free particle and cell-cell contact-dependent transmission.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In this study we use a novel infectious coculture system to examine these alternative modes of infection.</Species>

<Species>Cell-to-cell transmission is relatively resistant to anti-HCV glycoprotein monoclonal antibodies and polyclonal immunoglobulin isolated from infected individuals, providing an effective strategy for escaping host humoral immune responses.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Chimeric viruses expressing the structural proteins representing the seven major HCV genotypes demonstrate neutralizing antibody-resistant cell-to-cell transmission.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>HCV entry is a multistep process involving numerous receptors.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this study we demonstrate that, in contrast to earlier reports, CD81 and the tight-junction components claudin-1 and occludin are all essential for both cell-free and cell-to-cell viral transmission.</Species>

<Species>However, scavenger receptor BI (SR-BI) has a more prominent role in cell-to-cell transmission of the virus, with SR-BI-specific antibodies and small-molecule inhibitors showing preferential inhibition of this infection route.</Species>
<Species>These observations highlight the importance of targeting host cell receptors, in particular SR-BI, to control viral infection and spread in the liver.</Species>
<Species>The atypical OmpR/PhoB response regulator ChxR from Chlamydia trachomatis forms homodimers in vivo and binds a direct repeat of nucleotide sequences.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Two-component signal transduction systems are widespread in bacteria and are essential regulatory mechanisms for many biological processes.</Species>
<Species>These systems predominantly rely on a sensor kinase to phosphorylate a response regulator for controlling activity, which is frequently transcriptional regulation.</Species>
<Species>In recent years, an increasing number of atypical response regulators have been discovered in phylogenetically diverse bacteria.</Species>
<Species>These atypical response regulators are not controlled by phosphorylation and exhibit transcriptional activity in their wild-type form.</Species>
<Species>Relatively little is known regarding the mechanisms utilized by these atypical response regulators and the conserved characteristics of these atypical response regulators.</Species>
<Species>Chlamydia spp. are medically important bacteria and encode an atypical OmpR/PhoB subfamily response regulator termed ChxR.</Species>

<Species>In this study, protein expression analysis supports that ChxR is likely exerting its effect during the middle and late stages of the chlamydial developmental cycle, stages that include the formation of infectious elementary bodies.</Species>
<Species>In the absence of detectable phosphorylation, ChxR formed homodimers in vitro and in vivo, similar to a phosphorylated OmpR/PhoB subfamily response regulator.</Species>
<Species>ChxR was demonstrated to bind to its own promoter in vivo, supporting the role of ChxR as an autoactivator.</Species>
<Species>Detailed analysis of the ChxR binding sites within its own promoter revealed a conserved cis-acting motif that includes a tandem repeat sequence.</Species>
<Species>ChxR binds specifically to each of the individual sites and exhibits a relatively large spectrum of differential affinity.</Species>

<Species>Taken together, these observations support the conclusion that ChxR, in the absence of phosphorylation, exhibits many of the characteristics of a phosphorylated (active) OmpR/PhoB subfamily response regulator.</Species>
<Species>Parallel evolution of cytochrome b mediated bifenazate resistance in the citrus red mite Panonychus citri.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>Bifenazate is a recently developed acaricide that is mainly used to control spider mites on a variety of crops.</Species>

<Species>Although first thought to be a neurotoxin, genetic evidence obtained from bifenazate resistant Tetranychus urticae strains suggested an alternative mode of action as a Qo pocket inhibitor of the mitochondrial complex III.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this study, we reveal how bifenazate resistance in strains of Panonychus citri is maternally inherited and can confer cross-resistance to the known Qo inhibitor acequinocyl.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The mitochondrial genome of P. citri was sequenced and Qo pocket mutations were shown to be linked with the resistant trait.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Parallel evolution of cytochrome b mediated bifenazate resistance corroborates the alternative mode of action and yet again illustrates that care should be taken when employing Qo inhibitors as crop protection compounds.</Species>
<Species>Towards a conceptual framework to support one-health research for policy on emerging zoonoses.</Species>

<Species>In the past two decades there has been a growing realisation that the livestock sector was in a process of change, resulting from an expansion of intensive animal production systems and trade to meet a globalised world's increasing demand for livestock products.</Species>
<Species>One unintended consequence has been the emergence and spread of transboundary animal diseases and, more specifically, the resurgence and emergence of zoonotic diseases.</Species>
<Species>Concurrent with changes in the livestock sector, contact with wildlife has increased.</Species>
<Species>This development has increased the risk of transmission of infections from wildlife to human beings and livestock.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Two overarching questions arise with respect to the real and perceived threat from emerging infectious diseases: why are these problems arising with increasing frequency, and how should we manage and control them?</Species>
<Species>A clear conceptual research framework can provide a guide to ensure a research strategy that coherently links to the overarching goals of policy makers.</Species>
<Species>We propose such a new framework in support of a research and policy-generation strategy to help to address the challenges posed by emerging zoonoses.</Species>
<Species>The osmosensing signal transduction pathway from Botrytis cinerea regulates cell wall integrity and MAP kinase pathways control melanin biosynthesis with influence of light.</Species>

text: <Species>Mitogen activated protein kinase (MAPK) signal transduction pathways are ubiquitous among eukaryotic organisms with evolutionary conserved modules.</Species>
<Species>Although generally classified as osmotic and cell wall integrity pathways, functional divergences have been observed for HOG1- and SLT2-related MAPK pathways.</Species>
<Species>Here we show that the osmotic signal transduction cascade is involved in cell wall integrity in the phytopathogenic ascomycete Botrytis cinerea.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The deletion mutants of the upstream histidine kinase Bos1 and of the MAPK Sak1 showed modified tolerance to cell wall degrading enzymes and cell wall interfering agents, as well as increased staining of Beta1-3 glucan and chitin compared to the wild-type.</Species>
<Species>The Sak1 MAPK was phosphorylated upon cell wall challenging.</Species>
<Species>Sak1 interfered with the phosphorylation status of the SLT2 type MAPK Bmp3 hinting to cross talk between both MAPK pathways.</Species>
<Species>All signal transduction components interfered with the expression of melanin biosynthesis genes in dark and bright, suggesting a coordinated control of melanin biosynthesis.</Species>
<Species>Comparison of commercial systems for extraction of nucleic acids from DNA/RNA respiratory pathogens.</Species>

<Species>This study compared six automated nucleic acid extraction systems and one manual kit for their ability to recover nucleic acids from human nasal wash specimens spiked with five respiratory pathogens, representing Gram-positive bacteria (Streptococcus pyogenes), Gram-negative bacteria (Legionella pneumophila), DNA viruses (adenovirus), segmented RNA viruses (human influenza virus A), and non-segmented RNA viruses (respiratory syncytial virus).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The robots and kit evaluated represent major commercially available methods that are capable of simultaneous extraction of DNA and RNA from respiratory specimens, and included platforms based on magnetic-bead technology (KingFisher mL, Biorobot EZ1, easyMAG, KingFisher Flex, and MagNA Pure Compact) or glass fiber filter technology (Biorobot MDX and the manual kit Allprep).</Species>
<Species>All methods yielded extracts free of cross-contamination and RT-PCR inhibition.</Species>
<Species>All automated systems recovered L. pneumophila and adenovirus DNA equivalently.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the MagNA Pure protocol demonstrated more than 4-fold higher DNA recovery from the S. pyogenes than other methods.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The KingFisher mL and easyMAG protocols provided 1- to 3-log wider linearity and extracted 3- to 4-fold more RNA from the human influenza virus and respiratory syncytial virus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These findings suggest that systems differed in nucleic acid recovery, reproducibility, and linearity in a pathogen specific manner.</Species>

text: <Species>The FusariumNpc1 gene shares 34% amino acid sequence identity and 51% similarity to the human gene, has similar domain structure and is constitutively expressed, although up-regulated in ungerminated macroconidia and ascospores.</Species>

text: <Species>GFP-tagged Npc1p localizes to the fungal vacuolar membrane.</Species>
<Species>Cultures derived from a Deltanpc1 mutant strain contain significantly more ergosterol than cultures of the wildtype.</Species>

text: <Species>The glassy-winged sharpshooter, Homalodisca vitripennis (Germar), is an invasive pest that has spread across the southern and western United States.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>H. vitripennis is highly polyphagous and voracious, feeding on at least 100 plant species and consuming up to 100 times its weight in xylem fluid daily.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The insect is a vector of the phytopathogen Xylella fastidiosa (Wells), which is the causative agent of Pierce's disease in grapevines.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To evaluate the microbial flora associated with H. vitripennis, total DNA extracts from hemolymph, alimentary canal excretions, and whole insect bodies were subjected to 16S rDNA pyrosequencing using the bTEFAP methodology and the resulting sequences (370-520 bp in length) were compared with a curated high quality 16S database derived from GenBank http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Species from the genera Wolbachia, Delftia (formerly Pseudomonas), Pectobacterium, Moraxella, Serratia, Bacillus, and many others were detected and a comprehensive picture of the microbiome associated with H. vitripennis was established.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Some of the bacteria identified in this report are initial discoveries; providing a breadth of knowledge to the microbial flora of this insect pest can serve as a reservoir of information for developing biological control strategies.</Species>

<Species>Fur negatively regulates hns and is required for the expression of HilA and virulence in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Iron is an essential element for the survival of living cells.</Species>
<Species>However, excess iron is toxic, and its uptake is exquisitely regulated by the ferric uptake regulator, Fur.</Species>
<Species>In Salmonella, the Salmonella pathogenicity island 1 (SPI-1) encodes a type three secretion system, which is required for invasion of host epithelial cells in the small intestine.</Species>
<Species>A major activator of SPI-1 is HilA, which is encoded within SPI-1.</Species>
<Species>One known regulator of hilA is Fur.</Species>
<Species>The mechanism of hilA regulation by Fur is unknown.</Species>

<Species>We report here that Fur is required for virulence in Salmonella enterica serovar Typhimurium and that Fur is required for the activation of hilA, as well as of other HilA-dependent genes, invF and sipC. The Fur-dependent regulation of hilA was independent of PhoP, a known repressor of hilA. Instead, the expression of the gene coding for the histone-like protein, hns, was significantly derepressed in the fur mutant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Indeed, the activation of hilA by Fur was dependent on 28 nucleotides located upstream of hns.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, we used chromatin immunoprecipitation to show that Fur bound, in vivo, to the upstream region of hns in a metal-dependent fashion.</Species>
<Species>Finally, deletion of fur in an hns mutant resulted in Fur-independent activation of hilA. In conclusion, Fur activates hilA by repressing the expression of hns.</Species>
<Species>Host plant effects on alkaline phosphatase activity in the whiteflies, Bemisia tabaci Biotype B and Trialeurodes vaporariorum.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Bemisia tabaci (Gennadius) B-biotype and Trialeurodes vaporariorum (Westwood) (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae) often coexist on greenhouse-grown vegetable crops in northern China.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The recent spread of B. tabaci B-biotype has largely replaced T. vaporariorum, and B-biotype now overlaps with T. vaporariorum where common hosts occur in most invaded areas.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The impact of the B-biotype on the agro eco system appears to be widespread, and involves the ability to compete with and perhaps replace other phytophages like T. vaporariorum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>An emerging hypothesis is that the B-biotype is physiologically superior due at least in part to an improved ability to metabolically utilize the alkaline phosphatase pathway.</Species>

<Species>To test this hypothesis, alkaline phosphatase activity was studied in the B-biotype and T. vaporariorum after feeding on a number of different hosts for a range of durations, with and without host switching.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Alkaline phosphatase activity in T. vaporariorum was 1.45 to 2.53-fold higher than that of the B-biotype when fed on tomato for 4 and 24 h, or switched from tomato to cotton and cabbage for the same durations.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>However, alkaline phosphatase activity in the B-biotype was 1.40 to 3.35-fold higher than that of T. vaporariorum when the host switching time was -72 and -120 h on the same plant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Both short-term (4 h) and long-term (72 h) switching of plant hosts can significantly affect the alkaline phosphatase activity in the two species.</Species>
<Species>After -120 h, feeding on tomato and cotton alkaline phosphatase activity in the B-biotype was significantly higher than that of T. vaporariorum.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>It was shown that alkaline phosphatase aids the species feeding on different plant species, and that the B-biotype is physiologically superior to T. vaporariorum in utilizing the enzyme compared to T. vaporariorum over longer periods of feeding.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Dermamoeba algensis n. sp. (Amoebozoa, Dermamoebidae): an algivorous lobose amoeba with complex cell coat and unusual feeding mode.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The genus Dermamoeba unifies oblong, flattened amoebae of lingulate morphotype, possessing a thick multilayered cell coat.</Species>
<Species>It includes two species, D. granifera and D. minor.</Species>
<Species>In this paper we describe a third species of this genus, D. algensis n. sp.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This species is algivorous; engulfing a large algal cell, it destroys part of the cell coat liberating the plasma membrane, which forms the food vacuole.</Species>
<Species>Thus the glycocalyx never appears inside the phagosome.</Species>
<Species>This observation confirms that some of the thick-coated amoebae may use this way to avoid energetically costly digestion of their own glycocalyx.</Species>

<Species>Studies of the physiology of this organism show that it feeds most actively at a temperature of 22-25 ^0C. Below and above this temperature the feeding intensity drastically decreases.</Species>
<Species>The new species can survive NaCl concentrations up to 5%, which roughly corresponds to 50 ppt salinity.</Species>
<Species>Accordingly, D. algensis has a wide range of salinity tolerance.</Species>

<Species>GintAMT2, a new member of the ammonium transporter family in the arbuscular mycorrhizal fungus Glomus intraradices.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the symbiotic association of plants and arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi, the fungus delivers mineral nutrients, such as phosphate and nitrogen, to the plant while receiving carbon.</Species>
<Species>Previously, we identified an NH(4)(+) transporter in the AM fungus Glomus intraradices (GintAMT1) involved in NH(4)(+) uptake from the soil when preset at low concentrations.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, we report the isolation and characterization of a new G. intraradicesNH(4)(+) transporter gene (GintAMT2).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Yeast mutant complementation assays showed that GintAMT2 encodes a functional NH(4)(+) transporter.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The use of an anti-GintAMT2 polyclonal antibody revealed a plasma membrane location of GintAMT2.</Species>

<Species>GintAMT1 and GintAMT2 were differentially expressed during the fungal life cycle and in response to N. In contrast to GintAMT1, GintAMT2 transcript levels were higher in the intraradical than in the extraradical fungal structures.</Species>
<Species>However, transcripts of both genes were detected in arbuscule-colonized cortical cells.</Species>
<Species>GintAMT1 expression was induced under low N conditions.</Species>

<Species>Constitutive expression of GintAMT2 in N-limiting conditions and transitory induction after N re-supply suggests a role for GintAMT2 to retrieve NH(4)(+) leaked out during fungal metabolism.</Species>
<Species>Cotterillia bromelicola nov. gen., nov. spec., a gonostomatid ciliate (Ciliophora, Hypotricha) from tank bromeliads (Bromeliaceae) with de novo originating dorsal kineties.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cotterillia bromelicola nov. gen., nov. spec.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>was discovered in the tanks of the Mexican bromeliad Tillandsia heterophylla.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Its morphology, ontogenesis, and 18S rDNA were studied with standard methods.</Species>
<Species>Cotterillia has many cirral rows on both sides of the body.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Uniquely, and thus used to diagnose the new genus Cotterillia, it has dorsal kineties originating de novo, producing neokinetal waves where the parental dorsal kineties reorganize to "combined rows", consisting of dorsal bristles anteriorly and of cirri posteriorly.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, up to four generations of bristles and cirri occur on the dorsal body surface.</Species>
<Species>Cotterillia bromelicola has a gonostomatid body and adoral zone of membranelles, while the dense ciliature and the neokinetal waves resemble kahliellid hypotrichs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the de novo origin of anlage 1 and the molecular analyses show convincingly that Cotterillia belongs to the Gonostomatidae Small and Lynn, 1985, for which an improved diagnosis is provided.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, neokinetal waves originated several times independently.</Species>

<Species>The molecular differences between Trachelostyla, Gonostomum, and Cotterillia are small (=< 5%) compared to their distinct morphologies and ontogeneses, suggesting that the 18S rDNA underestimates generic diversity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our study emphasizes the need of combined morphological, ontogenetic, and molecular investigations to unravel the complex phylogeny and evolution of hypotrich ciliates.</Species>
<Species>A cis-encoded antisense small RNA regulated by the HP0165-HP0166 two-component system controls expression of ureB in Helicobacter pylori.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Expression of urease is essential for gastric colonization by Helicobacter pylori.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The increased level of urease in gastric acidity is due, in part, to acid activation of the two-component system (TCS) consisting of the membrane sensor HP0165 and its response regulator, HP0166, which regulates transcription of the seven genes of the urease gene cluster.</Species>

<Species>We now find that there are two major ureAB transcripts: a 2.7-kb full-length ureAB transcript and a 1.4-kb truncated transcript lacking 3' ureB. Acidic pH (pH 4.5) results in a significant increase in transcription of ureAB, while neutral pH (pH 7.4) increases the truncated 1.4-kb transcript.</Species>

<Species>Northern blot analysis with sense RNA and strand-specific oligonucleotide probes followed by 5' rapid amplification of cDNA ends detects an antisense small RNA (sRNA) encoded by the 5' ureB noncoding strand consisting of -290 nucleotides (5'ureB-sRNA).</Species>
<Species>Deletion of HP0165 elevates the level of the truncated 1.4-kb transcript along with that of the 5'ureB-sRNA at both pH 7.4 and pH 4.5.</Species>
<Species>Overexpression of 5'ureB-sRNA increases the 1.4-kb transcript, decreases the 2.7-kb transcript, and decreases urease activity.</Species>
<Species>Electrophoretic mobility shift assay shows that unphosphorylated HP0166 binds specifically to the 5'ureB-sRNA promoter.</Species>

<Species>The ability of the HP0165-HP0166 TCS to both increase and decrease ureB expression at low and high pHs, respectively, facilitates gastric habitation and colonization over the wide range of intragastric pHs experienced by the organism.</Species>
<Species>Reduced predator species richness drives the body gigantism of a frog species on the Zhoushan Archipelago in China.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Shifts in the body size of insular vertebrates have been an interesting theme in ecological and evolutionary studies.</Species>

<Species>Four primary factors, including predation pressures, resource availability, inter-species competition and immigrant selection, have been proposed to explain the trend in insular body size.</Species>

<Species>Life-history theory predicts that body size, average age, the proportion of old-aged members and the density of insular populations are negatively correlated with predator species richness, and that body size and population density are positively related to resource availability.</Species>

<Species>The niche expansion hypothesis argues that a positive relationship is expected to exist between insular body size and prey size, which varies in response to extinction due to small or large competitors.</Species>
<Species>The immigrant hypothesis predicts that insular body size is positively correlated with distance to the mainland.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>We tested these hypotheses by using populations of rice frogs Rana limnocharis on 20 islands in the Zhoushan Archipelago and two sites of nearby mainland China.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>The body size (snout-vent length) of rice frogs on half of the islands was larger before and after the variable of age was controlled for; rice frog density and prey availability was higher and prey size was larger on most of the islands as compared to the two mainland sites.</Species>

<Species>On the islands, the body size and other features [e.g. average age, the proportion of old-aged frogs (ages 3 and 4) and density] of the rice frogs were negatively associated with predator species richness; female body size and other features were positively associated with prey availability.</Species>

<Species>The inference of multivariate linear models based on corrected Akaike Information Criterion (AIC(c) ) showed that the relative importance of predator species richness on body size and each of the other features was larger than that of prey availability, prey size and distance to the mainland.</Species>
<Species>In addition, the parameters for predator species richness were all negative.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>The results provided strong support for the life-history theory of predation pressures, but weak evidence for the life-history theory of prey availability, the niche expansion or the immigrant hypothesis.</Species>
<Species>The reduced predator species richness was a dominant factor contributing to the body gigantism of rice frogs on the islands.</Species>

text: <Species>Microtubule dynamics in mitosis in Aspergillus nidulans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mitosis in Aspergillus nidulans is very rapid, requiring less than 5 min at 37 ^0C in germlings (Bergen and Morris, 1983).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this time the cytoplasmic microtubules (MTs) must disassemble, the mitotic spindle assemble, function and disassemble, and cytoplasmic MTs reassemble.</Species>

<Species>It follows that cytoplasmic MTs must be extremely dynamic in this period and we were interested, in particular, in examining the processes of MT disassembly in prophase and reassembly in anaphase and telophase.</Species>
<Species>We observed a diploid strain that expressed GFP-alpha-tubulin.</Species>
<Species>We used a spinning disk confocal microscope that allowed rapid image capture, which proved necessary because microtubule dynamics were extremely rapid.</Species>
<Species>We found, for the first time, that microtubule severing occurs in prophase in a filamentous fungus and that catastrophe rather than nucleation limits astral microtubule growth.</Species>
<Species>Identification of missing genes and enzymes for autotrophic carbon fixation in crenarchaeota.</Species>
<Species>Two autotrophic carbon fixation cycles have been identified in Crenarchaeota.</Species>
<Species>The dicarboxylate/4-hydroxybutyrate cycle functions in anaerobic or microaerobic autotrophic members of the Thermoproteales and Desulfurococcales.</Species>
<Species>The 3-hydroxypropionate/4-hydroxybutyrate cycle occurs in aerobic autotrophic Sulfolobales; a similar cycle may operate in autotrophic aerobic marine Crenarchaeota.</Species>
<Species>Both cycles form succinyl-coenzyme A (CoA) from acetyl-CoA and two molecules of inorganic carbon, but they use different means.</Species>
<Species>Both cycles have in common the (re)generation of acetyl-CoA from succinyl-CoA via identical intermediates.</Species>

<Species>Here, we identified several missing enzymes/genes involved in the seven-step conversion of succinyl-CoA to two molecules of acetyl-CoA in Thermoproteus neutrophilus (Thermoproteales), Ignicoccus hospitalis (Desulfurococcales), and Metallosphaera sedula (Sulfolobales).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The identified enzymes/genes include succinyl-CoA reductase, succinic semialdehyde reductase, 4-hydroxybutyrate-CoA ligase, bifunctional crotonyl-CoA hydratase/(S)-3-hydroxybutyryl-CoA dehydrogenase, and beta-ketothiolase.</Species>

<Species>4-Hydroxybutyryl-CoA dehydratase, which catalyzes a mechanistically intriguing elimination of water, is well conserved and rightly can be considered the key enzyme of these two cycles.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, several of the other enzymes evolved from quite different sources, making functional predictions based solely on genome interpretation difficult, if not questionable.</Species>
<Species>The peptidoglycan-binding protein FimV promotes assembly of the Pseudomonas aeruginosa type IV pilus secretin.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Pseudomonas aeruginosa inner membrane protein FimV is among several proteins of unknown function required for type IV pilus-mediated twitching motility, arising from extension and retraction of pili from their site of assembly in the inner membrane.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The pili transit the periplasm and peptidoglycan (PG) layer, ultimately exiting the cell through the PilQ secretin.</Species>
<Species>Although fimV mutants are nonmotile, they are susceptible to killing by pilus-specific bacteriophage, a hallmark of retractable surface pili.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here we show that levels of recoverable surface pili were markedly decreased in fimV pilT retraction-deficient mutants compared with levels in the pilT control, demonstrating that FimV acts at the level of pilus assembly.</Species>

<Species>Levels of inner membrane assembly subcomplex proteins PilM/N/O/P were decreased in fimV mutants, but supplementation of these components in trans did not restore pilus assembly or motility.</Species>

<Species>Loss of FimV dramatically reduced the levels of the PilQ secretin multimer through which pili exit the cell, in part due to decreased levels of PilQ monomers, while PilF pilotin levels were unchanged.</Species>
<Species>Expression of pilQ in trans in the wild type or fimV mutants increased total PilQ monomer levels but did not alter secretin multimer levels or motility.</Species>

<Species>PG pulldown assays showed that the N terminus of FimV bound PG in a LysM motif-dependent manner, and a mutant with an in-frame chromosomal deletion of the LysM motif had reduced motility, secretin levels, and surface piliation.</Species>
<Species>Together, our data show that FimV's role in pilus assembly is to promote secretin formation and that this function depends upon its PG-binding domain.</Species>

<Species>A recombinant measles virus unable to antagonize STAT1 function cannot control inflammation and is attenuated in rhesus monkeys.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Measles remains a leading cause of death worldwide among children because it suppresses immune function.</Species>

<Species>The measles virus (MV) P gene encodes three proteins (P, V, and C) that interfere with innate immunity, controlling STAT1, STAT2, mda5, and perhaps other key regulators of immune function.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We identified here three residues in the shared domain of the P and V proteins-tyrosine 110, valine 112, and histidine 115-that function to retain STAT1 in the cytoplasm and inhibit interferon transcription.</Species>

<Species>This information was used to generate a recombinant measles virus unable to antagonize STAT1 function (STAT1-blind MV) differing only in these three residues from a wild-type strain of well-defined virulence.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This virus was used to assess the relevance of P and V interactions with STAT1 for virulence in primates.</Species>

<Species>When a group of six rhesus monkeys (Macaca mulatta) was inoculated intranasally with STAT1-blind MV, viremia was short-lived, and the skin rash and other clinical signs observed with wild-type MV were absent.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The STAT1-blind virus less efficiently controlled the inflammatory response, as measured by enhanced transcription of interleukin-6 and tumor necrosis factor alpha in peripheral blood mononuclear cells from infected hosts.</Species>
<Species>Importantly, neutralizing antibody titers and MV-specific T-cell responses were equivalent in hosts infected with either virus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These findings indicate that efficient MV interactions with STAT1 are required to sustain virulence in a natural host by controlling the inflammatory response against the virus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>They also suggest that selectively STAT1-blind MV may have utility as vectors for targeted oncolysis and vaccination.</Species>

text: <Species>Measles virus (MV) vaccine effectively protects seronegative individuals against infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, inhibition of vaccine-induced seroconversion by maternal antibodies after vaccination remains a problem, as it leaves infants susceptible to MV infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In cotton rats, passive transfer of MV-specific IgG mimics maternal antibodies and inhibits vaccine-induced seroconversion.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, we report that immunization in the presence of passively transferred IgG inhibits the secretion of neutralizing antibodies but not the generation of MV-specific B cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This finding suggested that MV-specific B cells require an additional stimulus to mature into antibody-secreting plasma cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In order to provide such a stimulus, we generated a recombinant Newcastle disease virus (NDV) expressing the MV hemagglutinin (NDV-H).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In contrast to MV, NDV-H induced high levels of type I interferon in plasmacytoid dendritic cells and in lung tissue.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In cotton rats immunized with NDV-H, neutralizing antibodies were also generated in the presence of passively transferred antibodies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the latter case, however, the level and kinetics of antibody generation were reduced.</Species>
<Species>In vitro, alpha interferon stimulated the activation of MV-specific B cells from MV-immune spleen cells.</Species>

text: <Species>NDV infection (which induces alpha interferon) had the same effect, and stimulation could be abrogated by antibodies neutralizing alpha interferon, but not interleukin 6 (IL-6).</Species>

text: <Species>In vivo, coapplication of UV-inactivated MV with NDV led to increased MV-specific antibody production in the presence and absence of passively transferred antibodies.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>These data indicate that MV-specific B cells are being generated after immunization in the presence of maternal antibodies and that the provision of alpha interferon as an additional signal leads to antibody secretion.</Species>

text: <Species>Both cocoon and frass attracted the female parasitoids, but frass alone was more attractive than the cocoon and the cocoon with frass was more attractive than frass alone.</Species>

<Species>Expanding character sampling for ciliate phylogenetic inference using mitochondrial SSU-rDNA as a molecular marker.</Species>
<Species>Molecular systematics of ciliates, particularly at deep nodes, has largely focused on increasing taxon sampling using the nuclear small subunit rDNA</Species>
<Species>(nSSU-rDNA) locus.</Species>
<Species>These previous analyses have generally been congruent with morphologically-based classifications, although there is extensive non-monophyly at many levels.</Species>
<Species>However, caution is needed in interpreting these results as nSSU-rDNA is just a single molecular marker.</Species>
<Species>Here the mitochondrial small subunit rDNA</Species>
<Species>(mtSSU-rDNA) is evaluated for deep ciliate nodes using the Colpodea as an example.</Species>
<Species>Overall, well-supported nodes in the mtSSU-rDNA and concatenated topologies are well supported in the nSSU-rDNA topology; e.g., the non-monophyly of the Cyrtolophosidida.</Species>
<Species>The two moderately- to well-supported incongruences between the loci are the placement of the Sorogenida and Colpoda aspera.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our analyses of mtSSU-rDNA support the conclusion, originally derived from nSSU-rDNA, that the morphological characters used in taxonomic circumscriptions of the Colpodea represent a mixture of ancestral and derived states.</Species>

<Species>This demonstration of the efficacy of the mtSSU-rDNA will enable phylogenetic reconstructions of deep nodes in the ciliate tree of life to move from a single-locus to a multi-locus approach.</Species>

text: <Species>Although the phenotypic effects of facultative symbionts upon hosts have been studied in some detail, little is known about the molecular and genomic basis of these interactions.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>Whole-genome transcriptional profiling and next-generation sequencing demonstrated expression of 94% of RefSeq genes from the pea aphid genome, providing the largest dataset to date on aphid gene expression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, only 28 genes showed changes in expression with S. symbiotica infection, and these changes were of small magnitude.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>No expression differences in genes involved in innate immunity in other insects were observed.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, the large metabolic impact of S. symbiotica is most likely a result of metabolism of the symbiont itself, or of post-transcriptional modification of host gene expression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although S. symbiotica has a major influence on its host's metabolome and resistance to heat, it induces little change in gene expression in its host.</Species>

text: <Species>We have undertaken a proteomics study comparing M. arctica, acclimated at -2^0C, the temperature known to induce the production of the anhydroprotectant trehalose in this species, and -6^0C, the temperature at which trehalose expression plateaus, against control animals acclimated at +5^0C.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Using difference gel electrophoresis, and liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry, we identified three categories of differentially expressed proteins with specific functions, up-regulated in both the -2^0C and -6^0C animals, that were involved in metabolism, membrane transport and protein folding.</Species>

<Species>Drivers of age-specific survival in a long-lived seabird: contributions of observed and hidden sources of heterogeneity.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>We assessed the relative influence of variability in recruitment age, dynamic reproductive investment (time-specific reproductive states) and frailty (unobserved differences in survival abilities across individuals) on survival in the black-legged kittiwake.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, we examined whether observed variability in survival trajectories was best explained by immediate reproductive investment, cumulative investment, or both.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Individuals that delayed recruitment (>= age 7) suffered a higher mortality risk than early recruits (age 3), especially later in life, suggesting that recruitment age may be an indicator of individual quality.</Species>
<Species>Although recruitment age helped explain variation in survival, time-varying reproductive investment had a more substantial influence.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>The dichotomy of attempting to breed or not explained variability in survival across life better than other parameterizations of reproductive states such as clutch size, brood size or breeding success.</Species>
<Species>In the kittiwake, the sinequanon condition to initiate reproduction is to hold a nest site, which is considered a very competitive activity.</Species>
<Species>This might explain why attempting to breed is the key level of investment that affects survival, independent of the outcome (failure or success).</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, the more individuals cumulate reproductive attempts over life, the lower their mortality risk, indicating that breeding experience may be a good indicator of parental quality as well.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, attempting to breed at time t increased the risk of mortality between t and t + 1.</Species>

<Species>We thus detected an immediate trade-off between attempting to breed and survival in this population; however, the earlier individuals recruited, and the more breeding experience they accumulated, the smaller the cost.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Lastly, unobserved heterogeneity across individuals improved model fit more (1*3 times) than fixed and dynamic sources of observed heterogeneity in reproductive investment, demonstrating that it is critical to account for both sources of individual heterogeneity when studying survival trajectories.</Species>

<Species>Only after simultaneously accounting for both sources of heterogeneity were we able to detect the 'cost' of immediate reproductive investment on survival and the 'benefit' of cumulative breeding attempts (experience), a proxy to individual quality.</Species>

text: <Species>Instead, HCMV-induced PABP accumulation resulted from new protein synthesis and was sensitive to the mTORC1-selective inhibitor rapamycin, which interferes with phosphorylation of the mTORC1 substrate p70 S6K and the translational repressor 4E-BP1.</Species>

<Species>A novel strictly anaerobic, moderately halophilic and mesophilic bacterium, designated strain SOL3f37(T), was isolated from a hydrocarbon-polluted soil surrounding a deep petroleum environment located in south Tunisia.</Species>

<Species>Strain SOL3f37(T) had a typical Gram-positive-type cell-wall structure, unlike the thick, multilayered cell wall of its closest relative Clostridiisalibacter paucivorans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The major fatty acids were iso-C(15 : 0) (41 %), iso-C(14 : 0) 3-OH and/or iso-C(15 : 0) dimethyl acetal (21.6 %), iso-C(13 : 0) (4.4 %), anteiso-C(15 : 0) (3.9 %) and iso-C(15 : 1) (2.8 %).</Species>
<Species>Strain SOL3f37(T) grew between 20 and 48 ^0C (optimum 40 ^0C) and at pH 6.2-8.1 (optimum pH 6.9).</Species>

<Species>Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences revealed that strain SOL3f37(T) was a member of the family Clostridiaceae in the order Clostridiales; strain SOL3f37(T) was related to members of various genera of the family Clostridiaceae.</Species>

<Species>Norovirus GII.4 strain antigenic variation.</Species>
<Species>Noroviruses are the principal cause of epidemic gastroenteritis worldwide.</Species>

<Species>Multiple reports have concluded that the major capsid proteins of GII.4 strains, which cause 80% of norovirus infections worldwide, are evolving rapidly, resulting in new epidemic strains.</Species>

<Species>Surrogate neutralization assays using sera from outbreaks and from immunized mice suggest that, as with influenza virus, antigenic variation maintains GII.4 persistence in the face of human population herd immunity.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>To test this hypothesis, mice were hyperimmunized with virus-like particles (VLPs) representing an early (GII.4-1987) and a contemporary (GII.4-2006) GII.4 strain.</Species>
<Species>Anti-GII.4-1987 IgG monoclonal antibodies (MAbs) strongly reacted with GII.4 VLPs derived between only 1987 and 2002.</Species>
<Species>Ligand binding blockade was more efficient with GII.4-1987 and GII.4-1997 VLPs than with GII.4-2002.</Species>
<Species>Anti-GII.4-2006 IgG MAbs recognized either a broad panel of GII.4 VLPs (1987 to 2006) or a subset of contemporary (2004 to 2006) VLPs.</Species>
<Species>Most 2006 antibodies did not recognize or only poorly recognized GII.4 VLPs of 2007 or 2008, documenting rapid antigenic evolution of GII.4 capsids.</Species>
<Species>Generally, 2006 MAbs blocked homotypic VLP-ligand binding but were unable to block VLPs representing strains primarily circulating during or earlier than 2002.</Species>

<Species>These analyses demonstrate that both subtle and significant evolutionary change has occurred within antibody epitopes between epidemic strains, providing direct evidence that the GII.4 noroviruses are undergoing antigenic variation, likely in response to herd immunity.</Species>

<Species>As with influenza virus, HIV, and hepatitis C virus, norovirus antigenic variation will significantly influence the design of efficacious vaccines and immunotherapeutics against these important human pathogens.</Species>

text: <Species>p27 is an antigenic protein produced by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, the etiologic agent of paracoccidioidomycosis (PCM).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Despite its unknown function, it has been suggested as a putative virulence factor, proposed as a suitable target for the design of diagnostic tools and vaccines, and considered as an enhancer in antifungal treatment of PCM.</Species>
<Species>We evaluated sequence polymorphisms of PbP27 gene sequence among isolates, finding some polymorphisms associated with the isolates' phylogenetic origin.</Species>

<Species>In order to determine if there was a differential expression pattern between morphological states and among isolates, we also evaluated PbP27 expression, at transcriptional and translational levels, in mycelia and yeast cultures in 14 isolates belonging to the P. brasiliensis species complex (S1, PS2, PS3, and "Pb01-like", proposed to be named Paracoccidioides lutzii) by two techniques, real time RT-PCR (RT-qPCR) and protein dot blot.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>For the latter, four protein extracts from different cell localizations (SDS or Beta-mercaptoethanol, cytoplasmic and extracellular proteins) were analyzed for each isolate.</Species>
<Species>p27 was present in the four extracts evaluated, mainly in the SDS extract, corresponding to an extract containing proteins loosely attached to the cell wall.</Species>
<Species>This information correlates with immunohistochemical analysis, where positive staining of the yeasts' cell wall was observed.</Species>
<Species>We found that p27 was present in all isolates, mainly in the yeast form.</Species>
<Species>This pattern was corroborated by RT-qPCR results, with higher expression levels found in the yeast form for most of the isolates.</Species>
<Species>The results provide new insights into the expression patterns of this protein, and further characterize it in view of potential uses as a diagnostic and/or therapeutic tool.</Species>

text: <Species>Following primary infection, KSHV typically goes through a brief period of lytic replication prior to the establishment of latency.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Plasmacytoid dendritic cells (pDCs) are the major producers of type 1 interferon (IFN), primarily in response to virus infection.</Species>
<Species>Toll-like receptors (TLRs) are key components of the innate immune system, and they serve as pathogen recognition receptors that stimulate the host antiviral response.</Species>
<Species>pDCs express exclusively TLR7 and TLR9, and it is through these TLRs that the type 1 interferon response is activated in pDCs.</Species>
<Species>Currently, it is not known whether KSHV is recognized by pDCs and whether activation of pDCs occurs in response to KSHV infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We now report evidence that KSHV can infect human pDCs and that pDCs are activated upon KSHV infection, as measured by upregulation of CD83 and CD86 and by IFN-alpha secretion.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We further show that induction of IFN-alpha occurs through activation of TLR9 signaling and that a TLR9 inhibitor diminishes the production and secretion of IFN-alpha by KSHV-infected pDCs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Green-colored plastids in the dinoflagellate genus Lepidodinium are of core chlorophyte origin.</Species>

<Species>Most photosynthetic dinoflagellates possess plastids containing chlorophyllsa+c,but species belonging to the genus Lepidodinium are unique in bearing non-canonical plastids containing chlorophyllsa+b.</Species>

<Species>According to the pioneering works on pigment composition data, it has been proposed that Lepidodinium plastids were derived from a prasinophyte species, though this hypothesis was not supported by a recent phylogenetic analysis based on an alignment comprised of eight plastid proteins (Takishita et al. 2008, Gene 410: 26-26).</Species>

<Species>This "8-protein" analysis however was insufficient to clarify the origin of Lepidodinium plastids for two major reasons: First, the alignment lacked sufficient evolutionary information to resolve the precise origin of Lepidodinium plastids.</Species>
<Species>Second, the taxa considered did not well represent the diversity of Chlorophyta.</Species>
<Species>Particularly, prasinophytes were poorly sampled in the alignment.</Species>
<Species>In this study, we sequenced plastid-encoded genes from L. chlorophorum, one pedinophyte species, one ulvophyte species, and six prasinophyte species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The 85 sequences newly determined in this study and recent progress in plastid genome sequencing enabled us to prepare an alignment comprised of 11 plastid proteins from green algal taxa that appropriately cover the diversity of Chlorophyta.</Species>

<Species>All the analyses of the 11-protein data set robustly grouped L. chlorophorum with members of the "core chlorophytes." Thus, we here propose that Lepidodinium plastids are of core chlorophyte origin.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mannitol permeation and radial flow of water in maize roots.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>* The postulated nonselective hydraulic route through the root apoplast has not yet been supported by experimental findings on solvent drag.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Therefore, mannitol transport from the medium to the shoot of young maize plants was studied at different rates of transpiration in hydroculture.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The concentration of mannitol was determined by gas chromatography.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Mannitol utilization in shoot metabolism was not detectable.</Species>
<Species>Experiments with exuding roots showed that the radial transport of mannitol was mainly apoplastic.</Species>

<Species>The ratio alpha between the mannitol concentration in xylem vessels and that of the external medium was calculated from mannitol translocation to the shoot or measurement of the mannitol concentration in the root exudate, where it reached c. 0.07 in the steady state.</Species>
<Species>In transpiring plants, alpha decreased with increasing water flux from 0.04 to values below 0.01.</Species>
<Species>These findings demonstrate that the root reflection coefficient for mannitol is above 0.99.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>It is concluded that the radial movement of water to the vessels is under complete protoplastic control, whereas solutes can diffuse on an apoplastic path.</Species>

<Species>The absence of a significant volume flux through the root apoplast is of physiological importance as it prevents the coupling of the apoplastic permeation of ballast solutes, such as NaCl, to transpiration.</Species>
<Species>Tyrosine phosphorylation of actin during microcyst formation and germination in Polysphondylium pallidum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>High osmolarity causes amoebae of the cellular slime mould Polysphondylium pallidum to individually encyst, forming microcysts.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>During microcyst differentiation, actin is tyrosine phosphorylated.</Species>
<Species>Tyrosine phosphorylation of actin is independent of encystment conditions and occurs during the final stages of microcyst formation.</Species>
<Species>During microcyst germination, actin undergoes dephosphorylation prior to amoebal emergence.</Species>
<Species>Renewed phosphorylation of actin in germinating microcysts can be triggered by increasing the osmolarity of the medium which inhibits emergence.</Species>
<Species>Immunofluorescence reveals that actin is dispersed throughout the cytoplasm in dormant microcysts.</Species>
<Species>Following the onset of germination, actin is observed around vesicles where it co-localizes with phosphotyrosine.</Species>
<Species>Prior to emergence, actin localizes to patches near the cell surface.</Species>
<Species>Increasing osmolarity disrupts this localization and causes actin to redistribute throughout the cytoplasm, a situation similar to that observed in dormant microcysts.</Species>
<Species>The tyrosine phosphorylation state of actin does not appear to influence the long-term viability of dormant microcysts.</Species>
<Species>Together, these results indicate an association between actin tyrosine phosphorylation, organization of the actin cytoskeleton, and microcyst dormancy.</Species>
<Species>Competitive interactions shape offspring performance in relation to seasonal timing of emergence in Atlantic salmon.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1. Timing of birth/hatching may have strong effects on offspring fitness.</Species>

<Species>Breeding time is generally considered to have evolved to match offspring arrival with optimal seasonal environmental conditions, though this is rarely tested experimentally and factors shaping the relations between timing of birth and reproductive success are often poorly understood.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>By manipulating incubation temperature of Atlantic salmon embryos, and hence controlling for maternal and genetic effects, we obtained offspring emerging from nests prior to (accelerated), during and after (decelerated) normal emergence times, and accordingly experienced widely different seasonal environmental conditions at emergence (stream temperature range 4-16 ^0C).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The accelerated group emerged at temperatures that are generally considered to be highly sub-optimal for growth and likely imposes strong constraints on feeding and activity, and during a peak in water discharge which is expected to negatively influence habitat availability.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>In the wild, overall mortality during the period after emergence was 79%, and was significantly affected by both release density and emergence timing.</Species>
<Species>Accelerated offspring, which emerged earliest and experienced the harshest environmental conditions, had both highest survival and largest final body size.</Species>
<Species>The effect was particularly strong at the high density release site, where survival of accelerated offspring was significantly higher than both the normal and decelerated groups.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>In more controlled semi-natural environments, all developmental groups were able to perform well, but accelerated offspring had a relatively better performance than the later emerging offspring when density was high.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, the relative performance of the different groups was not sensitive to water discharge regimes (temporally stable vs. fluctuating).</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that the performance of offspring in relation to seasonal timing of emergence is highly affected by competitive interactions in Atlantic salmon.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although a match between phenology and optimal seasonal environmental conditions may be highly important for organisms depending on specific resources that are only available during a limited period of the season, such resources may be available in variable amounts year around for many organisms.</Species>
<Species>For these, offspring success may to a larger degree be shaped by the timing of their hatching/birth relative to each other, and particularly so under high population densities.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>* Primary carbohydrate metabolism plays a special role related to carbon/nitrogen exchange, as well as metabolic support of fruiting body development, in ectomycorrhizal macrofungi.</Species>

<Species>In this study, we used information retrieved from the recently sequenced Tuber melanosporum genome, together with transcriptome analysis data and targeted validation experiments, to construct the first genome-wide catalogue of the proteins supporting carbohydrate metabolism in a plant-symbiotic ascomycete.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>*</Species>

<Species>More than 100 genes coding for enzymes of the glycolysis, pentose phosphate, tricarboxylic acid, glyoxylate and methylcitrate pathways, glycogen, trehalose and mannitol metabolism and cell wall precursor were annotated.</Species>

<Species>Transcriptional regulation of these pathways in different stages of the T. melanosporum lifecycle was investigated using whole-genome oligoarray expression data together with real-time reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction analysis of selected genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>*</Species>

<Species>The most significant results were the identification of methylcitrate cycle genes and of an acid invertase, the first enzyme of this kind to be described in a plant-symbiotic filamentous fungus.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>

<Species>A subset of transcripts coding for trehalose, glyoxylate and methylcitrate enzymes was up-regulated in fruiting bodies, whereas genes involved in mannitol and glycogen metabolism were preferentially expressed in mycelia and ectomycorrhizas, respectively.</Species>
<Species>These data indicate a high degree of lifecycle stage specialization for particular branches of carbohydrate metabolism in T. melanosporum.</Species>

text: <Species>A fluorescence resonance energy transfer-based fluorometer assay for screening anti-coxsackievirus B3 compounds.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In view of the need to develop a simple and rapid method to screen for antiviral therapeutic agents, a fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET)-based reporter system consisting of engineered mammalian cells expressing a cyan fluorescent protein-yellow fluorescent protein (CFP-YFP) pair linked by a short peptide containing the cleavage site of viral protease 2A (2A(pro)) was developed.</Species>

<Species>By detecting the 2A(pro) produced early during the virus infection cycle, the CFP-YFP pair effectively identifies infectious coxsackievirus B3 (CVB3), a picornavirus that causes viral myocarditis in humans.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The reporter system was used to screen a library of 2000 drugs and natural products for potential antiviral compounds.</Species>
<Species>The reporter cells were treated with the test compounds, challenged with CVB3, and then examined using a fluorometer at 24h post-infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sixty-four compounds, mostly therapeutic drugs, antimicrobial compounds and compounds with unknown functions, caused at least 50% inhibition of 2A(pro) activity.</Species>
<Species>Three known antiviral compounds, cosmosiin, ribavirin and baicalein, were also identified in the screening.</Species>
<Species>The developed method is an effective strategy for rapid screening, and identifies compounds that inhibit CVB3 2A(pro).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This method should be a valuable aid in the antiviral drug discovery effort.</Species>

<Species>Mutational analysis of the transmembrane helix 2-HAMP domain connection in the Escherichia coli aspartate chemoreceptor tar.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Transmembrane helix 2 (TM2) of the Tar chemoreceptor undergoes an inward piston-like displacement of 1 to 3 A upon binding aspartate.</Species>
<Species>This signal is transmitted to the kinase-control module via the HAMP domain.</Species>
<Species>Within Tar, the HAMP domain forms a parallel four-helix bundle consisting of a dimer of two amphipathic helices connected by a flexible linker.</Species>

<Species>In the nuclear magnetic resonance structure of an archaeal HAMP domain, residues corresponding to the MLLT sequence between Arg-214 at the end of TM2 and Pro-219 of Tar are an N-terminal helical extension of AS1.</Species>
<Species>We modified this region to test whether it behaves as a continuous helical connection between TM2 and HAMP.</Species>
<Species>First, one to four Gly residues were inserted between Thr-218 and Pro-219.</Species>
<Species>Second, the MLLT sequence was replaced with one to nine Gly residues.</Species>
<Species>Third, the sequence was shortened or extended with residues compatible with helix formation.</Species>
<Species>Cells expressing receptors in which the MLLT sequence was shortened to MLL or in which the MLLT sequence was replaced by four Gly residues performed good aspartate chemotaxis.</Species>
<Species>Other mutant receptors supported diminished aspartate taxis.</Species>
<Species>Most mutant receptors had biased signal outputs and/or abnormal patterns of adaptive methylation.</Species>
<Species>We interpret these results to indicate that a strong, permanent helical connection between TM2 and the HAMP domain is not necessary for normal transmembrane signaling.</Species>
<Species>Spatial regulation of histidine kinases governing biofilm formation in Bacillus subtilis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Bacillus subtilis is able to form architecturally complex biofilms on solid medium due to the production of an extracellular matrix.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A master regulator that controls the expression of the genes involved in matrix synthesis is Spo0A, which is activated by phosphorylation via a phosphorelay involving multiple histidine kinases.</Species>
<Species>Here we report that four kinases, KinA, KinB, KinC, and KinD, help govern biofilm formation but that their contributions are partially masked by redundancy.</Species>

<Species>We show that the kinases fall into two categories and that the members of each pair (one pair comprising KinA and KinB and the other comprising KinC and KinD) are partially redundant with each other.</Species>

<Species>We also show that the kinases are spatially regulated: KinA and KinB are active principally in the older, inner regions of the colony, and KinC and KinD function chiefly in the younger, outer regions.</Species>

<Species>These conclusions are based on the morphology of kinase mutants, real-time measurements of gene expression using luciferase as a reporter, and confocal microscopy using a fluorescent protein as a reporter.</Species>

<Species>Our findings suggest that multiple signals from the older and younger regions of the colony are integrated by the kinases to determine the overall architecture of the biofilm community.</Species>
<Species>Linking irradiance-induced changes in pit membrane ultrastructure with xylem vulnerability to cavitation.</Species>
<Species>The effect of shading on xylem hydraulic traits and xylem anatomy was studied in hybrid poplar (Populus trichocarpa x deltoides, clone H11-11).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Hydraulic measurements conducted on stem segments of 3-month-old saplings grown in shaded (SH) or control light (C) conditions indicated that shading resulted in more vulnerable and less efficient xylem.</Species>
<Species>Air is thought to enter vessels through pores in inter-vessel pit membranes, thereby nucleating cavitation.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, we tested if the ultrastructure and/or chemistry of pit membranes differed in SH and C plants.</Species>
<Species>Transmission electron micrographs revealed that pit membranes were thinner in SH, which was paralleled by lower compound middle lamella thickness.</Species>

<Species>Immunolabelling with JIM5 and JIM7 monoclonal antibodies surprisingly indicated that pectic homogalacturonans were not present in the mature pit membrane regardless of the light treatment.</Species>
<Species>Porosity measurements conducted with scanning electron microscopy were significantly affected by the method used for sample dehydration.</Species>
<Species>Drying through a gradual ethanol series seems to be a better alternative to drying directly from a hydrated state for pit membrane observations in poplar.</Species>
<Species>Scanning electron microscopy based estimates of pit membrane porosity probably overestimated real porosity as suggested by the results from the 'rare pit' model.</Species>
<Species>Titrating the cost of plant toxins against predators: determining the tipping point for foraging herbivores.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Foraging herbivores must deal with plant characteristics that inhibit feeding and they must avoid being eaten.</Species>
<Species>Principally, toxins limit food intake, while predation risk alters how long animals are prepared to harvest resources.</Species>
<Species>Each of these factors strongly affects how herbivores use food patches, and both constraints can pose immediate proximate costs and long-term consequences to fitness.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Using a generalist mammalian herbivore, the common brushtail possum (Trichosurus vulpecula), our aim was to quantitatively compare the influence of plant toxin and predation risk on foraging decisions.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>
<Species>We performed a titration experiment by offering animals a choice between non-toxic food at a risky patch paired with food with one of five toxin concentrations at a safe patch.</Species>
<Species>This allowed us to identify the tipping point, where the cost of toxin in the safe food patch was equivalent to the perceived predation risk in the alternative patch.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>At low toxin concentration, animals ate more from the safe than the risky patch.</Species>
<Species>As toxin concentration increased at the safe patch, intake shifted until animals ate mainly from the risky patch.</Species>
<Species>This shift was associated with behavioural changes: animals spent more time and fed longer at the risky patch, while vigilance increased at both risky and safe patches.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Our results demonstrate that the variation in toxin concentration, which occurs intraspecifically among plants, can critically influence the relative cost of predation risk on foraging.</Species>
<Species>We show that herbivores quantify, compare and balance these two different but proximate costs, altering their foraging patterns in the process.</Species>
<Species>This has potential ecological and evolutionary implications for the production of plant defence compounds in relation to spatial variation in predation risk to herbivores.</Species>

text: <Species>*</Species>

text: <Species>Cellular damage was assessed by Evans blue penetration (enhanced membrane permeability) and by H2O2 generation [3,3'-diaminobenzidine 4HCl (DAB)-staining].</Species>
<Species>Critical temperature for dark fluorescence (F(0) ) rise (T(F)) was at 46-48 ^0C, and a burst of respiration was observed near T(F).</Species>
<Species>However, A(n) was strongly inhibited already before T(F) was reached.</Species>

<Species>Membrane permeability increased with temperature according to a switch-type response, with enhanced permeability observed above 48 ^0C. Experiments with varying heat pulse lengths and intensities underscored the threshold-type loss of photosynthetic function, and indicated that the degree of photosynthetic deterioration and cellular damage depended on accumulated heat-dose.</Species>

<Species>Beyond the 'point of no return', propagation of cellular damage and reduction of photosynthesis continued upon transfer to lower temperatures and photosynthetic recovery was slow or absent.</Species>
<Species>We conclude that instability of photosynthesis under severe heat stress is associated with time-dependent propagation of cellular lesions.</Species>
<Species>Effects of deficiency and overdose of group 2 sigma factors in triple inactivation strains of Synechocystis sp. strain PCC 6803.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Acclimation of cyanobacteria to environmental changes includes major changes in the gene expression patterns partly orchestrated by the replacement of a particular sigma subunit with another in the RNA polymerase holoenzyme.</Species>
<Species>The cyanobacterium Synechocystis sp. strain PCC 6803 encodes nine sigma factors, all belonging to the sigma(70) family.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cyanobacteria typically encode many group 2 sigma factors that closely resemble the principal sigma factor.</Species>

<Species>We inactivated three out of the four group 2 sigma factors of Synechocystis simultaneously in all possible combinations and found that all triple inactivation strains grow well under standard conditions.</Species>

<Species>Unlike the other strains, the DeltasigBCD strain, which contains SigE as the only functional group 2 sigma factor, did not grow faster under mixotrophic than under autotrophic conditions.</Species>
<Species>The SigB and SigD factors were important in low-temperature acclimation, especially under diurnal light rhythm.</Species>
<Species>The DeltasigBCD, DeltasigBCE, and DeltasigBDE strains were sensitive to high-light-induced photoinhibition, indicating a central role of the SigB factor in high-light tolerance.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, the DeltasigBCE strain (SigD is the only functional group 2 sigma factor) appeared to be locked in the high-fluorescence state (state 1) and grew slowly in blue but not in orange or white light.</Species>

<Species>Our results suggest that features of the triple inactivation strains can be categorized as (i) direct consequences of the inactivation of a particular sigma factor(s) and (ii) effects resulting from the higher probability that the remaining group 2 sigma factors associate with the RNA polymerase core.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>In India, there has been co-circulation, extinction and emergence of genotypes/lineages within serotype A foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) virus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At present an antigenically heterogeneous, unique lineage within genotype VII dominates the field outbreaks.</Species>
<Species>This genetic cluster has amino acid deletion at position 59 of VP3 (VP3(59)-deletion group), considered to be critical antigenically.</Species>
<Species>The emergence of this group warrants rapid and accurate detection to facilitate early planning and implementation of an effective control policy.</Species>

<Species>A rapid multiplex PCR assay was developed for detection of the dominating VP3(59)-deletion group with 100% sensitivity and specificity, even before generating sequence data and confirmatory phylogenetic analysis.</Species>
<Species>This development is important for surveillance of FMD in India.</Species>

text: <Species>Intestinal ciliate composition found in the feces of the Turk rahvan horse Equus caballus, Linnaeus 1758.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Species composition and distribution of large intestinal ciliates were investigated in the feces from 15 Turk rahvan horses, living in the vicinity of Izmir, Turkey.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Twenty-two ciliate genera consisting of 36 species were identified.</Species>
<Species>This is the first report on intestinal ciliates in Turk rahvan horses and no previously unknown species were observed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The mean number of ciliates was 14.2+/-13.9x10(4) cells ml(-1) of feces and the mean number of ciliate species per host was 9.9+/-7.1.</Species>
<Species>No ciliates were observed in 2 horses.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Bundleia and Blepharocorys were considered to be the major genera since these ciliates were constantly found in high proportions.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, Paraisotricha, Didesmis and Gassovskiella were only observed at low frequencies.</Species>

<Species>The ciliates found in this survey had almost the same characteristics as those described in previous reports, suggesting that there was no significant geographic variation in the intestinal ciliate fauna of equids.</Species>
<Species>Scales of orientation, directed walks and movement path structure in sharks.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Animal search patterns reflect sensory perception ranges combined with memory and knowledge of the surrounding environment.</Species>
<Species>2. Random walks are used when the locations of resources are unknown, whereas directed walks should be optimal when the location of favourable habitats is known.</Species>
<Species>However, directed walks have been quantified for very few species.</Species>
<Species>3. We re-analysed tracking data from three shark species to determine whether they were using directed walks, and if so, over which spatial scales.</Species>
<Species>Fractal analysis was used to quantify how movement structure varied with spatial scale and determine whether the sharks were using patches.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>Tiger sharks performed directed walks at large spatial scales (at least 6-8 km).</Species>

<Species>Thresher sharks also showed directed movement (at scales of 400-1900 m), and adult threshers were able to orient at greater scales than juveniles, which may suggest that learning improves the ability to perform directed walks.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Blacktip reef sharks had small home ranges, high site fidelity and showed no evidence of oriented movements at large scales.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>
<Species>There were inter- and intraspecific differences in path structure and patch size, although most individuals showed scale-dependent movements.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, some individuals of each species performed movements similar to a correlated random walk.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>Sharks can perform directed walks over large spatial scales, with scales of movements reflecting site fidelity and home range size.</Species>
<Species>Understanding when and where directed walks occur is crucial for developing more accurate population-level dispersal models.</Species>

text: <Species>The presence of arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) influences plant nutrient uptake, growth, and plant defensive chemistry, thereby directly influencing multi-trophic interactions.</Species>

<Species>Plants infected with different AMF genotypes may vary in foliar nutrient or defensive chemical levels, potentially influencing multi-trophic interactions.</Species>

<Species>Using a completely randomized design, we compared the effect of two isolates of the mycorrhizal fungus Glomus etunicatum W. N. Becker & Gerdemann on silver leaf whitefly (Bemisia argentifolii Bellows & Perring) (Hemiptera: Aleyrodidae) and parasitic wasp (Eretmocerus eremicus Rose & Zolnerowich) (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae) abundance.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>Whitefly populations were not influenced by AMF infection.</Species>

<Species>We propose that AMF indirectly influences parasite abundance and parasitism through a change in leaf surface chemicals that affect parasitic wasps.</Species>
<Species>Because of the ubiquity of and genetic variation in AMF, multi-trophic interactions are likely to be strongly influenced by belowground processes.</Species>

<Species>Recently, genes coding for odorant receptors (ORs) OR6, OR14, OR15 and OR16 have been genetically associated with species-specific male response to female pheromone blends in Heliothis virescens (Hv) and Heliothis subflexa (Hs).</Species>

<Species>Transcription factors BmPOUM2 and BmBetaFTZ-F1 are involved in regulation of the expression of the wing cuticle protein gene BmWCP4 in the silkworm, Bombyx mori.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In Bombyx mori, the wing cuticle protein gene BmWCP4 is expressed specifically in the epidermis at the onset and mid-stage of pupation and is responsible for the formation of the pupal cuticle during the larval-pupal metamorphosis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The gene consists of four exons and three introns and is present as a single copy in the genome.</Species>
<Species>Its expression was up-regulated by 20-hydroxyecdysone (20E) and the 20E-induced expression was suppressed by juvenile hormone (JH) III.</Species>
<Species>The upstream regulatory sequence region of the BmWCP4 gene was cloned and the regulatory elements responsible for 20E induction were identified.</Species>
<Species>Two cis-regulatory elements (CREs) bound by the transcription factors BmPOUM2 and BmBetaFTZ-F1 were identified that mediated 20E-regulated expression of this gene.</Species>

<Species>An electrophoretic mobility shift assay detected two nuclear proteins isolated from the epidermis and the BmN cell line that specifically bound to the POU and BetaFTZ-F1 CREs, respectively.</Species>
<Species>BmPOUM2 recombinant protein explicitly bound to the POU CRE.</Species>
<Species>Developmental and 20E-induced expression of the BmWCP4, BmPOUM2 and BmBetaFTZ-F1 genes showed that BmPOUM2 and BmBetaFTZ-F1 were initially expressed, followed by BmWCP4.</Species>

<Species>These data suggest that the 20E-induced expression of BmWCP4 is mediated by the transcription factors BmPOUM2 and BmBetaFTZ-F1 binding to their CREs in the regulatory sequence region of the BmWCP4 gene.</Species>
