<Species>Host phylogeography and beta diversity in avian haemosporidian (Plasmodiidae) assemblages of the Lesser Antilles.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>We estimated the correlation between host phylogeographical structure and beta diversity of avian haemosporidian assemblages of passerine birds to determine the degree to which parasite communities change with host evolution, expressed as genetic divergence between island populations, and we investigated whether differences among islands in the haemosporidia of a particular host species reflect beta diversity in the entire parasite assemblage, beta diversity in vectors, turnover of bird species and/or geographical distance.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>We used Mantel tests to assess the significance of partial correlations between host nucleotide difference (based on cytochrome b) and haemosporidian (Haemoproteus spp.</Species>
<Species>and Plasmodium spp.)</Species>

<Species>mitochondrial lineage beta diversity within a given host species and between Plasmodium mitochondrial lineage beta diversity and mosquito and bird species beta diversity (or turnover).</Species>
<Species>Three abundant and widespread host species (Tiaris bicolor, Coereba flaveola and Loxigilla noctis/barbadensis) were included in the study.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Haemosporidian lineage beta diversity among nine islands was assessed using the Chao-Jaccard, Chao-Sorensen and Morisita-Horn indices of community similarity.</Species>
<Species>Beta diversity indices of mosquito species and turnover of bird species were calculated from data in published records and field guides.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>In Loxigilla spp., we found a positive correlation with geographical distance and an unexpected negative correlation between haemosporidian beta diversity and host genetic distance.</Species>
<Species>Tiaris bicolor exhibited a significant positive correlation between haemosporidian beta diversity and beta diversity within the entire parasite assemblage.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We did not find significant correlations between parasite beta diversity and mosquito beta diversity or bird species turnover.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>Host phylogeographical structure does not appear to drive within-host beta diversity of haemosporidian lineages.</Species>
<Species>Instead, the array of parasites on one host can reflect the haemosporidian assemblage on other hosts.</Species>

text: <Species>*</Species>

text: <Species>The absence of lupeol in the silenced plant lines was determined by GC-MS.</Species>

<Species>Silenced plants also showed a more rapid nodulation phenotype, consistent with this.</Species>

<Species>Evaluation of tag entanglement as a factor in harmonic radar studies of insect dispersal.</Species>

<Species>The observation of insects and other small organisms entangled in the habitat after the addition of vertical or trailing electronic tags to their body has generated concerns on the suitability of harmonic radars to track the dispersal of insects.</Species>

<Species>This study compared the walking behavior of adult Colorado potato beetle (Leptinotarsa decemlineata (Say) Chrysomelidae), plum curculio (Conotrachelus nenuphar (Herbst) Curculionidae), and western corn rootworm (Diabrotica virgifera virgifera (LeConte) Chrysomelidae) with and without vertical and or trailing tags in field plots or arenas.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The frequency of the larger Colorado potato beetles crossing bare ground or grassy plots was unaffected by the presence of an 8 cm trailing harmonic radar tag.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, plum curculios and western corn rootworms, were either unable to walk with a 4 cm trailing tag (plum curculio) or displayed a reduced ability to successfully cross a bare ground arena.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Our results revealed the significant impact of vegetation on successful insect dispersal, whether tagged or not.</Species>
<Species>The vertical movement of these insects on stems, stalks, and tubes was also unaffected by the presence of vertical tags.</Species>
<Species>Trailing tags had a significant negative effect on the vertical movement of the western corn rootworm.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Results show that harmonic radar technology is a suitable method for studying the walking paths of the three insects with appropriate tag type and size.</Species>
<Species>The nuisance factor generated by appropriately sized tags was small relative to that of vegetation.</Species>

text: <Species>Involvement of a helix-loop-helix transcription factor CHC-1 in CO(2)-mediated conidiation suppression in Neurospora crassa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The morphological switch from vegetative growth to conidiation in filamentous fungi is highly regulated, but the understanding of the regulatory mechanisms is limited.</Species>

<Species>In this study, by screening a set of knock-out mutants corresponding to 103 transcription factor encoding genes in Neurospora crassa, a mutant was found to produce abundant conidia in race tubes in which conidiation in the wild-type strain was suppressed.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The corresponding gene NCU00749 encodes a protein containing a helix-loop-helix DNA binding region.</Species>

<Species>Unlike enhanced conidiation in ras-1 and sod-1 mutants, which was completely suppressed by antioxidant N-acetyl cysteine, enhanced conidiation in the NCU00749 mutant was only slightly affected by N-acetyl cysteine.</Species>
<Species>When grown on slants, the NCU00749 deletion mutant exhibited earlier conidial formation than the wild-type strain, and this was more evident at a higher (5%) CO(2) concentration.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, we named NCU00749 as conidiation at high carbon dioxide-1 (chc-1).</Species>

<Species>Genes that are highly expressed during conidial development, eas, con-6, con-8 and con-10, were transcribed at a higher rate in the chc-1 deletion mutant than the wild-type strain in response to conidiation induction.</Species>

<Species>To determine the mechanisms by which CHC-1 regulates conidiation, we conducted a RNA sequencing analysis and found that 404 genes exhibited >= 2 fold changes in transcription in response to chc-1 deletion.</Species>

<Species>Among them, fluffy and ada-6, two transcription factor genes that positively regulate conidiation in N. crassa, and rca-1, whose homolog flbD in Aspergillus nidulans is essential for conidiation, were upregulated in the chc-1 deletion mutant.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Results of RNA sequencing also suggest that signal transduction via the cAMP and the MAK-2 mediated signal pathways, and ROS generation and removal, mechanisms known to regulate conidiation, are not involved in chc-1 mediated control of conidiation.</Species>

<Species>In addition, chc-1 also influences expression of genes involved in other important biological processes besides conidiation such as carbon metabolism, sphingolipid synthesis, cell wall synthesis, and calcium signaling.</Species>

<Species>Small-molecule inhibition of human immunodeficiency virus type 1 infection by virus capsid destabilization.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (HIV-1) infection is dependent on the proper disassembly of the viral capsid, or "uncoating," in target cells.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The HIV-1 capsid consists of a conical multimeric complex of the viral capsid protein (CA) arranged in a hexagonal lattice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mutations in CA that destabilize the viral capsid result in impaired infection owing to defects in reverse transcription in target cells.</Species>
<Species>We describe here the mechanism of action of a small molecule HIV-1 inhibitor, PF-3450074 (PF74), which targets CA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>PF74 acts at an early stage of HIV-1 infection and inhibits reverse transcription in target cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We show that PF74 binds specifically to HIV-1 particles, and substitutions in CA that confer resistance to the compound prevent binding.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A single point mutation in CA that stabilizes the HIV-1 core also conferred strong resistance to the virus without inhibiting compound binding.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Treatment of HIV-1 particles or purified cores with PF74 destabilized the viral capsid in vitro.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, the compound induced the rapid dissolution of the HIV-1 capsid in target cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>PF74 antiviral activity was promoted by binding of the host protein cyclophilin A to the HIV-1 capsid, and PF74 and cyclosporine exhibited mutual antagonism.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our data suggest that PF74 triggers premature HIV-1 uncoating in target cells, thereby mimicking the activity of the retrovirus restriction factor TRIM5alpha.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This study highlights uncoating as a step in the HIV-1 life cycle that is susceptible to small molecule intervention.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Introduced brown trout alter native acanthocephalan infections in native fish.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Native parasite acquisition provides introduced species with the potential to modify native host-parasite dynamics by acting as parasite reservoirs (with the 'spillback' of infection increasing the parasite burdens of native hosts) or sinks (with the 'dilution' of infection decreasing the parasite burdens of native hosts) of infection.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>In New Zealand, negative correlations between the presence of introduced brown trout (Salmo trutta) and native parasite burdens of the native roundhead galaxias (Galaxias anomalus) have been observed, suggesting that parasite dilution is occurring.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We used a multiple-scale approach combining field observations, experimental infections and dynamic population modelling to investigate whether native Acanthocephalus galaxii acquisition by brown trout alters host-parasite dynamics in native roundhead galaxias.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>4. Field observations demonstrated higher infection intensity in introduced trout than in native galaxias, but only small, immature A. galaxii were present in trout.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Experimental infections also demonstrated that A. galaxii does not mature in trout, although parasite establishment and initial growth were similar in the two hosts.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Taken together, these results support the hypothesis that trout may serve as an infection sink for the native parasite.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>
<Species>However, dynamic population modelling predicts that A. galaxii infections in native galaxias should at most only be slightly reduced by dilution in the presence of trout.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Rather, model exploration indicates parasite densities in galaxias are highly sensitive to galaxias predation on infected amphipods, and to relative abundances of galaxias and trout.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Genetics of lung-cancer susceptibility.</Species>
<Species>Lung cancer is the most common form of cancer death worldwide.</Species>

<Species>Although reduction of tobacco consumption remains the most appropriate strategy to reduce lung-cancer burden, identification of genes involved in the cause of disease could contribute to further understanding of the underlying mechanisms, and eventually lead to additional prevention strategies and targeted treatments.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Common gene variants involved in lung cancer have been recently identified through large, collaborative, genome-wide association studies.</Species>

<Species>These studies identified three separate loci that are associated with lung cancer (5p15, 6p21, and 15q25) and include genes that regulate acetylcholine nicotinic receptors and telomerase production.</Species>
<Species>However, much about genetic risk remains to be discovered, and rarer gene variants, such as those of the CHEK2 gene, likely account for most of the remaining risk.</Species>
<Species>There is also a need for studies that investigate how genetic susceptibility is associated with clinical outcome measures, including treatment response and tumour relapse.</Species>

text: <Species>Although B cells may be effective in stimulating cytotoxic T lymphocyte responses, studies involving their role in FV infection have mainly focused on neutralizing antibody production.</Species>

<Species>Rate of egg maturation in marine turtles exhibits 'universal temperature dependence'.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>The metabolic theory of ecology (MTE) predicts that, after correcting for body mass variation among organisms, the rates of most biological processes will vary as a universal function of temperature.</Species>
<Species>However, empirical support for 'universal temperature dependence' (UTD) is currently equivocal and based on studies of a limited number of traits.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>In many ectothermic animals, the rate at which females produce mature eggs is temperature dependent and may be an important factor in determining the costs of reproduction.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We tested whether the rate of egg maturation in marine turtles varies with environmental temperature as predicted by MTE, using the time separating successive clutches of individual females to estimate the rate at which eggs are formed.</Species>

<Species>We also assessed the phenotypic contribution to this rate, by using radio telemetry to make repeated measurements of interclutch intervals for individual green turtles (Chelonia mydas).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Rates of egg maturation increased with seasonally increasing water temperatures in radio-tracked green turtles, but were not repeatable for individual females, and did not vary according to maternal body size or reproductive investment (number and size of eggs produced).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Using a collated data set from several different populations and species of marine turtles, we then show that a single relationship with water temperature explains most of the variation in egg maturation rates, with a slope that is statistically indistinguishable from the UTD predicted by MTE.</Species>
<Species>However, several alternative statistical models also described the relationship between temperature and egg maturation rates equally parsimoniously.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>Our results offer novel support for the MTE's predicted UTD of biological rates, although the underlying mechanisms require further study.</Species>

<Species>The strong temperature dependence of egg maturation combined with the apparently weak phenotypic contribution to this rate has interesting behavioural implications in ectothermic animals.</Species>

<Species>We suggest that maternal thermoregulatory behaviour in marine turtles, and many other reptiles, is consistent with a strategy of adaptively increasing body temperatures to accelerate egg maturation.</Species>

<Species>Seasonal dynamics in the stable carbon isotope composition delta^1^3C from non-leafy branch, trunk and coarse root CO2 efflux of adult deciduous (Fagus sylvatica) and evergreen (Picea abies) trees.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Respiration is a substantial driver of carbon (C) flux in forest ecosystems and stable C isotopes provide an excellent tool for its investigation.</Species>

<Species>We studied seasonal dynamics in delta^1^3C of CO2 efflux (delta^1^3C(E)) from non-leafy branches, upper and lower trunks and coarse roots of adult trees, comparing deciduous Fagus sylvatica (European beech) with evergreen Picea abies (Norway spruce).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In both species, we observed strong and similar seasonal dynamics in the delta^1^3C(E) of above-ground plant components, whereas delta^1^3C(E) of coarse roots was rather stable.</Species>
<Species>During summer, delta^1^3C(E) of trunks was about -28.2% (Beech) and -26.8% (Spruce).</Species>
<Species>During winter dormancy, delta^1^3C(E) increased by 5.6-9.1%.</Species>

<Species>The observed dynamics are likely related to a switch from growth to starch accumulation during fall and remobilization of starch, low TCA cycle activity and accumulation of malate by PEPc during winter.</Species>

<Species>The seasonal delta^1^3C(E) pattern of branches of Beech and upper trunks of Spruce was less variable, probably because these organs were additionally supplied by winter photosynthesis.</Species>

<Species>In view of our results and pervious studies, we conclude that the pronounced increases in delta^1^3C(E) of trunks during the winter results from interrupted access to recent photosynthates.</Species>

<Species>Parasitoid developmental mortality in the field: patterns, causes and consequences for sex ratio and virginity.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Sex ratio theory predicts that developmental mortality can affect sex ratio optima under Local Mate Competition and also lead to 'virgin' broods containing only females with no sibling-mating opportunities on maturity.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Estimates of developmental mortality and its sex ratio effects have been laboratory based, and both models and laboratory studies have treated mortality as a phenomenon without identifying its biological causes.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We contribute a large set of field data on Metaphycus luteolus Timberlake (Hymenoptera: Encyrtidae), an endoparasitoid of soft scale insects (Hemiptera: Coccidae), which has sex allocation conditional on host quality and female-biased brood sex ratios.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Developmental mortality within broods can be both assessed and attributed to distinct causes, including encapsulation by the host and larval-larval competition.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>Thirty per cent of M. luteolus offspring die during development with 65% of this mortality because of encapsulation and 28% because of larval competition.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The distributions of mortality overall and for each cause of mortality separately were overdispersed.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>The probability of an individual being encapsulated increased with clutch size, while the probability of being killed by a brood mate declined with increasing clutch size and with increasing per capita availability of resources.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>The sexual compositions of broods at emergence were influenced by both the degree and the type of mortality operating.</Species>
<Species>At higher levels of mortality, single sex broods were more common and sex ratios were less precise.</Species>

<Species>Overall, virginity was more prevalent than predicted and was more greatly affected by the occurrence of competition than by other sources of mortality, almost certainly because competition tended to eliminate males.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>

<Species>The reproductive and developmental biology of M. luteolus appears to be influenced by a complex interplay of maternal clutch size and sex allocation strategies, offspring-offspring developmental interactions, host defence mechanisms and postemergence mating behaviour.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Despite the great sophistication of sex ratio theory, it has not yet evolved to the point where it is capable of considering all of these influences simultaneously.</Species>

text: <Species>Gram-positive pili are composed of covalently bound pilin subunits whose assembly is mediated via a pilus-specific sortase(s).</Species>
<Species>Major subunits constitute the pilus backbone and are therefore essential for pilus formation.</Species>
<Species>Minor subunits are also incorporated into the pilus, but they are considered to be dispensable for backbone formation.</Species>
<Species>The srtG cluster is one of the putative pilus gene clusters identified in the major swine pathogen Streptococcus suis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>It consists of one sortase gene (srtG) and two putative pilin subunit genes (sgp1 and sgp2).</Species>

<Species>In this study, by constructing mutants for each of the genes in the cluster and by both immunoblotting and immunogold electron microscopic analysis with antibodies against Sgp1 and Sgp2, we found that the srtG cluster mediates the expression of pilus-like structures in S. suis strain 89/1591.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this pilus, Sgp1 forms the backbone, whereas Sgp2 is incorporated as the minor subunit.</Species>
<Species>In accordance with the current model of pilus assembly by Gram-positive organisms, the major subunit Sgp1 was indispensable for backbone formation and the cognate sortase</Species>
<Species>SrtG mediated the polymerization of both subunits.</Species>
<Species>However, unlike other well-characterized Gram-positive bacterial pili, the minor subunit Sgp2 was required for polymerization of the major subunit Sgp1.</Species>

<Species>Because Sgp2 homologues are encoded in several other Gram-positive bacterial pilus gene clusters, in some types of pili, minor pilin subunits may contribute to backbone formation by a novel mechanism.</Species>

<Species>Relating the physical properties of Pseudomonas aeruginosa lipopolysaccharides to virulence by atomic force microscopy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Lipopolysaccharides (LPS) are an important class of macromolecules that are components of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>P. aeruginosa contains two different sugar chains, the homopolymer common antigen (A band) and the heteropolymer O antigen (B band), which impart serospecificity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The characteristics of LPS are generally assessed after isolation rather than in the context of whole bacteria.</Species>
<Species>Here we used atomic force microscopy (AFM) to probe the physical properties of the LPS of P. aeruginosa strain PA103 (serogroup O11) in situ.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This strain contains a mixture of long and very long polymers of O antigen, regulated by two different genes.</Species>

<Species>For this analysis, we studied the wild-type strain and four mutants, DeltaWzz1 (producing only very long LPS), DeltaWzz2 (producing only long LPS), DDeltaM (with both the wzz1 and wzz2 genes deleted), and Wzy::GM (producing an LPS core oligosaccharide plus one unit of O antigen).</Species>

<Species>Forces of adhesion between the LPS on these strains and the silicon nitride AFM tip were measured, and the Alexander and de Gennes model of steric repulsion between a flat surface and a polymer brush was used to calculate the LPS layer thickness (which we refer to as length), compressibility, and spacing between the individual molecules.</Species>

<Species>LPS chains were longest for the wild-type strain and DeltaWzz1, at 170.6 and 212.4 nm, respectively, and these values were not statistically significantly different from one another.</Species>
<Species>Wzy::GM and DDeltaM have reduced LPS lengths, at 34.6 and 37.7 nm, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Adhesion forces were not correlated with LPS length, but a relationship between adhesion force and bacterial pathogenicity was found in a mouse acute pneumonia model of infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The adhesion forces with the AFM probe were lower for strains with LPS mutations, suggesting that the wild-type strain is optimized for maximal adhesion.</Species>
<Species>Our research contributes to further understanding of the role of LPS in the adhesion and virulence of P. aeruginosa.</Species>

<Species>Seasonal influenza epidemiology in sub-Saharan Africa: a systematic review.</Species>
<Species>Acute respiratory infection (ARI) is a leading cause of mortality worldwide, of which influenza is an important cause that can be prevented with vaccination.</Species>

<Species>We did a systematic review of research published from 1980 to 2009 on seasonal influenza epidemiology in sub-Saharan Africa to identify data strengths and weaknesses that might affect policy decisions, to assess the state of knowledge on influenza disease burden, and to ascertain unique features of influenza epidemiology in the region.</Species>
<Species>We assessed 1203 papers, reviewed 104, and included 49 articles.</Species>

<Species>1-25% of outpatient ARI visits were caused by influenza (11 studies; mean 9*5%; median 10%), whereas 0*6-15*6% of children admitted to hospital for ARI had influenza identified (15 studies; mean 6*6%; median 6*3%).</Species>
<Species>Influenza was highly seasonal in southern Africa.</Species>

<Species>Other data were often absent, particularly direct measurement of influenza incidence rates for all ages, within different patient settings (outpatient, inpatient, community), and for all countries.</Species>
<Species>Data from sub-Saharan Africa are insufficient to allow most countries to prioritise strategies for influenza prevention and control.</Species>

<Species>Key data gaps include incidence and case-fatality ratios for all ages, the contribution of influenza towards admission of adults to hospital for ARI, representative seasonality data, economic burden, and the interaction of influenza with prevalent disorders in Africa, such as malaria, HIV, and malnutrition.</Species>

<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Recently, quantitative food webs have been used to infer that herbivorous insect species attacked by the same major parasitoid species will affect each other negatively through apparent competition.</Species>
<Species>Nonetheless, theoretical work predicts several alternative outcomes, including positive effects.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>In this paper, we use an experimental approach to link food web patterns to realized population dynamics.</Species>
<Species>First, we construct a quantitative food web for three dominant leaf miner species on the oak Quercus robur.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We then measure short- and long-term indirect effects by increasing leaf miner densities on individual trees.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we test whether experimental results are consistent with natural leaf miner dynamics on unmanipulated trees.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>The quantitative food web shows that all leaf miner species share a minimum of four parasitoid species.</Species>

<Species>While only a small fraction of the parasitoid pool is shared among Tischeria ekebladella and each of two Phyllonorycter species, the parasitoid communities of the congeneric Phyllonorycter species overlap substantially.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Based on the structure of the food web, we predict strong short- and long-term indirect interactions between the Phyllonorycter species, and limited interactions between them and T. ekebladella.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As T. ekebladella is the main source of its own parasitoids, we expect to find intraspecific density-dependent parasitism in this species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>
<Species>Consistent with these predictions, parasitism in T. ekebladella was high on trees with high densities of conspecifics in the previous generation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Among leaf miner species sharing more parasitoids, we found positive rather than negative interactions among years.</Species>
<Species>No short-term indirect interactions (i.e. indirect interactions within a single generation) were detected.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>

<Species>Overall, this study is the first to experimentally demonstrate that herbivores with overlapping parasitoid communities may exhibit independent population dynamics - or even apparent mutualism.</Species>

<Species>Hence, it proves the potential for versatile indirect interactions in nature, and suggests that the link between patterns in food web structure and realized population dynamics should be verified by rigorous experiments.</Species>

text: <Species>The Perigord black truffle responds to cold temperature with an extensive reprogramming of its transcriptional activity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Tuber melanosporum genome has been analysed with the aim of identifying and characterizing the genes involved in the environmental stress response.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A whole genome array (7496 genes/probe) was used to verify the fungal transcriptional profiling upon a cold temperature period (7 days at 4 ^0C).</Species>

<Species>A total of 423 genes resulted to be differentially expressed in a significant manner (>2.5-fold; p-value<0.05) in the mycelia exposed to cold, compared to the control ones: 187 of these genes were up-regulated, while 236 were down-regulated.</Species>

<Species>Sixty-six and fifty-one percent, respectively, of the up- or down-regulated transcripts had no KOG classification and were clustered as unclassified proteins, which was the most abundant category in the both up- and down-regulated genes.</Species>
<Species>A gene subset, containing a range of biological functions, was chosen to validate the microarray experiment through quantitative real time PCR (qRT-PCR).</Species>
<Species>The analysis confirmed the array data for 16 out of 22 of the considered genes, confirming that a cold temperature period influences the truffle global gene expression.</Species>

<Species>The expressed genes, which mostly resulted to be genes for heat shock proteins (HSPs) and genes involved in cell wall and lipid metabolism, could be involved in mechanisms, which are responsible for fungal adaptation.</Species>

<Species>Since truffle ascomata develop during the winter period, we hypothesize that these differentially expressed genes may help the truffle to adapt to low temperatures and/or perceive environmental signals that regulate the fructification.</Species>
<Species>One step construction of Agrobacterium-Recombination-ready-plasmids (OSCAR), an efficient and robust tool for ATMT based gene deletion construction in fungi.</Species>
<Species>Increasing availability of genomic data and sophistication of analytical methodology in fungi has elevated the need for functional genomics tools in these organisms.</Species>

<Species>Previously we reported a method called DelsGate for rapid preparation of deletion constructs for protoplast-mediated fungal transformation systems, which is based on Gateway(R) technology.</Species>

<Species>However, over the past several years Agrobacteriumtumefaciens-mediated transformation (ATMT) has become the preferred genetic transformation method for an increasing number of fungi.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Therefore, we developed a method for One Step Construction of Agrobacterium-Recombination-ready-plasmids (OSCAR), to rapidly create deletion constructs for ATMT systems.</Species>

<Species>The OSCAR methodology involves PCR amplification of the upstream and downstream flanks of the gene of interest, using gene specific primers each with a 5' extension containing one of four different attB recombination sites, modified from the Invitrogen MultiSite Gateway(R) system.</Species>
<Species>Amplified gene flanks are then mixed with specifically designed marker and binary vectors and treated with BP clonase, generating the deletion construct in a single cloning step.</Species>
<Species>The entire process of deletion construct preparation can be accomplished in just 2days.</Species>
<Species>Using OSCAR we generated eight targeted deletion constructs and used two of them to generate deletion mutants in Verticillium dahliae by ATMT.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In summary, OSCAR methodology combines PCR and Gateway(R) technology to rapidly and robustly generate precise deletion constructs for fungal ATMT and homologous gene replacement.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>Hyperaccumulators store accumulated metals in the vacuoles of large leaf epidermal cells (storage cells).</Species>
<Species>For investigating cadmium uptake, we incubated protoplasts obtained from leaves of Thlaspi caerulescens (Ganges ecotype) with a Cd-specific fluorescent dye.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A fluorescence kinetic microscope was used for selectively measuring Cd-uptake and photosynthesis in different cell types, so that physical separation of cell types was not necessary.</Species>
<Species>Few minutes after its addition, cadmium accumulated in the cytoplasm before its transport into the vacuole.</Species>
<Species>This demonstrated that vacuolar sequestration is the rate-limiting step in cadmium uptake into protoplasts of all leaf cell types.</Species>
<Species>During accumulation in the cytoplasm, Cd-rich vesicle-like structures were observed.</Species>
<Species>Cd uptake rates into epidermal storage cells were higher than into standard-sized epidermal cells and mesophyll cells.</Species>

<Species>This shows that the preferential heavy metal accumulation in epidermal storage cells, previously observed for several metals in intact leaves of various hyperaccumulator species, is due to differences in active metal transport and not differences in passive mechanisms like transpiration stream transport or cell wall adhesion.</Species>

<Species>Combining this with previous studies, it seems likely that the transport steps over the plasma and tonoplast membranes of leaf epidermal storage cells are driving forces behind the hyperaccumulation phenotype.</Species>

text: <Species>The tetrameric cytoplasmic chaperone SecB binds to precursors of exported proteins before they can become stably folded and delivers them to SecA. During this delivery step, SecB binds to SecA. The complex between SecA and SecB that is maximally active in translocation contains two protomers of SecA bound to a tetramer of SecB.</Species>

text: <Species>Family II chitin synthases (CS), including classes IV and V enzymes, share conserved catalytic domains flanked by transmembrane regions.</Species>
<Species>Here we addressed the characterization of Family II fungal CSs by heterologous expression in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Species>

text: <Species>Full-length CSs from classes V or IV were not functional when expressed in S. cerevisiae and accumulated in different intracellular compartments.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the exchange between different class IV, but not of class V, CHS domains resulted in functional proteins both in vivo and in vitro.</Species>

<Species>These results allow a role in chitin synthesis to be assigned to all class IV enzymes, but they also highlight the involvement of the intracellular globular domain of these CSs, not only in enzymatic activity but also in the regulation of their intracellular turnover.</Species>

<Species>Aerobic degradation of mercaptosuccinate by the gram-negative bacterium Variovorax paradoxus strain B4.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Gram-negative bacterium Variovorax paradoxus strain B4 was isolated from soil under mesophilic and aerobic conditions to elucidate the so far unknown catabolism of mercaptosuccinate (MS).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>During growth with MS this strain released significant amounts of sulfate into the medium. Tn5::mob-induced mutagenesis was successfully employed and yielded nine independent mutants incapable of using MS as a carbon source.</Species>
<Species>In six of these mutants, Tn5::mob insertions were mapped in a putative gene encoding a molybdenum (Mo) cofactor biosynthesis protein (moeA).</Species>
<Species>In two further mutants the Tn5::mob insertion was mapped in the gene coding for a putative molybdopterin (MPT) oxidoreductase.</Species>
<Species>In contrast to the wild type, these eight mutants also showed no growth on taurine.</Species>
<Species>In another mutant a gene putatively encoding a 3-hydroxyacyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (paaH2) was disrupted by transposon insertion.</Species>
<Species>Upon subcellular fractionation of wild-type cells cultivated with MS as sole carbon and sulfur source, MPT oxidoreductase activity was detected in only the cytoplasmic fraction.</Species>
<Species>Cells grown with succinate, taurine, or gluconate as a sole carbon source exhibited no activity or much lower activity.</Species>
<Species>MPT oxidoreductase activity in the cytoplasmic fraction of the Tn5::mob-induced mutant Icr6 was 3-fold lower in comparison to the wild type.</Species>

<Species>Therefore, a new pathway for MS catabolism in V. paradoxus strain B4 is proposed: (i) MPT oxidoreductase catalyzes the conversion of MS first into sulfinosuccinate (a putative organo-sulfur compound composed of succinate and a sulfino group) and then into sulfosuccinate by successive transfer of oxygen atoms, (ii) sulfosuccinate is cleaved into oxaloacetate and sulfite, and (iii) sulfite is oxidized to sulfate.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Ecosystem engineering and predation: the multi-trophic impact of two ant species.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Ants are ubiquitous ecosystem engineers and generalist predators and are able to affect ecological communities via both pathways.</Species>
<Species>They are likely to influence any other terrestrial arthropod group either directly or indirectly caused by their high abundance and territoriality.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>We studied the impact of two ant species common in Central Europe, Myrmica rubra and Lasius niger, on an arthropod community.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Colony presence and density of these two ant species were manipulated in a field experiment from the start of ant activity in spring to late summer.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>The experiment revealed a positive influence of the presence of one ant colony on densities of decomposers, herbivores and parasitoids.</Species>
<Species>However, in the case of herbivores and parasitoids, this effect was reversed in the presence of two colonies.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Generally, effects of the two ant species were similar with the exception of their effect on Braconidae parasitoid densities that responded positively to one colony of M. rubra but not of L. niger. 5.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Spider density was not affected by ant colony manipulation, but species richness of spiders responded positively to ant presence.</Species>

<Species>This effect was independent of ant colony density, but where two colonies were present, spider richness was significantly greater in plots with two M. rubra colonies than in plots with one colony of each ant species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>6. To test whether the positive ecosystem engineering effects were purely caused by modified properties of the soil, we added in an additional experiment (i) the soil from ant nests (without ants) or (ii) unmodified soil or (iii) ant nests (including ants) to experimental plots.</Species>

<Species>Ant nest soil on its own did not have a significant impact on densities of decomposers, herbivores or predators, which were significantly, and positively, affected by the addition of an intact nest.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>
<Species>The results suggest an important role of both ant species in the grassland food web, strongly affecting the densities of decomposers, herbivores and higher trophic levels.</Species>
<Species>We discuss how the relative impact via bottom-up and top-down effects of ants depends on nest density, with a relatively greater top-down predatory impact at higher densities.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of genetic variation and phylogeny of the predatory bug, Pilophorus typicus, in Japan using mitochondrial gene sequences.</Species>

text: <Species>Pilophorus typicus (Distant) (Heteroptera: Miridae) is a predatory bug occurring in East, Southeast, and South Asia.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Because the active stages of P. typicus prey on various agricultural pest insects and mites, this species is a candidate insect as an indigenous natural enemy for use in biological control programs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the mass releasing of introduced natural enemies into agricultural fields may incur the risk of affecting the genetic integrity of species through hybridization with a local population.</Species>

<Species>To clarify the genetic characteristics of the Japanese populations of P. typicus two portions of the mitochondrial DNA, the cytochrome oxidase subunit I (COI) (534 bp) and the cytochrome B (cytB) (217 bp) genes, were sequenced for 64 individuals collected from 55 localities in a wide range of Japan.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Totals of 18 and 10 haplotypes were identified for the COI and cytB sequences, respectively (25 haplotypes over regions).</Species>
<Species>Phylogenetic analysis using the maximum likelihood method revealed the existence of two genetically distinct groups in P. typicus in Japan.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These groups were distributed in different geographic ranges: one occurred mainly from the Pacific coastal areas of the Kii Peninsula, the Shikoku Island, and the Ryukyu Islands; whereas the other occurred from the northern Kyushu district to the Kanto and Hokuriku districts of mainland Japan.</Species>
<Species>However, both haplotypes were found in a single locality of the southern coast of the Shikoku Island.</Species>
<Species>COI phylogeny incorporating other Pilophorus species revealed that these groups were only recently differentiated.</Species>

text: <Species>The importance of marine vs. human-induced subsidies in the maintenance of an expanding mesocarnivore in the arctic tundra.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Most studies addressing the causes of the recent increases and expansions of mesopredators in many ecosystems have focused on the top-down, releasing effect of extinctions of large apex predators.</Species>

<Species>However, in the case of the northward expansion of the red fox into the arctic tundra, a bottom-up effect of increased resource availability has been proposed, an effect that can counteract prey shortage in the low phase of the multi-annual rodent cycle.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Resource subsidies both with marine and with terrestrial origins could potentially be involved.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>During different phases of a multi-annual rodent cycle, we investigated the seasonal dynamics and spatial pattern of resource use by red foxes across a coast to inland low arctic tundra gradient, Varanger Peninsula, Norway.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We employed two complementary methods of diet analyses: stomach contents and stable isotope analysis.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>We found that inland red foxes primarily subsisted on reindeer carrions during the low phase of a small rodent population cycle.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Lemmings became the most important food item towards the peak phase of the rodent cycle, despite being less abundant than sympatric voles.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Isotopic signatures of tissue from both predator and prey also revealed that red foxes near the coast used marine-derived subsidies in the winter, but these allochthonous resources did not spillover to adult foxes living beyond 20-25 km from the coast.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Although more needs to be learned about the link between increasing primary productivity due to climatic warming and trophic dynamics in tundra ecosystems, we suggest that changes in reindeer management through a bottom-up effect, at least regionally, may have paved the way towards the establishment of a new mesopredator in the tundra biome.</Species>

text: <Species>Alcohol dehydrogenase and hydrogenase transcript fluctuations during a day-night cycle in Chlamydomonas reinhardtii: the role of anoxia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>* The unicellular green alga Chlamydomonas reinhardtii contains two iron (Fe)-hydrogenases which are responsible for hydrogen production under anoxia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the present work the patterns of expression of alcohol dehydrogenase, a typical anaerobic gene in plants, of the hydrogenases genes (HYD1, HYD2) and of the genes responsible for their maturation (HYDEF, HYDG), were analysed.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>

<Species>The expression patterns were analysed by real-time reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction in Chlamydomonas cultures during the day-night cycle, as well as in response to oxygen availability.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>The results indicated that ADH1, HYD1, HYD2, HYDEF and HYDG were expressed following precise day-night fluctuations.</Species>
<Species>ADH1 and HYD2 were modulated by the day-night cycle.</Species>
<Species>Low oxygen plays an important role for the induction of HYD1, HYDEF and HYDG, while ADH1 and HYD2 expression was relatively insensitive to oxygen availability.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>The regulation of the anaerobic gene expression in Chlamydomonas is only partly explained by responses to anoxia.</Species>
<Species>The cell cycle and light-dark cycles are equally important elements in the regulatory network modulating the anaerobic response in Chlamydomonas.</Species>
<Species>OsRAN2, essential for mitosis, enhances cold tolerance in rice by promoting export of intranuclear tubulin and maintaining cell division under cold stress.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>With global climate change, abnormally low temperatures have affected the world's rice production.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Many genes have been shown to be essential for molecular improvement of rice cold-tolerance traits.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, less is known about the molecular cellular mechanism of their response to cold stress.</Species>
<Species>Here, we investigated OsRAN2 involved in regulation of cell division during cold stress in rice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Expression of OsRAN2 was increased under cold treatment, but not during salt and drought stress.</Species>
<Species>The mean root mitotic index was closely related to the expression level of OsRAN2.</Species>
<Species>Knockdown transgenic rice lines showed an aberrant organization of spindles during mitosis and stunted growth during development.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Overexpression of OsRAN2 enhanced cold tolerance in rice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The transgenic rice overexpressing OsRAN2 showed maintained cell division, decreased proportion of cells with intranuclear tubulin and formation of a normal nuclear envelope under the cold condition.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our study suggests a mechanism for OsRAN2 in regulating cold resistance in rice by maintaining cell division through promoting the normal export of intranuclear tubulin at the end of mitosis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This insight could help improve the cold-tolerance trait in rice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Health-financing reforms in southeast Asia: challenges in achieving universal coverage.</Species>

<Species>In this sixth paper of the Series, we review health-financing reforms in seven countries in southeast Asia that have sought to reduce dependence on out-of-pocket payments, increase pooled health finance, and expand service use as steps towards universal coverage.</Species>

<Species>Laos and Cambodia, both resource-poor countries, have mostly relied on donor-supported health equity funds to reach the poor, and reliable funding and appropriate identification of the eligible poor are two major challenges for nationwide expansion.</Species>

<Species>For Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia, and Vietnam, social health insurance financed by payroll tax is commonly used for formal sector employees (excluding Malaysia), with varying outcomes in terms of financial protection.</Species>
<Species>Alternative payment methods have different implications for provider behaviour and financial protection.</Species>

<Species>Two alternative approaches for financial protection of the non-poor outside the formal sector have emerged-contributory arrangements and tax-financed schemes-with different abilities to achieve high population coverage rapidly.</Species>
<Species>Fiscal space and mobilisation of payroll contributions are both important in accelerating financial protection.</Species>
<Species>Expanding coverage of good-quality services and ensuring adequate human resources are also important to achieve universal coverage.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As health-financing reform is complex, institutional capacity to generate evidence and inform policy is essential and should be strengthened.</Species>
<Species>Characterization of the Bacteroides CTnDOT regulatory protein RteC.</Species>
<Species>Excision of the Bacteroides conjugative transposon CTnDOT is stimulated by tetracycline.</Species>
<Species>It was shown previously that a gene, rteC, is necessary for tetracycline-stimulated transcriptional regulation of the orf2c operon, which contains the excision genes.</Species>
<Species>The protein encoded by this gene, RteC, did not have primary amino acid sequence homology to any known proteins in the databases.</Species>
<Species>Accordingly, we sought structural homologs of RteC.</Species>
<Species>A three-dimensional structure prediction by Robetta suggested that RteC might have two domains and that the C-terminal domain might have a winged helix motif.</Species>
<Species>Based on the Robetta prediction, the human transcriptional factors E2F-4 and DP2 were identified as the most likely structural homologs of RteC.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We made alanine substitutions within the putative DNA binding helix 3 region of RteC. Assays of orf2c::uidA activation by alanine mutants indicated that residues 174, 175, 178, 180, and 184 in helix 3 might contact the upstream region of P(E).</Species>
<Species>The upstream region of orf2c contained two inverted-repeat half sites.</Species>
<Species>Mutational analysis of these half sites showed that both half sites are important for activity.</Species>
<Species>Thus, we have identified the DNA binding portion of RteC and the DNA site to which it binds.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>*</Species>
<Species>Aerenchyma formation was studied in rice stems by light microscopy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It was analyzed in response to submergence, ethylene and hydrogen peroxide (H(2)O(2)) treatment, and in the MT2b::Tos17 mutant.</Species>
<Species>O(2)*(-) was detected with nitroblue tetrazolium and an epinephrine assay.</Species>
<Species>H(2)O(2) was detected with 3,3'-diaminobenzidine.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Aerenchyma develop constitutively in all internodes of the deep-water rice variety Pin Gaew 56, but are absent from the nodes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Constitutive aerenchyma formation was also observed in two lowland rice varieties, albeit to a lesser degree.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A larger number of aerenchyma are present in older internodes, and at the top of each internode, revealing developmental gradients.</Species>
<Species>Submergence or treatment with the ethylene-releasing compound ethephon promoted aerenchyma formation in all genotypes analyzed.</Species>
<Species>Pre-aerenchymal cells contain less starch, no chloroplasts, thinner cell walls and produce elevated levels of O(2)*(-) and H(2)O(2) compared with other parenchymal cells.</Species>
<Species>Ethephon promotes O(2)*(-) formation and H(2)O(2) promotes aerenchyma formation in a dose-dependent manner.</Species>
<Species>Further-more, genetic downregulation of the H(2)O(2) scavenger MT2b enhances aerenchyma formation.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Aerenchyma formation is mediated by reactive oxygen species.</Species>
<Species>Candidate chemosensory ionotropic receptors in a Lepidoptera.</Species>
<Species>A new family of candidate chemosensory ionotropic receptors (IRs) related to ionotropic glutamate receptors (iGluRs) was recently discovered in Drosophila melanogaster.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Through Blast analyses of an expressed sequenced tag library prepared from male antennae of the noctuid moth Spodoptera littoralis, we identified 12 unigenes encoding proteins related to D. melanogaster and Bombyx mori IRs.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Their full length sequences were obtained and the analyses of their expression patterns suggest that they were exclusively expressed or clearly enriched in chemosensory organs.</Species>

<Species>The deduced protein sequences were more similar to B. mori and D. melanogaster IRs than to iGluRs and showed considerable variations in the predicted ligand-binding domains; none have the three glutamate-interacting residues found in iGluRs, suggesting different binding specificities.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Our data suggest that we identified members of the insect IR chemosensory receptor family in S. littoralis and we report here the first demonstration of IR expression in Lepidoptera.</Species>

text: <Species>Persistent Friend virus replication and disease in Apobec3-deficient mice expressing functional B-cell-activating factor receptor.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Rfv3 is an autosomal dominant gene that influences the recovery of resistant mice from Friend retrovirus (FV) infection by limiting viremia and promoting a more potent neutralizing antibody response.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We previously reported that Rfv3 is encoded by Apobec3, an innate retrovirus restriction factor.</Species>

<Species>However, it was recently suggested that the Rfv3 susceptible phenotype of high viremia at 28 days postinfection (dpi) was more dominantly controlled by the B-cell-activating factor receptor (BAFF-R), a gene that is linked to but located outside the genetically mapped region containing Rfv3.</Species>

<Species>Although one prototypical Rfv3 susceptible mouse strain, A/WySn, indeed contains a dysfunctional BAFF-R, two other Rfv3 susceptible strains, BALB/c and A.BY, express functional BAFF-R genes, determined on the basis of genotyping and B-cell immunophenotyping.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, transcomplementation studies in (C57BL/6 [B6] x BALB/c)F(1) and (B6 x A.BY)F(1) mice revealed that the B6 Apobec3 gene significantly influences recovery from FV viremia, cellular infection, and disease at 28 dpi.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Finally, the Rfv3 phenotypes of prototypic B6, A.BY, A/WySn, and BALB/c mouse strains correlate with reported Apobec3 mRNA expression levels.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Overall, these findings argue against the generality of BAFF-R polymorphisms as a dominant mechanism to explain the Rfv3 recovery phenotype and further strengthen the evidence that Apobec3 encodes Rfv3.</Species>

<Species>Fire ant decapitating fly cooperative release programs (1994-2008): two Pseudacteon species, P. tricuspis and P. curvatus, rapidly expand across imported fire ant populations in the southeastern United States.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Natural enemies of the imported fire ants, Solenopsis invicta Buren S. richteri Forel (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), and their hybrid, include a suite of more than 20 fire ant decapitating phorid flies from South America in the genus Pseudacteon.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Over the past 12 years, many researchers and associates have cooperated in introducing several species as classical or self-sustaining biological control agents in the United States.</Species>

<Species>As a result, two species of flies, Pseudacteon tricuspis Borgmeier and P. curvatus Borgmeier (Diptera: Phoridae), are well established across large areas of the southeastern United States.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Whereas many researchers have published local and state information about the establishment and spread of these flies, here distribution data from both published and unpublished sources has been compiled for the entire United States with the goal of presenting confirmed and probable distributions as of the fall of 2008.</Species>
<Species>Documented rates of expansion were also used to predict the distribution of these flies three years later in the fall of 2011.</Species>

<Species>In the fall of 2008, eleven years after the first successful release, we estimate that P. tricuspis covered about 50% of the fire ant quarantined area and that it will occur in almost 65% of the quarantine area by 2011.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Complete coverage of the fire ant quarantined area will be delayed or limited by this species' slow rate of spread and frequent failure to establish in more northerly portions of the fire ant range and also, perhaps, by its preference for red imported fire ants (S. invicta).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Eight years after the first successful release of P. curvatus, two biotypes of this species (one biotype occurring predominantly in the black and hybrid imported fire ants and the other occurring in red imported fire ants) covered almost 60% of the fire ant quarantined area.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We estimate these two biotypes will cover almost 90% of the quarantine area by 2011 and 100% by 2012 or 2013.</Species>
<Species>Strategic selection of several distributional gaps for future releases will accelerate complete coverage of quarantine areas.</Species>
<Species>However, some gaps may be best used for the release of additional species of decapitating flies because establishment rates may be higher in areas without competing species.</Species>
<Species>Sequenced dermatophyte strains: growth rate, conidiation, drug susceptibilities, and virulence in an invertebrate model.</Species>
<Species>Although dermatophytes are the most common cause of fungal infections in the world, their basic biology is not well understood.</Species>

<Species>The recent sequencing and annotation of the genomes of five representative dermatophyte species allows for the creation of hypotheses as to how they cause disease and have adapted to their distinct environments.</Species>
<Species>An understanding of the microbiology of these strains will be essential for testing these hypotheses.</Species>
<Species>This study is the first to generally characterize these five sequenced strains of dermatophytes for their microbiological aspects.</Species>

<Species>We measured the growth rate on solid medium and found differences between species, with Microsporum gypseum CBS118893 having the fastest growth and Trichophyton rubrum CBS118892 the slowest.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We also compared different media for conidia production and found that the highest numbers of conidia were produced when dermatophytes were grown on MAT agar.</Species>
<Species>We determined the Minimum Inhibitory Concentration (MIC) of nine antifungal agents and confirmed susceptibility to antifungals commonly used as selectable markers.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we tested virulence in the Galleria mellonella (wax moth) larvae model but found the results variable.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These results increase our understanding of the microbiology and molecular biology of these dermatophyte strains and will be of use in advancing hypothesis-driven research about dermatophytes.</Species>
<Species>Accumulation of P-bodies in Candida albicans under different stress and filamentous growth conditions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Candida albicans is an opportunistic fungal pathogen that grows as budding yeast, pseudohyphal, and hyphal forms.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In response to external signals, C. albicans switches rapidly among these forms.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>mRNA-containing cytoplasmic granules, termed processing bodies (P-bodies), have been reported to accumulate under various environmental stress conditions in diverse species from yeast to mammals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, we provide the first microscopic and genetic characterization of P-bodies in C. albicans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The core components of P-bodies, including the decapping machinery (Dcp2 and Dhh1), 5'-3' exoribonuclease (Kem1/Xrn1), and the P-body scaffolding protein (Edc3), were identified and their localizations with respect to P-bodies were demonstrated.</Species>
<Species>Various growth conditions, including glucose deprivation, hyperosmotic stress, and heat stress, stimulated the accumulation of P-bodies.</Species>
<Species>In addition, we observed P-body aggregation during hyphal development.</Species>
<Species>The deletion mutant strain edc3/edc3 had a defect in filamentation and exhibited a dramatic reduction in the number of P-bodies.</Species>

<Species>These results suggest that Edc3 plays an essential role in the assembly and maintenance of P-bodies in C. albicans, and that the switch to filamentous growth appears to accompany P-body accumulation.</Species>

<Species>Resistance and recovery of soil microbial communities in the face of Alliaria petiolata invasions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Invaders can gain ecological advantages because of their evolutionary novelty, but little is known about how these novel advantages will change over time as the invader and invaded community evolve in response to each other.</Species>
<Species>Invasive plants often gain such an advantage through alteration of soil microbial communities.</Species>

<Species>In soil communities sampled from sites along a gradient of invasion history with Alliaria petiolata, microbial richness tended to decline, but the community's resistance to A. petiolata's effects generally increased with increasing history of invasion.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, sensitive microbial taxa appeared to recover in the two oldest sites, leading to an increase in richness, but consequent decrease in resistance.</Species>
<Species>This may be because of evolutionary changes in the A. petiolata populations, which tend to reduce their investment to allelopathic compounds over time.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results show that, over time, microbial communities can develop resistance to an invasive plant but at the cost of lower richness.</Species>
<Species>However, over longer time-scales evolution in the invasive species may allow for the recovery of soil microbial communities.</Species>

text: <Species>The HwSho1 protein isoforms are 93.8% identical in their amino-acid sequences, and have a conserved SH3 domain.</Species>

text: <Species>Through microscopic and biochemical validation, we demonstrate that in S. cerevisiae, both of the HwSho1 proteins have characteristic subcellular localizations similar to the S. cerevisiae Sho1 protein, and they can both activate the HOG pathway under conditions of osmotic stress.</Species>

<Species>The genetic basis for 3-ADON and 15-ADON trichothecene chemotypes in Fusarium.</Species>
<Species>Certain Fusarium species cause head blight of wheat and other small grains worldwide and produce trichothecene mycotoxins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These mycotoxins can induce toxicoses in animals and humans and can contribute to the ability of some fusaria to cause plant disease.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Production of the trichothecene 3-acetyldeoxynivalenol (3-ADON) versus 15-acetyldeoxynivalenol (15-ADON) is an important phenotypic difference within and among some Fusarium species.</Species>
<Species>However, until now, the genetic basis for this difference in chemotype has not been identified.</Species>
<Species>Here, we identified consistent DNA sequence differences in the coding region of the trichothecene biosynthetic gene TRI8 in 3-ADON and 15-ADON strains.</Species>

<Species>Functional analyses of the TRI8 enzyme (Tri8) in F. graminearum, the predominant cause of wheat head blight in North America and Europe, revealed that Tri8 from 3-ADON strains catalyzes deacetylation of the trichothecene biosynthetic intermediate 3,15-diacetyldeoxynivalenol at carbon 15 to yield 3-ADON, whereas Tri8 from 15-ADON strains catalyzes deacetylation of 3,15-diacetyldeoxynivalenol at carbon 3 to yield 15-ADON.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Fusarium strains that produce the trichothecene nivalenol have a Tri8 that functions like that in 15-ADON strains.</Species>
<Species>TRI3, which encodes a trichothecene carbon 15 acetyltransferase, was found to be functional in all three chemotypes.</Species>
<Species>Together, our data indicate that differential activity of Tri8 determines the 3-ADON and 15-ADON chemotypes in Fusarium.</Species>
<Species>Scale and state dependence of the relationship between personality and dispersal in a great tit population.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Dispersal is a key process in population biology and ecology.</Species>
<Species>Although the general ecological conditions that lead to dispersal have been well studied, the causes of individual variation in dispersal are less well understood.</Species>

<Species>A number of recent studies suggest that heritable temperament - or personality - traits are correlated with dispersal in the wild but the extent to which these 'personality-dispersal syndromes' are general, how they depend on an individual's state and on spatial scale and whether they are temporally stable, both within and across individuals, remains unclear.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Here, we examine the relationship between exploration behaviour - an axis of personality that appears to be important in animals generally - and a variety of dispersal processes over 6 years in a population of the great tit Parus major.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Exploration behaviour was higher in immigrant than in locally born juveniles, but the difference was much larger for individuals with a small body mass, though independent of sex, representing one of the first examples of a state-dependent effect in a personality-dispersal syndrome.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Despite a temporal trend in exploration behaviour at the population level, the difference between immigrants and locally born birds remained stable over time, both across and within individuals.</Species>

<Species>This suggests that the personality difference between immigrants and locally born birds is established early in development, but that the process of immigration interacts with both personality and state.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>We found that the number of immigrant parents a locally born bird had did not influence exploration behaviour, suggesting either the difference between immigrants and residents was environmental or that the effect is overridden by local environmental sources of variation.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>

<Species>In contrast to previous work, we found no evidence for links between personality and natal dispersal distance within the population, either in terms of an individual's own exploration behaviour or that of its parents.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>

<Species>Our results suggest that there are links between individual differences in personality and dispersal, but that these can be dependent on differences in state among individuals and on the scale over which dispersal is measured.</Species>

<Species>Future work should aim to understand the differences between dispersal within and between populations and the ways in which personality and state interact to determine the outcome of these processes.</Species>
<Species>Genome-wide identification of Mycobacterium tuberculosis exported proteins with roles in intracellular growth.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The exported proteins of Mycobacterium tuberculosis that are localized at the bacterial cell surface or secreted into the environment are ideally situated to interact with host factors and to function in virulence.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this study, we constructed a novel Beta-lactamase reporter transposon and used it directly in M. tuberculosis for genome-wide identification of exported proteins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>From 177 Beta-lactam-resistant transposon mutants, we identified 111 different exported proteins.</Species>

<Species>The majority of these proteins have no known function, and for nearly half of the proteins, our demonstration that they are exported when fused to a Beta-lactamase reporter is the first experimental proof of their extracytoplasmic localization.</Species>
<Species>The transposon mutants in our banked library were of further value as a collection of mutants lacking individual exported proteins.</Species>
<Species>By individually testing each of 111 mutants for growth in macrophages, six attenuated mutants with insertions in mce1A, mce1B, mce2F, rv0199, ctaC, and lppX were identified.</Species>

<Species>Given that much of the M. tuberculosis genome encodes proteins of unknown function, our library of mapped transposon mutants is a valuable resource for efforts in functional genomics.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This work also demonstrates the power of a Beta-lactamase reporter transposon that could be applied similarly to other bacterial pathogens.</Species>

<Species>Intraspecific trait variation and covariation in a widespread tree species (Nothofagus pumilio) in southern Chile.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>*</Species>
<Species>The focus of the trait-based approach to study community ecology has mostly been on trait comparisons at the interspecific level.</Species>

<Species>Here we quantified intraspecific variation and covariation of leaf mass per area (LMA) and wood density (WD) in monospecific forests of the widespread tree species Nothofagus pumilio to determine its magnitude and whether it is related to environmental conditions and ontogeny.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also discuss probable mechanisms controlling the trait variation found.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>

<Species>We collected leaf and stem woody tissues from 30-50 trees of different ages (ontogeny) from each of four populations at differing elevations (i.e. temperatures) and placed at each of three locations differing in soil moisture.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>The total variation in LMA (coefficient of variation (CV) = 21.14%) was twice that of WD (CV = 10.52%).</Species>
<Species>The total variation in traits was never less than 23% when compared with interspecific studies.</Species>
<Species>Differences in elevation (temperature) for the most part explained variation in LMA, while differences in soil moisture and ontogeny explained the variation in WD.</Species>
<Species>Traits covaried similarly in the altitudinal gradient only.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Functional traits of N. pumilio exhibited nonnegligible variation; LMA varied for the most part with temperature, while WD mostly varied with moisture and ontogeny.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We demonstrate that environmental variation can cause important trait variation without species turnover.</Species>
<Species>The first vitellogenin receptor from a Lepidopteran insect: molecular characterization, expression patterns and RNA interference analysis.</Species>

<Species>The vitellogenin receptor (VgR) belongs to the low-density lipoprotein receptor (LDLR) superfamily, and is an important carrier for the uptake of vitellogenin (Vg) into developing oocytes of all oviparous species.</Species>
<Species>The first full-length message for a VgR from a Lepidopteran insect was cloned and sequenced from the ovary of Spodoptera litura Fabricius (GenBank accession no. GU983858).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The coding region consisted of 5370 bp flanked by a 49 bp 5'-untranslated region (UTR) and a 177 bp 3'-UTR, which encoded a 1798-residue protein with a predicted molecular weight (MW) of 201.69 kDa.</Species>

<Species>S. litura VgR (SlVgR)comprised two ligand binding sites with four LDLR class A repeats in the first domain and seven in the second domain, an epidermal growth factor-like domain containing an LDLR class B repeat and a YWXD motif, a transmembrane domain and a cytoplasmic domain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A phylogenetic relationship placed SlVgR as a separate group from the other insects.</Species>
<Species>SlVgR messenger RNA (mRNA) was specifically expressed in the ovarian tissues.</Species>
<Species>The developmental expression patterns showed that VgR mRNA was first transcribed in 6(th) day female pupae and the maximum level of VgR mRNA appeared in 36-h-old adults.</Species>
<Species>Immunoblot analysis detected an ovary-specific VgR protein with a MW of -200 kDa, whose development profiles were consistent with VgR mRNA expression patterns.</Species>
<Species>RNA inteference (RNAi) specifically disrupted the VgR gene by injection of 3 or 5 mug VgR double-stranded RNA per insect in 4(th) or 6(th) day pupae.</Species>
<Species>RNAi of SlVgR led to a phenotype characterized by high Vg accumulation in the haemolymph, low Vg deposition in the ovary and the failure of insect spawning.</Species>
<Species>These results mean that VgR is critical for binding Vg and transporting it into the oocytes of the insect ovary, thus playing an important role in insect reproduction.</Species>
<Species>Perithecium morphogenesis in Sordaria macrospora.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The perithecium of the self-fertile ascomycete Sordaria macrospora provides an excellent model in which to analyse fungal multicellular development.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This study provides a detailed analysis of perithecium morphogenesis in the wild type and eight developmental mutants of S. macrospora, using a range of correlative microscopical techniques.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Fundamentally, perithecia and other complex multicellular structures produced by fungi arise by hyphal aggregation and adhesion, and these processes are followed by specialization and septation of hyphal compartments within the aggregates.</Species>
<Species>Perithecial morphogenesis can be divided into the ascogonial, protoperithecial, and perithecial stages of development.</Species>

<Species>At least 13 specialized, morphologically distinct cell-types are involved in perithecium morphogenesis, and these fall into three basic classes: hyphae, conglutinate cells and spores.</Species>
<Species>Conglutinate cells arise from hyphal adhesion and certain perithecial hyphae develop from conglutinate cells.</Species>
<Species>Various hypha-conglutinate cell transitions play important roles during the development of the perithecial wall and neck.</Species>

text: <Species>The nsp1 protein of transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV), an alphacoronavirus, efficiently suppressed protein synthesis in mammalian cells.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Unlike the nsp1 protein of severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus, a betacoronavirus, the TGEV nsp1 protein was unable to bind 40S ribosomal subunits or promote host mRNA degradation.</Species>

text: <Species>Developmental plasticity of immune defence in two life-history ecotypes of the garter snake, Thamnophis elegans - a common-environment experiment.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Ecoimmunological theory predicts a link between life-history and immune-defence strategies such that fast-living organisms should rely more on constitutive innate defences compared to slow-living organisms.</Species>
<Species>An untested assumption of this hypothesis is that the variation in immune defence associated with variation in life history has a genetic basis.</Species>
<Species>2. Replicate populations of two life-history ecotypes of the garter snake Thamnophis elegans provide an ideal system in which to test this assumption.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Free-ranging snakes of the fast-living ecotype, which reside in lakeshore habitats, show higher levels of three measures of constitutive innate immunity than those of the slow-living ecotype, which inhabit meadows around the lake.</Species>

<Species>Although this pattern is consistent with the ecoimmunological pace-of-life hypothesis, environmental differences between the lakeshore and meadow habitats could also explain the observed differences in immune defence.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>We performed a common-environment experiment to distinguish between these alternatives.</Species>

<Species>Snakes born and raised in common-environment conditions reflected the immune phenotype of their native habitats when sampled at 4 months of age (i.e. fast-living lakeshore snakes showed higher levels of natural antibodies, complement activity and bactericidal competence than slow-living meadow snakes), but no longer showed differences when 19 months old.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>This suggests that the differences in innate immunity observed between the two ecotypes have an important - and likely age-specific - environmental influence, with these immune components showing developmental plasticity.</Species>

<Species>A genetic effect in early life may also be present, but further research is needed to confirm this possibility and therefore provide a more definitive test of the ecoimmunological pace-of-life hypothesis in this system.</Species>
