text: <Species>Poliovirus RNA is released from the capsid near a twofold symmetry axis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After recognizing and binding to its host cell, poliovirus (like other nonenveloped viruses) faces the challenge of translocating its genome across a cellular membrane and into the cytoplasm.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To avoid entanglement with the capsid, the RNA must exit via a single site on the virion surface.</Species>
<Species>However, the mechanism by which a single site is selected (from among 60 equivalents) is unknown; and until now, even its location on the virion surface has been controversial.</Species>

<Species>To help to elucidate the mechanism of infection, we have used single-particle cryo-electron microscopy and tomography to reconstruct conformationally altered intermediates that are formed by the poliovirion at various stages of the poliovirus infection process.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Recently, we reported icosahedrally symmetric structures for two forms of the end-state 80S empty capsid particle.</Species>
<Species>Surprisingly, RNA was frequently visible near the capsid; and in a subset of the virions, RNA was seen on both the inside and outside of the capsid, caught in the act of exiting.</Species>

<Species>To visualize RNA exiting, we have now determined asymmetric reconstructions from that subset, using both single-particle cryo-electron microscopy and cryo-electron tomographic methods, producing independent reconstructions at -50-A resolution.</Species>

<Species>Contrary to predictions in the literature, the footprint of RNA on the capsid surface is located close to a viral 2-fold axis, covering a slot-shaped area of reduced density that is present in both of the symmetrized 80S reconstructions and which extends by about 20 A away from the 2-fold axis toward each neighboring 5-fold axis.</Species>

text: <Species>A monoclonal antibody (Mab)-based blocking ELISA was developed for the detection of serum neutralizing antibodies to porcine circovirus type 2 (PCV2).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Mab with neutralizing activity, which was produced by immunizing a recombinant capsid protein of PCV2 expressed in insect cells, was used as the detector antibody.</Species>
<Species>The assay was evaluated in comparison with a serum neutralization assay, and its sensitivity and specificity were determined to be 98.8% and 88.5%, respectively.</Species>
<Species>A significant positive correlation was found between results of the blocking ELISA and the serum neutralization assay (r=0.9381).</Species>

text: <Species>A longitudinal antibody profile showed that serum neutralizing antibodies were detected 2 weeks after vaccination and that the detection rate reached 100% at 4 weeks.</Species>

text: <Species>Additionally, the positive detection rate in 703 sera collected from nine commercial pig farms was 73%.</Species>

text: <Species>Chromera velia is a photosynthetic alga with a secondary plastid that represents the closest known photosynthetic relative of the apicomplexan parasites.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The original description of this organism was based on brownish, immotile coccoid cells, which is the predominating stage of C. velia in the culture.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here we provide a detailed light and electron microscopy description of coccoid cells of C. velia and a previously undocumented bi-flagellated stage that is highly motile and moves in a characteristic zig-zag pattern.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Transformation from a coccoid into a flagellate stage occurs in exponentially growing cultures, and is accelerated by exposure to light.</Species>

<Species>The C. velia cells contain a pseudoconoid, which is likely homologous to the corresponding structure in the apical complex of Apicomplexa, cortical alveoli subtended by subpellicular microtubules, mitochondrion with tubular cristae, a micropyle, and a distinctive chromerosome, an apparently novel type of extrusion organelle.</Species>

<Species>Genetic and molecular characterization of a blue light photoreceptor MGWC-1 in Magnaporth oryzae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Three key factors involved in successful plant disease development include the presence of a susceptible host, a virulent pathogen, and a disease-conducive environment.</Species>

<Species>Our understanding of how environmental factors influence disease-conducive or disease-suppressive conditions, and how a pathogen advantageously capitalizes on them, is quite limited.</Species>
<Species>Utilizing the model pathosystem Magnaporthe oryzae-Oryza sativa, we found a significant light-dependent disease suppression.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Our genetic data suggest that the blue-light receptor MGWC-1 in M. oryzae is involved in light-dependent disease suppression during the dark-phase (disease-conducive light condition) immediately after pathogen-host contact.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sensing "darkness" is accomplished by MGWC-1, a blue-light receptor in M. oryzae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To explore the potential molecular mechanisms of light-dependent disease suppression we performed a genome-wide microarray experiment and identified several groups of gene families that are differentially regulated during the light-to-dark transition.</Species>
<Species>Our genetic and molecular data provide insights into how a fungal pathogen utilizes ambient light signals for successful disease development.</Species>
<Species>XerCD-mediated site-specific recombination leads to loss of the 57-kilobase gonococcal genetic island.</Species>
<Species>Most strains of Neisseria gonorrhoeae carry the 57-kb gonococcal genetic island (GGI), as do a few strains of Neisseria meningitidis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The GGI is inserted into the chromosome at the dif site (difA) and is flanked by a partial repeat of the dif site (difB).</Species>

<Species>Since dif is a sequence recognized by the site-specific recombinases XerC and XerD and the GGI shows evidence of horizontal acquisition, we hypothesized that the GGI may be acquired or lost by XerCD-mediated site-specific recombination.</Species>

<Species>We show that while the GGI flanked by wild-type dif sites, difA and difB, is not readily lost from the gonococcal chromosome, the substitution of difB with another copy of difA allows the frequent excision and loss of the GGI.</Species>
<Species>In mutants carrying two difA sites (difA(+) difA(+)), the GGI can be detected as an extrachromosomal circle that exists transiently.</Species>
<Species>A mutation of xerD diminished GGI excision from the chromosome of a difA(+) difA(+) strain, while mutations in recA or type IV secretion genes had no effect on the loss of the GGI.</Species>

<Species>These data indicate that the GGI is maintained by the replication of the chromosome and that GGI excision and loss are dependent upon the dif sequence and xerD. The detection of a circular form of the GGI in a wild-type strain suggests that GGI excision may occur naturally and could function to facilitate GGI transfer.</Species>

<Species>These data suggest a model of GGI excision and loss explaining the absence of the GGI from some gonococcal strains and the maintenance of variant GGIs in some gonococcal and meningococcal isolates.</Species>

text: <Species>Mapping of the Neisseria meningitidis NadA cell-binding site: relevance of predicted {alpha}-helices in the NH2-terminal and dimeric coiled-coil regions.</Species>

text: <Species>NadA is a trimeric autotransporter protein of Neisseria meningitidis belonging to the group of oligomeric coiled-coil adhesins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It is implicated in the colonization of the human upper respiratory tract by hypervirulent serogroup B N. meningitidis strains and is part of a multiantigen anti-serogroup B vaccine.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Structure prediction indicates that NadA is made by a COOH-terminal membrane anchor (also necessary for autotranslocation to the bacterial surface), an intermediate elongated coiled-coil-rich stalk, and an NH(2)-terminal region involved in cell interaction.</Species>
<Species>Electron microscopy analysis and structure prediction suggest that the apical region of NadA forms a compact and globular domain.</Species>
<Species>Deletion studies proved that the NH(2)-terminal sequence (residues 24 to 87) is necessary for cell adhesion.</Species>

<Species>In this study, to better define the NadA cell binding site, we exploited (i) a panel of NadA mutants lacking sequences along the coiled-coil stalk and (ii) several oligoclonal rabbit antibodies, and their relative Fab fragments, directed to linear epitopes distributed along the NadA ectodomain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We identified two critical regions for the NadA-cell receptor interaction with Chang cells: the NH(2) globular head domain and the NH(2) dimeric intrachain coiled-coil alpha-helices stemming from the stalk.</Species>
<Species>This raises the importance of different modules within the predicted NadA structure.</Species>
<Species>The identification of linear epitopes involved in receptor binding that are able to induce interfering antibodies reinforces the importance of NadA as a vaccine antigen.</Species>

text: <Species>Infectious hypodermal and hematopoietic necrosis virus (IHHNV) is an important shrimp pathogen that causes mortality in Penaeus stylirostris and stunting (called runt deformity syndrome or RDS) in Penaeus vannamei.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Loop-mediated isothermal amplification (LAMP) allows rapid amplification of nucleic acids under isothermal conditions.</Species>
<Species>It can be combined with a chromatographic lateral flow dipstick (LFD) for highly specific, rapid and simple visual detection of IHHNV-specific amplicons.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Using this protocol, a 30-min amplification followed by 5 min hybridization with an FITC-labeled DNA probe and 5 min LFD resulted in visualization of DNA amplicons trapped at the LFD test line.</Species>

<Species>Thus, 10 min for rapid DNA extraction followed by LAMP combined with LFD detection resulted in a total assay time of approximately 50 min. Detection sensitivity was comparable to other methods used commonly for nested PCR detection of IHHNV but had the additional advantages of reduced assay time, confirmation of amplicon identity by hybridization and elimination of electrophoresis with carcinogenic ethidium bromide.</Species>

text: <Species>Characterization of the developmental regulator FlbE in Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus nidulans.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Several upstream developmental activators control asexual development (conidiation) in Aspergillus.</Species>
<Species>In this study, we characterize one of such activators called flbE in Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus nidulans.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The predicted FlbE protein is composed of 222 and 201 aa in A. fumigatus and A. nidulans, respectively.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>While flbE is transiently expressed during early phase of growth in A. nidulans, it is somewhat constitutively expressed during the lifecycle of A. fumigatus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The deletion of flbE causes reduced conidiation and delayed expression of brlA and vosA in both species.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, FlbE is necessary for salt-induced development in liquid submerged culture in A. fumigatus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The A. nidulans flbE null mutation is fully complemented by A. fumigatus flbE, indicating a functional conservancy of FlbE in Aspergillus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Both the deletion and overexpression of flbE in A. nidulans result in developmental defects, enhanced autolysis, precocious cell death, and delayed expression of brlA/vosA, suggesting that balanced activity of FlbE is crucial for proper growth and development.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Importantly, the N-terminal portion of FlbE exhibits the trans-activation ability in yeast, whereas the C-terminal half negatively affects its activity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Site-directed mutagenesis of certain conserved N-terminal amino acids abolishes the ability of trans-activation, overexpression-induced autolysis, and complementing the null mutation.</Species>
<Species>Finally, overexpression of flbD, but not flbB or flbC, restores conidiation in A. nidulans DeltaflbE, generally supporting the current genetic model for developmental regulation.</Species>

text: <Species>Response of ecosystems to realistic extinction sequences.</Species>
<Species>Separating parental environment from seed size effects on next generation growth and development in Arabidopsis.</Species>
<Species>Plant growth and development is profoundly influenced by environmental conditions that laboratory experimentation typically attempts to control.</Species>
<Species>However, growth conditions are not uniform between or even within laboratories and the extent to which these differences influence plant growth and development is unknown.</Species>
<Species>Experiments with wild-type Arabidopsis thaliana were designed to quantify the influences of parental environment and seed size on growth and development in the next generation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A single lot of seed was planted in six environmental chambers and grown to maturity.</Species>
<Species>The seed produced was mechanically sieved into small and large size classes then grown in a common environment and subjected to a set of assays spanning the life cycle.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of variance demonstrated that seed size effects were particularly significant early in development, affecting primary root growth and gravitropism, but also flowering time.</Species>
<Species>Parental environment affected progeny germination time, flowering and weight of seed the progeny produced.</Species>
<Species>In some cases, the parental environment affected the magnitude of (interacted with) the observed seed size effects.</Species>

<Species>These data indicate that life history circumstances of the parental generation can affect growth and development throughout the life cycle of the next generation to an extent that should be considered when performing genetic studies.</Species>

<Species>The absence of sex-biased dispersal in the cooperatively breeding grey-crowned babbler.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1. Cooperatively breeding birds are thought to be especially vulnerable to habitat fragmentation, in part because dispersal is typically restricted for one sex, increasing the likelihood of inbreeding.</Species>

<Species>Knowledge of dispersal is essential to conservation efforts, but is often hampered by our inability to measure its frequency and distance when dispersal is infrequent and difficult to observe.</Species>
<Species>2. Disrupted dispersal is a purported cause of decline in the Australian grey-crowned babbler (Pomatostomus temporalis).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Both sexes of offspring delay dispersal for up to several years to help parents raise subsequent broods, yet little else is known about the dispersal of this cooperatively breeding woodland bird.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>As both sexes appear to help, but only male helpers boost fledgling production, we hypothesized that males would be the more philopatric sex in this species, and that female grey-crowned babblers would disperse over greater distances.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>4. To ensure reliable determination of sex and minimize bias towards detecting short-distance dispersal events, we combined molecular-based sexing and analyses of population genetic structure using polymorphic microsatellite loci with observational data obtained over multiple field seasons.</Species>
<Species>5. Observations of banded birds showed only infrequent fission of groups or short-distance dispersal (mean=854 m), but no apparent sex-bias in these patterns.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>There was significant genetic differentiation between social groups, but not between the sexes.</Species>
<Species>Spatial genetic autocorrelation analysis of breeders revealed a random distribution of genotypes across the study area for both sexes.</Species>

<Species>Thus, contrary to expectations, we found no genetic evidence for restricted dispersal or for sex-biased dispersal over the 85-km scale of this study, indicating that effective dispersal occurs over greater distances and more frequently than recoveries of banded birds indicated.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>
<Species>We conclude that while constraints on independent breeding encourage high rates of philopatry, incest avoidance nonetheless drives high rates of dispersal by both sexes.</Species>

<Species>In fragmented habitat, the dispersal dynamics of this cooperatively breeding species are unlikely to render them particularly vulnerable to genetic consequences such as inbreeding, but may lead to increased group dissolution.</Species>

text: <Species>Durable resistance to apple scab (Venturia inaequalis (Cke) Wint; anamorph Spilocaea pomi Fries) is one of the major goals of apple (Malus) breeding programs.</Species>

<Species>While the genomic organization of apple scab resistance genes has been studied extensively, little is known about the avirulence genes in the pathogen.</Species>

text: <Species>The progeny of a cross of European V. inaequalis race (1) isolate EU-B04 and race (1,2,8,9) isolate 1639 was used to generate a genetic map based on microsatellite and AFLP markers, and investigated for inheritance of avirulence traits on 20 Malus accessions representing 17 scab resistance genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The accessions comprised scab differential hosts (0), (1), (2), (8), and (9), and hosts carrying known as well as not previously reported secondary resistance genes, including some identified in crosses that have resistant accessions 'Geneva', 'Dolgo', Malus baccata jackii, M. micromalus, or 'Antonovka' in their pedigree.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The latter genes appear to be narrow spectrum genes that showed gene-for-gene relationships as a segregation ratio of Avr:avr=1:1 was observed on 12 accessions, while a ratio of 3:1 was observed on five accessions and a ratio of 7:1 on one host.</Species>
<Species>All progenies were shown to be pathogenic, as all of them were able to infect hosts (0) and (1).</Species>
<Species>A genetic map consisting of 15 major linkage groups (LGs) and spanning 972cM was generated with the aid of 156 markers.</Species>

<Species>The map position of 12 avirulence traits was determined: eight avirulence genes mapped into two separate clusters (1: AvrVdg2, AvrVv1, AvrVu1, AvrVrjrd; and 2: AvrVu2, AvrVh3.2, AvrVs1, AvrVu4), while four avirulence genes (AvrRvi8, AvrVv2, AvrVt57 and AvrVsv) mapped to different LGs.</Species>
<Species>AvrRvi2 and AvrRvi9 also are genetically linked, but showed an interaction with AvrRvi8, the nature of which is unclear.</Species>
<Species>While AvrRvi8 segregated at 1:1 ratio, the other two Avrs segregated at 3:1 ratios.</Species>
<Species>However, all progeny avirulent on hosts (2) and (9) were also avirulent on host (8) and further research is required to determine the avirulence gene relationships.</Species>
<Species>A further two independently segregating loci, AvrRvi1 and AvrRvi6, identified in previous studies, were mapped by inference based on their known linkage to SSR markers.</Species>

<Species>The clustering of avirulence genes in V. inaequalis reflecting the clustering of resistance genes in Malus suggests this pathosystem is a classical example of an "arms race" between host and pathogen.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This also seems to apply to the narrow spectrum scab resistance genes, which may imply a larger role in plant defense for these genes than has been assumed to date.</Species>

<Species>Adaptation of a Madin-Darby canine kidney cell line to suspension growth in serum-free media and comparison of its ability to produce avian influenza virus to Vero and BHK21 cell lines.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells are currently considered for influenza vaccine manufacturing.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A drawback of these cells is their anchorage dependent growth, which greatly complicates process scale-up.</Species>

<Species>In this paper a novel MDCK cell line (MDCK-SFS) is described that grows efficiently in suspension and retained high expression levels of both alpha-2,6 and alpha-2,3 sialic acid receptors, which bind preferably to human and avian influenza viruses, respectively.</Species>
<Species>The production of avian influenza virus by BHK21, Vero and MDCK-SFS cell lines was compared.</Species>
<Species>Although BHK21 cells consisted of two populations, one of which lacks the alpha-2,3 receptor, they supported the replication of two influenza strains to high titres.</Species>
<Species>However, BHK21 cells are generally not applicable for influenza production since they supported the replication of six further strains poorly.</Species>

<Species>MDCK-SFS cells yielded the highest infectious virus titres and virus genome equivalent concentration for five of the eight influenza strains analyzed and the highest hemagglutination activity for all eight virus strains.</Species>
<Species>Taken together with their suitability for suspension growth this makes the MDCK-SFS cell line potentially useful for large scale influenza virus production.</Species>
<Species>Characterizing the role of RNA silencing components in Cryptococcus neoformans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The RNA interference (RNAi) mediated by homology-dependent degradation of the target mRNA with small RNA molecules plays a key role in controlling transcription and translation processes in a number of eukaryotic organisms.</Species>
<Species>The RNAi machinery is also evolutionarily conserved in a wide variety of fungal species, including pathogenic fungi.</Species>

<Species>To elucidate the physiological functions of the RNAi pathway in Cryptococcus neoformans that causes fungal meningitis, here we performed genetic analyses for genes encoding Argonaute (AGO1 and AGO2), RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RDP1), and Dicers (DCR1 and DCR2) in both serotype A and D C. neoformans.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The present study shows that Ago1, Rdp1, and Dcr2 are the major components of the RNAi process occurring in C. neoformans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, the RNAi machinery is not involved in regulation of production of two virulence factors (capsule and melanin), sexual differentiation, and diverse stress response.</Species>

<Species>Comparative transcriptome analysis of the serotype A and D RNAi mutants revealed that only modest changes occur in the genome-wide transcriptome profiles when the RNAi process was perturbed.</Species>

<Species>Notably, the serotype D rdp1Delta mutants showed an increase in transcript abundance of active retrotransposons and transposons, such as T2 and T3, the latter of which is a novel serotype D-specific transposon of C. neoformans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In a wild type background both T2 and T3 were found to be weakly active mobile elements, although we found no evidence of Cnl1 retrotransposon mobility.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, all three transposable elements exhibited enhanced mobility in the rdp1Delta mutant strain.</Species>
<Species>In conclusion, the RNAi pathway plays an important role in controlling transposon activity and genome integrity of C. neoformans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Molecular structure of the prothoracicotropic hormone gene in the northern house mosquito, Culex pipiens, and its expression analysis in association with diapause and blood feeding.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We cloned the gene that encodes prothoracicotropic hormone (PTTH) in the northern house mosquito, Culex pipiens, and investigated its expression profile in short-day (diapause-destined) and long-day (nondiapause-destined) individuals from the fourth-instar larval stage to 2 months of adulthood, as well as after a blood meal.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The deduced C. pipiens PTTH (Cupip-PTTH) amino acid sequence contains seven cysteines with a specific spacing pattern.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sequence alignment suggests that Cupip-PTTH is 23% identical to Drosophila melanogaster PTTH, but is >=59% identical to the PTTHs of other mosquitoes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cupip-PTTH has structural characteristics similar to those of Bombyx mori PTTH and some vertebrate nerve growth factors with cysteine-knot motifs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>PTTH transcripts exhibit a daily cycling profile during the final (fourth) larval instar, with peak abundance occurring late in the scotophase.</Species>
<Species>The fourth-larval instar stage is one day longer in short-day larvae than in long-day larvae, resulting in larger larvae and adults.</Species>
<Species>This additional day of larval development is associated with one extra PTTH cycle.</Species>
<Species>No cycling was observed in pupae, but PTTH transcripts were slightly higher in short-day pupae than in long-day pupae throughout much of the pupal stage.</Species>

<Species>PTTH expression persisted at a nearly constant level in diapausing adult females for the first month but then dropped by -50%, while expression decreased at the beginning of adulthood in nondiapausing females and then remained at a low level as long as the females were denied a blood meal.</Species>

<Species>However, when nondiapausing females were offered a blood meal, PTTH transcripts rose approximately 7 fold in 2 h and remained elevated for 24 h. A few diapausing females (-10%) will take a blood meal when placed in close proximity to a host, but much of the blood is ejected and such meals do not result in mature eggs.</Species>
<Species>Yet, elevated PTTH mRNA expression was also observed in diapausing females that were force fed.</Species>

<Species>Our results thus point to several distinctions in PTTH expression between short-day and long-day mosquitoes, but both types of females responded to a blood meal by elevating levels of PTTH mRNA.</Species>
<Species>Assembly of the type II secretion system: identification of ExeA residues critical for peptidoglycan binding and secretin multimerization.</Species>
<Species>Aeromonas hydrophila secretes a number of protein toxins across the outer membrane via the type II secretion system (T2SS).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Assembly of the secretion channel ExeD secretin into the outer membrane is dependent on the peptidoglycan binding domain of ExeA. In this study, the peptidoglycan binding domain PF01471 family members were divided into a prokaryotic group and a eukaryotic group.</Species>

<Species>By comparison of their sequence conservation profiles and their representative crystal structures, we found the prokaryotic members to have a highly conserved pocket(s) that is not present in the eukaryotic members.</Species>

<Species>Substitution mutations of nine amino acids of the pocket were constructed in ExeA. Five of the substitution derivatives showed greatly decreased lipase secretion, accompanied by defects in secretin assembly.</Species>
<Species>In addition, using in vivo cross-linking and in vitro cosedimentation assays, we showed that these mutations decreased ExeA-peptidoglycan interactions.</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that the highly conserved pocket in ExeA is the binding site for its peptidoglycan ligand and identify residues critical for this binding.</Species>
<Species>Universal primers for rapid detection of hytrosaviruses.</Species>

<Species>Hytrosaviridae is a proposed virus family encompassing viruses that cause salivary gland hypertrophy (SGH) syndrome in infected insects and reduce the fertility in their dipteran insect hosts.</Species>
<Species>They contain a large, double stranded DNA genome of 120-190 kbp.</Species>
<Species>To date, these viruses have been detected only in adult Diptera.</Species>
<Species>These include hytrosaviruses detected in various tsetse fly species (Glossina spp.), the narcissus bulb fly Merodon equestris and the house fly Musca domestica.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The limited number of hytrosaviruses reported to date may be a reflection of the frequent absence of external symptoms in infected adult flies and the fact that the virus does not cause rapid mortality.</Species>

<Species>Based on the complete genome sequence of Glossinia pallidipes (GpSGHV) and Musca domestica (MdSGHV) salivary gland hypertrophy viruses, a PCR based methodology was developed to detect the viruses in these species.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>To be able to detect hytrosaviruses in other Diptera, five degenerate primer pairs were designed and tested on GpSGHV and MdSGHV DNA using gradient PCR with annealing temperatures from 37 to 61^0C. Two pairs of primers were selected from p74, two pairs from PIF-1 and one pair from ODV-e66 homologous proteins.</Species>

<Species>Four primer pairs generated a virus specific PCR product on both MdSGHV and GpSGHV at all tested annealing temperatures, while the ODV-e66 based primers did not generate a virus specific product with annealing temperatures higher that 47^0C.</Species>
<Species>No non-specific PCR product was found when using genomic DNA of infected flies as template DNA.</Species>
<Species>These results offer new sets of primers that could be used to detect hytrosaviruses in other insects.</Species>
<Species>Reproductive health, and child health and nutrition in India: meeting the challenge.</Species>
<Species>India, with a population of more than 1 billion people, has many challenges in improving the health and nutrition of its citizens.</Species>

<Species>Steady declines have been noted in fertility, maternal, infant and child mortalities, and the prevalence of severe manifestations of nutritional deficiencies, but the pace has been slow and falls short of national and Millennium Development Goal targets.</Species>
<Species>The likely explanations include social inequities, disparities in health systems between and within states, and consequences of urbanisation and demographic transition.</Species>
<Species>In 2005, India embarked on the National Rural Health Mission, an extraordinary effort to strengthen the health systems.</Species>
<Species>However, coverage of priority interventions remains insufficient, and the content and quality of existing interventions are suboptimum.</Species>
<Species>Substantial unmet need for contraception remains, adolescent pregnancies are common, and access to safe abortion is inadequate.</Species>
<Species>Increases in the numbers of deliveries in institutions have not been matched by improvements in the quality of intrapartum and neonatal care.</Species>

<Species>Infants and young children do not get the health care they need; access to effective treatment for neonatal illness, diarrhoea, and pneumonia shows little improvement; and the coverage of nutrition programmes is inadequate.</Species>

<Species>Absence of well functioning health systems is indicated by the inadequacies related to planning, financing, human resources, infrastructure, supply systems, governance, information, and monitoring.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We provide a case for transformation of health systems through effective stewardship, decentralised planning in districts, a reasoned approach to financing that affects demand for health care, a campaign to create awareness and change health and nutrition behaviour, and revision of programmes for child nutrition on the basis of evidence.</Species>
<Species>This agenda needs political commitment of the highest order and the development of a people's movement.</Species>

<Species>Large differences were also observed between species and between larval and adult stages; however, the male and female larval samples were remarkably similar.</Species>
<Species>Quantitative PCR analysis of selected genes, cox1, l-rRNA and nd5, in larvae and adults of Ae. aegypti and in An.</Species>

<Species>Finally, the absence of a conserved mtDNA region involved in transcriptional control in other dipterans suggests that mosquitoes have evolved a distinct mechanism of regulation of gene expression in the mitochondrion.</Species>
<Species>Tortricid moths reared from the invasive weed Mexican palo verde, Parkinsonia aculeata, with comments on their host specificity, biology, geographic distribution, and systematics.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>As part of efforts to identify native herbivores of Mexican palo verde, Parkinsonia aculeata L. (Leguminosae: Caesalpinioideae), as potential biological control agents against this invasive weed in Australia, ten species of Tortricidae (Lepidoptera) were reared from Guatemala, Mexico, Nicaragua, and Venezuela: Amorbia concavana (Zeller), Platynota rostrana (Walker), Platynota helianthes (Meyrick), Platynota stultana Walsingham (all Tortricinae: Sparganothini), Rudenia leguminana (Busck), Cochylis sp. (both Tortricinae: Cochylini), Ofatulena duodecemstriata (Walsingham), O. luminosa Heinrich, Ofatulena sp. (all Olethreutinae: Grapholitini), and Crocidosema lantana Busck (Olethreutinae: Eucosmini).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Significant geographic range extensions are provided for O. duodecemstriata and R. leguminana.</Species>
<Species>These are the first documented records of P. aculeata as a host plant for all but O. luminosa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The four species of Sparganothini are polyphagous; in contrast, the two Cochylini and three Grapholitini likely are specialists on Leguminosae.</Species>
<Species>Ofatulena luminosa is possibly host specific on P. aculeata.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Host trials with Rudenia leguminana also provide some evidence of specificity, in contrast to historical rearing records.</Species>

<Species>To examine the possibility that R. leguminana is a complex of species, two data sets of molecular markers were examined: (1) a combined data set of two mitochondrial markers (a 781-basepair region of cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) and a 685-basepair region of cytochrome c oxidase II) and one nuclear marker (a 531-basepair region of the 28S domain 2); and (2) the 650-basepair "barcode" region of COI.</Species>
<Species>Analyses of both data sets strongly suggest that individuals examined in this study belong to more than one species.</Species>
<Species>Determinants of reproductive success in dominant pairs of clownfish: a boosted regression tree analysis.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Central questions of behavioural and evolutionary ecology are what factors influence the reproductive success of dominant breeders and subordinate nonbreeders within animal societies?</Species>
<Species>A complete understanding of any society requires that these questions be answered for all individuals.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>The clown anemonefish, Amphiprion percula, forms simple societies that live in close association with sea anemones, Heteractis magnifica.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Here, we use data from a well-studied population of A. percula to determine the major predictors of reproductive success of dominant pairs in this species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We analyse the effect of multiple predictors on four components of reproductive success, using a relatively new technique from the field of statistical learning: boosted regression trees (BRTs).</Species>
<Species>BRTs have the potential to model complex relationships in ways that give powerful insight.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We show that the reproductive success of dominant pairs is unrelated to the presence, number or phenotype of nonbreeders.</Species>
<Species>This is consistent with the observation that nonbreeders do not help or hinder breeders in any way, confirming and extending the results of a previous study.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>Primarily, reproductive success is negatively related to male growth and positively related to breeding experience.</Species>
<Species>It is likely that these effects are interrelated because males that grow a lot have little breeding experience.</Species>
<Species>These effects are indicative of a trade-off between male growth and parental investment.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>Secondarily, reproductive success is positively related to female growth and size.</Species>
<Species>In this population, female size is positively related to group size and anemone size, also.</Species>
<Species>These positive correlations among traits likely are caused by variation in site quality and are suggestive of a silver-spoon effect.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>
<Species>Noteworthily, whereas reproductive success is positively related to female size, it is unrelated to male size.</Species>

<Species>This observation provides support for the size advantage hypothesis for sex change: both individuals maximize their reproductive success when the larger individual adopts the female tactic.</Species>
<Species>8.</Species>

<Species>This study provides the most complete picture to date of the factors that predict the reproductive success of dominant pairs of clown anemonefish and illustrates the utility of BRTs for analysis of complex behavioural and evolutionary ecology data.</Species>
<Species>Compartmentalization and molecular traffic in secondary metabolism: a new understanding of established cellular processes.</Species>
<Species>Great progress has been made in understanding the regulation of expression of genes involved in secondary metabolism.</Species>
<Species>Less is known about the mechanisms that govern the spatial distribution of the enzymes, cofactors, and substrates that mediate catalysis of secondary metabolites within the cell.</Species>

<Species>Filamentous fungi in the genus Aspergillus synthesize an array of secondary metabolites and provide useful systems to analyze the mechanisms that mediate the temporal and spatial regulation of secondary metabolism in eukaryotes.</Species>

<Species>For example, aflatoxin biosynthesis in Aspergillus parasiticus has been studied intensively because this mycotoxin is highly toxic, mutagenic, and carcinogenic in humans and animals.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Using aflatoxin synthesis to illustrate key concepts, this review focuses on the mechanisms by which sub-cellular compartmentalization and intra-cellular molecular traffic contribute to the initiation and completion of secondary metabolism within the cell.</Species>

<Species>We discuss the recent discovery of aflatoxisomes, specialized trafficking vesicles that participate in the compartmentalization of aflatoxin synthesis and export of the toxin to the cell exterior; this work provides a new and clearer understanding of how cells integrate secondary metabolism into basic cellular metabolism via the intra-cellular trafficking machinery.</Species>

<Species>Comparative immunofluorescence and ultrastructural analysis of microtubule organization in Uronema sp., Klebsormidium flaccidum, K. subtilissimum, Stichococcus bacillaris and S. chloranthus (Chlorophyta).</Species>

text: <Species>A detailed comparative examination of microtubule (MT) organization in interphase and dividing cells of Uronema sp., Klebsormidium flaccidum, K. subtilissimum, Stichococcus bacillaris and S. chloranthus was made using tubulin immunofluorescence and transmission electron microscopy (TEM).</Species>
label: Species

Species

text: <Species>During interphase all the species bear a well-organized cortical MT system, consisting of parallel bundles with different orientations.</Species>
<Species>In Uronema sp.</Species>
<Species>the cortical MT bundles are longitudinally oriented, whereas in the other species they are in transverse orientation to the axis of the cells.</Species>
<Species>Considerable differences in MT organization were also observed during stages of mitosis, mainly preprophase, as well as cytokinesis.</Species>
<Species>In Uronema sp., a particular radial MT assembly is organized during preprophase-early prophase, which was not observed in the other species.</Species>
<Species>In Stichococcus a fine MT ring surrounded the nucleus during preprophase and prophase.</Species>
<Species>An MT ring, together with single cytoplasmic MTs, was also found associated with the developing diaphragm during cytokinesis in Stichococcus.</Species>
<Species>A phycoplast participates in cytokinesis in Uronema sp., but not in the other species.</Species>
<Species>In Uronema sp.</Species>
<Species>the centrosome functions as a microtubule organizing center (MTOC) during mitosis, but not during interphase and cytokinesis.</Species>
<Species>The phylogenetic significance of these differences is discussed in combination with SSU/ITS sequencing and other, existing molecular data.</Species>

<Species>The 13C/12C isotopic signal of day-respired CO2 in variegated leaves of Pelargonium x hortorum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In leaves, although it is accepted that CO(2) evolved by dark respiration after illumination is naturally (13) C-enriched compared to organic matter or substrate sucrose, much uncertainty remains on whether day respiration produces (13) C-depleted or (13) C-enriched CO(2).</Species>

<Species>Here, we applied equations described previously for mesocosm CO(2) exchange to investigate the carbon isotope composition of CO(2) respired by autotrophic and heterotrophic tissues of Pelargonium x hortorum leaves, taking advantage of leaf variegation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Day-respired CO(2) was slightly (13) C-depleted compared to organic matter both under 21% O(2) and 2% O(2).</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, most, if not all CO(2) molecules evolved in the light came from carbon atoms that had been fixed previously before the experiments, in both variegated and green leaves.</Species>

<Species>We conclude that the usual definition of day respiratory fractionation, that assumes carbon fixed by current net photosynthesis is the respiratory substrate, is not valid in Pelargonium leaves under our conditions.</Species>
<Species>In variegated leaves, total organic matter was slightly (13) C-depleted in white areas and so were most primary metabolites.</Species>

<Species>This small isotopic difference between white and green areas probably came from the small contribution of photosynthetic CO(2) refixation and the specific nitrogen metabolism in white leaf areas.</Species>
<Species>Promoter discrimination at class I MarA regulon promoters mediated by glutamic acid 89 of the MarA transcriptional activator of Escherichia coli.</Species>

text: <Species>Three paralogous transcriptional activators MarA, SoxS, and Rob, activate > 40 Escherichia coli promoters.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To understand why MarA does not activate certain promoters as strongly as SoxS, we compared MarA, MarA mutants, and SoxS for their abilities to activate 16 promoters and to bind their cognate marbox binding sites.</Species>
<Species>Replacement of the MarA glutamic acid residue 89 with alanine greatly increased the marbox binding and activation of many class I promoters.</Species>
<Species>Like cells constitutive for SoxS, cells expressing the MarA with the E89A mutation were more resistant to superoxides than those harboring WT MarA.</Species>
<Species>The activities of several other E89 substitutions ranked as follows: E89A ></Species>
<Species>E89G > E89V ></Species>
<Species>WT > E89D. Increased binding and activation occurred only at class</Species>
<Species>I promoters when the 12th base of the promoter's marbox (a position at which there is no known interaction between the marbox and MarA) was not a T residue.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, WT MarA binding to a synthetic marbox in vitro was enhanced when the phosphate group between positions 12 and 13 was eliminated on one strand.</Species>

<Species>The results demonstrate that relatively minor changes in a single amino acid side chain (e.g., alanine to valine or glutamic acid to aspartic acid) can strongly influence activity despite any evidence that the side chain is involved in positive interactions with either DNA or RNA polymerase.</Species>

<Species>We present a model which attributes the differences in binding and activation to the interference between the Beta- and gamma-carbons of the amino acid at position 89 and the phosphate group between positions 12 and 13.</Species>
<Species>Ca(2+)-dependent in vivo protein phosphorylation and encystment induction in the ciliated protozoan Colpoda cucullus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Encystment induction of Colpoda cucullus is promoted by an increase in external Ca(2+) and overpopulation of Colpoda vegetative cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Using phos-tag detection assays, the present study revealed that the in vivo phosphorylation level in several proteins [33 kDa, 37 kDa, 37.5 kDa, 43 kDa, 47 kDa, 49 kDa, etc.] was raised when the vegetative cells were stimulated by overpopulation to encyst in a medium containing 0.1 mM</Species>
<Species>Ca(2+) or without the addition of Ca(2+).</Species>
<Species>Both overpopulation-mediated encystment induction and protein phosphorylation were suppressed by the addition of EGTA.</Species>
<Species>Ca(2+)/overpopulation-stimulated encystment induction and protein phosphorylation were also suppressed by the addition of BAPTA-AM.</Species>

<Species>These results suggest that the Ca(2+) inflow promoted by cell-to-cell stimulation due to overpopulation may activate signaling pathways involving protein phosphorylation and encystment induction.</Species>
<Species>In the presence of cAMP-AM, the phosphorylation levels of 33 kDa, 37 kDa, 37.5 kDa, 43 kDa, 47 kDa and 49 kDa proteins were enhanced, and encystment induction was promoted.</Species>
<Species>Enzyme immunoassays (EIAs) showed that intracellular cAMP concentration was raised prior to encystment when the cells were stimulated by overpopulation.</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that cAMP/PKA-dependent protein phosphorylation, which is an event on Ca(2+)-triggered signaling pathways, may be involved in encystment induction.</Species>

text: <Species>Genetic and mass spectrometry analyses of the unusual type IV-like pili of the archaeon Methanococcus maripaludis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The structure of pili from the archaeon Methanococcus maripaludis is unlike that of any bacterial pili.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, genetic analysis of the genes involved in the formation of these pili has been lacking until this study.</Species>

<Species>Pili were isolated from a nonflagellated (DeltaflaK) mutant and shown by sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis to consist primarily of subunits with an apparent molecular mass of 17 kDa.</Species>

<Species>In-frame deletions were created in three genes, MMP0233, MMP0236, and MMP0237, which encode proteins with bacterial type IV pilin-like signal peptides previously identified by in silico methodology as likely candidates for pilus structural proteins.</Species>

<Species>Deletion of MMP0236 or MMP0237 resulted in mutant cells completely devoid of pili on the cell surface, while deletion of the third pilin-like gene, MMP0233, resulted in cells greatly reduced in the number of pili on the surface.</Species>
<Species>Complementation with the deleted gene in each case returned the cells to a piliated state.</Species>

<Species>Surprisingly, mass spectrometry analysis of purified pili identified the major structural pilin as another type IV pilin-like protein, MMP1685, whose gene is located outside the first pilus locus.</Species>
<Species>This protein was found to be glycosylated with an N-linked branched pentasaccharide glycan.</Species>
<Species>Deletion and complementation analysis confirmed that MMP1685 is required for piliation.</Species>

text: <Species>Human cytomegalovirus (HCMV) virions are composed of a DNA-containing nucleocapsid surrounded by a tegument layer and host-derived lipid envelope studded with virally encoded glycoproteins.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These complex virions are estimated to be composed of more than 50 viral proteins.</Species>

<Species>Assembly of HCMV virions is poorly understood, especially with respect to acquisition of the tegument; however, it is thought to involve the stepwise addition of virion components through protein-protein interactions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We sought to identify interactions among HCMV virion proteins using yeast two-hybrid analysis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Using 33 known capsid and tegument proteins, we tested 1,089 pairwise combinations for binary interaction in the two-hybrid assay.</Species>
<Species>We identified 24 interactions among HCMV virion proteins, including 13 novel interactions among tegument proteins and one novel interaction between capsid proteins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Several of these novel interactions were confirmed by coimmunoprecipitation of protein complexes from transfected cells.</Species>
<Species>In addition, we demonstrate three of these interactions in the context of HCMV infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This study reveals several new protein-protein interactions among HCMV tegument proteins, some of which are likely important for HCMV replication and pathogenesis.</Species>

text: <Species>Novel mutations reveal two important regions in Aspergillus nidulans transcriptional activator MetR.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Expression of the sulfur assimilation pathway in Aspergillus nidulans is under control of sulfur metabolite repression, which is composed of scon genes encoding subunits of ubiquitin ligase and the metR gene coding for a transcriptional activator.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this paper we report three dominant suppressors of methionine requirement isolated from a metB3 diploid strain.</Species>
<Species>All three mutations lead to the substitution of phenylalanine 48 by serine or leucine in the conserved N-terminal region of the MetR protein.</Species>

<Species>Strains carrying the dominant suppressor mutations exhibit increased activities of homocysteine synthase and sulfur assimilation enzymes as well as elevated levels of the corresponding transcripts.</Species>

<Species>These changes are observed even under conditions of methionine repression, which suggests that the mutated MetR protein may be resistant to inactivation or degradation mediated by sulfur metabolite repression.</Species>
<Species>We also found that a mutant impaired in sulfite reductase activity, known until now as sG8, has a frameshift which changes 41 C-terminal amino acids.</Species>
<Species>Therefore, it is now designated metR18.</Species>

<Species>This mutant has elevated levels of MetR-regulated transcripts and of activities of sulfur assimilation enzymes (except sulfite reductase), which can be repressed to the wild type level by exogenous methionine.</Species>
<Species>Thus, metR18 and the three dominant suppressors represent new types of mutations affecting different parts of the A. nidulans MetR protein.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Haplotype analysis of the genes encoding glutamine synthetase plastic isoforms and their association with nitrogen-use- and yield-related traits in bread wheat.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Glutamine synthetase (GS) plays a key role in the growth, nitrogen (N) use and yield potential of cereal crops.</Species>
<Species>Investigating the haplotype variation of GS genes and its association with agronomic traits may provide useful information for improving wheat N-use efficiency and yield.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We isolated the promoter and coding region sequences of the plastic glutamine synthetase isoform (GS2) genes located on chromosomes 2A, 2B and 2D in bread wheat.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>By analyzing nucleotide sequence variations of the coding region, two, six and two haplotypes were distinguished for TaGS2-A1 (a and b), TaGS2-B1 (a-f) and TaGS2-D1 (a and b), respectively.</Species>

<Species>By analyzing the frequency data of different haplotypes and their association with N use and agronomic traits, four major and favorable TaGS2 haplotypes (A1b, B1a, B1b, D1a) were revealed.</Species>
<Species>These favorable haplotypes may confer better seedling growth, better agronomic performance, and improved N uptake during vegetative growth or grain N concentration.</Species>
<Species>Our data suggest that certain TaGS2 haplotypes may be valuable in breeding wheat varieties with improved agronomic performance and N-use efficiency.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Climate, history and neutrality as drivers of mammal beta diversity in Europe: insights from multiscale deconstruction.</Species>
<Species>The organization of foraging in the fire ant, Solenopsis invicta.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although natural selection in ants acts most strongly at the colony, or superorganismal level, foraging patterns have rarely been studied at that level, focusing instead on the behavior of individual foragers or groups of foragers.</Species>

<Species>The experiments and observations in this paper reveal in broad strokes how colonies of the fire ant, Solenopsis invicta Buren (Hymenoptera: Formicidae), allocate their available labor to foraging, how they disperse that force within their territory, and how this force changes with colony size, season and worker age.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Territory area is positively related to colony size and the number of foragers, more so during the spring than fall.</Species>
<Species>Changes of colony size and territory area are driven by seasonal variation of sexual and worker production, which in turn drive seasonal variation of worker age-distribution.</Species>
<Species>During spring sexual production, colonies shrink because worker production falls below replacement.</Species>
<Species>This loss is proportional to colony size, causing forager density in the spring to be negatively related to colony and territory size.</Species>
<Species>In the fall, colonies emphasize worker production, bringing colony size back up.</Species>

<Species>However, because smaller colonies curtailed spring worker production less than larger ones, their fall forager populations are proportionally greater, causing them to gain territory at the expense of large colonies.</Species>
<Species>Much variation of territory area remains unexplained and can probably be attributed to pressure from neighboring colonies.</Species>
<Species>Boundaries between territories are characterized by "no ants' zones" mostly devoid of fire ants.</Species>
<Species>The forager population can be divided into a younger group of recruitable workers that wait for scouts to activate them to help retrieve large food finds.</Species>
<Species>About one-third of the recruits wait near openings in the foraging tunnels that underlie the entire territory, while two-thirds wait in the nest.</Species>
<Species>Recruitment to food is initially very rapid and local from the foraging tunnels, while sustained recruitment gradually involves the recruits waiting in the nest.</Species>
<Species>As recruits age, they become scouts searching for food on the surface, and die about two weeks later.</Species>
<Species>Foraging tunnels decrease in cross-sectional area with distance from the nest, in keeping with the gradual bleeding off of workers to the surface with distance.</Species>
<Species>Foragers lack route-faithfulness, and having been marked and released at one point within the territory, they can be recaptured at any other point a day later.</Species>
<Species>The size of the territory actually occupied may be limited during dry weather, resulting in very large no-ants' zones.</Species>
<Species>Regulation of nleA in Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli O84:H4 strain 4795/97.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Many Shiga toxin-producing Escherichia coli (STEC) strains express a type III secretion system (TTSS) encoded by the locus of enterocyte effacement (LEE).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Using the TTSS, STEC is able to inject effector proteins directly into eukaryotic host cells, where they cause characteristic attaching and effacing (A/E) lesions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In addition to the LEE-encoded effectors, a number of non-LEE-encoded effectors, located on phage-associated elements, have been described.</Species>
<Species>One of them, the non-LEE-encoded effector A (NleA), is widely distributed among pathogenic E. coli.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this study, we investigated the influence of environmental conditions on the expression of the phage-encoded effector nleA gene (designated nleA(4795)) present in STEC O84:H4 strain 4795/97.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We demonstrated that a particular NaCl concentration and starvation stress increase the activity of the nleA(4795) promoter.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, several regulators that control nleA(4795) expression were identified.</Species>
<Species>The involvement of the LEE regulators Ler, GrlA, and GrlR show that nleA(4795) is integrated in the LEE regulation circuit.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, the binding of Ler to sequences upstream of nleA(4795) underlined these findings.</Species>
<Species>Impact of density and environmental factors on population fluctuations in a migratory passerine.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Populations of plants and animals typically fluctuate because of the combined effects of density-dependent and density-independent processes.</Species>
<Species>The study of these processes is complicated by the fact that population sizes are typically not known exactly, because population counts are subject to sampling variance.</Species>

<Species>Although the existence of sampling variance is broadly acknowledged, relatively few studies on time-series data have accounted for it, which can result in wrong inferences about population processes.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>To increase our understanding of population dynamics, we analysed time series from six Central European populations of the migratory red-backed shrike Lanius collurio by simultaneously assessing the strength of density dependence, process and sampling variance.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In addition, we evaluated hypotheses predicting effects of factors presumed to operate on the breeding grounds, at stopover sites in eastern Africa during fall and spring migration and in the wintering grounds in southern Africa.</Species>
<Species>We used both simple and state-space formulations of the Gompertz equation to model population size.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>Across populations and modelling approaches, we found consistent evidence for negative density-dependent population regulation.</Species>
<Species>Further, process variance contributed substantially to variation in population size, while sampling variance did not.</Species>

<Species>Environmental conditions in eastern and southern Africa appear to influence breeding population size, as rainfall in the Sahel during fall migration and in the south African wintering areas were positively related to population size in the following spring in four of six populations.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, environmental conditions in the breeding grounds were not related to population size.</Species>

<Species>4. Our findings suggest negative density-dependent regulation of red-backed shrike breeding populations and are consistent with the long-standing hypothesis that conditions in the African staging and wintering areas influence population numbers of species breeding in Europe.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>

<Species>This study highlights the importance of jointly investigating density-dependent and density-independent processes to improve our understanding of factors influencing population fluctuations in space and time.</Species>
<Species>Aerosol drug delivery: developments in device design and clinical use.</Species>
<Species>B7-mediated costimulation of CD4 T cells constrains cytomegalovirus persistence.</Species>
<Species>Cytomegalovirus (CMV) utilizes multiple strategies to modulate immunity and promote lifelong, persistent/latent infection, including suppressing T cell activation pathways.</Species>
<Species>Here we examined the role of B7 costimulatory ligands in establishing immune detente from both the host and virus perspectives.</Species>
<Species>Mice lacking both B7.1 and B7.2 showed reduced early expansion of CMV-specific CD4 T cells, consequently allowing for enhanced levels of persistent virus replication.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In turn, a CMV mutant lacking expression of the m138 and m147.5 gene products, which restrict B7.1 and B7.2 expression in infected antigen-presenting cells, induced a more robust CD4 T cell response and showed decreased persistence.</Species>
<Species>Together, these data reveal a requirement for B7-mediated signaling in regulating the CMV-specific CD4 T cell response and establishing host-virus equilibrium.</Species>

text: <Species>The sensor kinase CbrA is a global regulator that modulates metabolism, virulence, and antibiotic resistance in Pseudomonas aeruginosa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Pseudomonas aeruginosa is an opportunistic pathogen that possesses a large arsenal of virulence factors enabling the pathogen to cause serious infections in immunocompromised patients, burn victims, and cystic fibrosis patients.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>CbrA is a sensor kinase that has previously been implied to play a role with its cognate response regulator CbrB in the metabolic regulation of carbon and nitrogen utilization in P. aeruginosa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here it is demonstrated that CbrA and CbrB play an important role in various virulence and virulence-related processes of the bacteria, including swarming, biofilm formation, cytotoxicity, and antibiotic resistance.</Species>

<Species>The cbrA deletion mutant was completely unable to swarm while exhibiting an increase in biofilm formation, supporting the inverse regulation of swarming and biofilm formation in P. aeruginosa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The cbrA mutant also exhibited increased cytotoxicity to human lung epithelial cells as early as 4 and 6 h postinfection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, the cbrA mutant demonstrated increased resistance toward a variety of clinically important antibiotics, including polymyxin B, ciprofloxacin, and tobramycin.</Species>

<Species>Microarray analysis revealed that under swarming conditions, CbrA regulated the expression of many genes, including phoPQ, pmrAB, arnBCADTEF, dnaK, and pvdQ, consistent with the antibiotic resistance and swarming impairment phenotypes of the cbrA mutant.</Species>

<Species>Phenotypic and real-time quantitative PCR (RT-qPCR) analyses of a PA14 cbrB mutant suggested that CbrA may be modulating swarming, biofilm formation, and cytotoxicity via CbrB and that the CrcZ small RNA is likely downstream of this two-component regulator.</Species>
<Species>However, as CbrB did not have a resistance phenotype, CbrA likely modulates antibiotic resistance in a manner independent of CbrB.</Species>
<Species>Catabolite control protein A controls hydrogen peroxide production and cell death in Streptococcus sanguinis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Streptococcus sanguinis is a commensal oral bacterium producing hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) that is dependent on pyruvate oxidase (Spx) activity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In addition to its well-known role in bacterial antagonism during interspecies competition, H2O2 causes cell death in about 10% of the S. sanguinis population.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As a consequence of H2O2-induced cell death, largely intact chromosomal DNA is released into the environment.</Species>
<Species>This extracellular DNA (eDNA) contributes to the self-aggregation phenotype under aerobic conditions.</Species>
<Species>To further investigate the regulation of spx gene expression, we assessed the role of catabolite control protein A (CcpA) in spx expression control.</Species>
<Species>We report here that CcpA represses spx expression.</Species>

<Species>An isogenic DeltaccpA mutant showed elevated spx expression, increased Spx abundance, and H2O2 production, whereas the wild type did not respond with altered spx expression in the presence of glucose and other carbohydrates.</Species>

<Species>Since H2O2 is directly involved in the release of eDNA and bacterial cell death, the presented data suggest that CcpA is a central control element in this important developmental process in S. sanguinis.</Species>

text: <Species>Priority actions for the non-communicable disease crisis.</Species>

<Species>The UN High-Level Meeting on Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) in September, 2011, is an unprecedented opportunity to create a sustained global movement against premature death and preventable morbidity and disability from NCDs, mainly heart disease, stroke, cancer, diabetes, and chronic respiratory disease.</Species>
<Species>The increasing global crisis in NCDs is a barrier to development goals including poverty reduction, health equity, economic stability, and human security.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Lancet NCD Action Group and the NCD Alliance propose five overarching priority actions for the response to the crisis--leadership, prevention, treatment, international cooperation, and monitoring and accountability--and the delivery of five priority interventions--tobacco control, salt reduction, improved diets and physical activity, reduction in hazardous alcohol intake, and essential drugs and technologies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The priority interventions were chosen for their health effects, cost-effectiveness, low costs of implementation, and political and financial feasibility.</Species>
<Species>The most urgent and immediate priority is tobacco control.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We propose as a goal for 2040, a world essentially free from tobacco where less than 5% of people use tobacco.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Implementation of the priority interventions, at an estimated global commitment of about US$9 billion per year, will bring enormous benefits to social and economic development and to the health sector.</Species>
<Species>If widely adopted, these interventions will achieve the global goal of reducing NCD death rates by 2% per year, averting tens of millions of premature deaths in this decade.</Species>
<Species>Limitation of Sludge Biotic Index application for control of a wastewater treatment plant working with shock organic and ammonium loadings.</Species>

<Species>This study aimed to determine the relationship between activated sludge microfauna, the sludge biotic index (SBI) and the effluent quality of a full-scale municipal wastewater treatment plant (WWTP) working with shock organic and ammonium loadings caused by periodic wastewater delivery from septic tanks.</Species>

<Species>Irrespective of high/low effluent quality in terms of COD, BOD(5), ammonium and suspended solids, high SBI values (8-10), which correspond to the first quality class of sludge, were observed.</Species>
<Species>High SBI values were connected with abundant taxonomic composition and the domination of crawling ciliates with shelled amoebae and attached ciliates.</Species>

<Species>High SBI values, even at a low effluent quality, limit the usefulness of the index for monitoring the status of an activated sludge system and the effluent quality in municipal WWTP-treated wastewater from septic tanks.</Species>

<Species>It was shown that a more sensitive indicator of effluent quality was a change in the abundance of attached ciliates with a narrow peristome (Vorticella infusionum and Opercularia coarctata), small flagellates and crawling ciliates (Acineria uncinata) feeding on flagellates.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Identification and characterization of the cysteine protease inhibitor gene MdCPI from Musca domestica.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cysteine proteinase inhibitors (CPIs) are involved in many vital cellular processes such as signalling pathways, apoptosis, immune response and development; however, no CPIs have yet been reported from the housefly Musca domestica.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Here we report the isolation and characterization of a housefly CPI gene designated MdCPI.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The gene contains an open reading frame of 357 bp encoding a protein of 118 amino acid residues with a putative signal peptide of 17 amino acid residues.</Species>
<Species>Protein alignment demonstrated a high homology to that of Sarcophaga crassipalpis (identity = 51%).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Phylogenetic analysis suggested that all CPIs from dipterans, including the housefly, belong to the I25A family and may be descended from a single common ancestor.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The gene was expressed in and purified from Escherichia coli.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Biochemical studies showed that MdCPI exerts an inhibiting function on papain, which is a classical assay to confirm CPIs.</Species>
<Species>Real-time quantitative PCR and immunolocalization analysis revealed that MdCPI is specifically expressed in haemocytes and fat bodies.</Species>
<Species>It is highly down-regulated in larvae and markedly up-regulated in the pupal stage, suggesting that it may be related to development.</Species>
<Species>A nuclear inhibitor of NF-kappaB encoded by a poxvirus.</Species>

<Species>Poxviruses have evolved various strategies to inhibit cytoplasmic events leading to activation of the nuclear factor kappaB (NF-kappaB) signaling pathway, with individual viruses often encoding multiple NF-kappaB inhibitors.</Species>
<Species>Here, the novel orf virus (ORFV)-encoded protein ORFV002 was shown to inhibit nuclear events regulating NF-kappaB transcriptional activity.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>ORFV002 expression in cell cultures significantly decreased wild-type-virus-, tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha)-, and lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced NF-kappaB-mediated gene expression.</Species>

<Species>Expression of ORFV002 in cells, while not affecting phosphorylation or nuclear translocation of NF-kappaB-p65, markedly decreased TNF-alpha- and wild-type-virus-induced acetylation of NF-kappaB-p65, a p300-mediated nuclear modification of NF-kappaB-p65 that regulates its transactivating activity.</Species>

<Species>ORFV002 was shown to colocalize and interact with NF-kappaB-p65, and expression of ORFV002 in cell cultures resulted in a reduced interaction of NF-kappaB-p65 with p300, suggesting that ORFV002 interferes with NF-kappaB-p65/p300 association.</Species>

<Species>Deletion of ORFV002 from the OV-IA82 genome had no significant effect on ORFV pathogenesis in sheep, indicating that ORFV002 is nonessential for virus virulence in the natural host.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This represents the first description of a nuclear inhibitor of NF-kappaB encoded by a poxvirus.</Species>

text: <Species>This paper describes a species-specific, real time polymerase chain reaction (PCR), based on unique molecular markers that were found in the G-protein-coupled chemokine receptor (GPCR) gene sequences of CaPVs, that uses dual hybridization probes for their simultaneous detection, quantitation and genotyping.</Species>
<Species>The assay can differentiate between CaPV strains based on differences in the melting point temperature (Tm) obtained after fluorescence melting curve analysis (FMCA).</Species>
<Species>It is highly sensitive and presents low intra- and inter-run variation.</Species>

<Species>This real time PCR assay will make a significant contribution to CaPV diagnosis and to the better understanding of the epidemiology of CaPVs by enabling rapid genotyping and gene-based classification of viral strains and unequivocal identification of isolates.</Species>

text: <Species>Although B. tabaci biotype B has been present in China for a relatively short period of time, it has become dominant over T. vaporariorum.</Species>
