text: <Species>Activation of the heat shock transcription factor Hsf1 is essential for the full virulence of the fungal pathogen Candida albicans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The evolutionarily conserved heat shock transcription factor Hsf1 plays a central role in thermal adaptation in the major fungal pathogen of humans, Candida albicans.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Hsf1 becomes hyperphosphorylated in response to heat shock and activates the transcription of genes with heat shock elements (HSEs) in their promoters, these genes contributing to thermal adaptation.</Species>

<Species>However, the relevance of Hsf1 activation to C. albicans virulence is not clear as this pathogen is thought to be obligately associated with warm blooded animals, and this issue has not been tested because HSF1 is essential for viability in C. albicans.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In this study, we demonstrate that the HSE regulon is active in C. albicans cells infecting the kidney.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also show the CE2 region of Hsf1 is required for activation and that the phosphorylation of specific residues in this domain contributes to Hsf1 activation.</Species>
<Species>C. albicans HSF1 mutants that lack this CE2 region are viable.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, they are unable to activate HSE-containing genes in response to heat shock, and they are thermosensitive.</Species>
<Species>Using this HSF1 CE2 deletion mutant we demonstrate that Hsf1 activation, and hence thermal adaptation, contributes significantly to the virulence of C. albicans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Function of the small hydrophobic protein of J paramyxovirus.</Species>
<Species>At 18,954 nucleotides, the J paramyxovirus (JPV) genome is one of the largest in the family Paramyxoviridae, consisting of eight genes in the order 3'-N-P/V/C-M-F-SH-TM-G-L-5'.</Species>
<Species>To study the function of novel paramyxovirus genes in JPV, a plasmid containing a full-length cDNA clone of the genome of JPV was constructed.</Species>
<Species>In this study, the function of the small hydrophobic (SH) protein of JPV was examined by generating a recombinant JPV lacking the coding sequence of the SH protein (rJPVDeltaSH).</Species>
<Species>rJPVDeltaSH was viable and had no growth defect in tissue culture cells.</Species>
<Species>However, more tumor necrosis factor alpha (TNF-alpha) was produced during rJPVDeltaSH infection, suggesting that SH plays a role in inhibiting TNF-alpha production.</Species>
<Species>rJPVDeltaSH induced more apoptosis in tissue culture cells than rJPV.</Species>
<Species>Virus-induced apoptosis was inhibited by neutralizing antibody against TNF-alpha, suggesting that TNF-alpha contributes to JPV-induced apoptosis in vitro.</Species>
<Species>The expression of JPV SH protein inhibited TNF-alpha-induced NF-kappaB activation in a reporter gene assay, suggesting that JPV SH protein can inhibit TNF-alpha signaling in vitro.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, infection of mice with rJPVDeltaSH induced more TNF-alpha expression, indicating that SH plays a role in blocking TNF-alpha expression in vivo.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Experimental evidence for emergent facilitation: promoting the existence of an invertebrate predator by killing its prey.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Recent theoretical insights have shown that predator species may help each other to persist by size-selective foraging on a shared prey.</Species>

<Species>By feeding on a certain prey stage, a predator may induce a compensatory response in another stage of the same prey species, thereby favouring other predators; a phenomenon referred to as emergent facilitation.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>To test whether emergent facilitation may occur in a natural system, we performed an enclosure experiment where we mimicked fish predation by selectively removing large zooplankton and subsequently following the response of the invertebrate predator Bythotrephes longimanus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>
<Species>Positive responses to harvest were observed in the biomass of juvenile individuals of the dominant zooplankton Holopedium gibberum and in Bythotrephes densities.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Hence, by removing large prey, we increased the biomass of small prey, i.e. stage-specific biomass overcompensation was present in the juvenile stage of Holopedium.</Species>
<Species>This favoured Bythotrephes, which preferentially feed on small Holopedium.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>We argue that the stage-specific overcompensation occurred as a result of increased per capita fecundity of adult Holopedium and as a result of competitive release following harvest.</Species>
<Species>If shown to be common, emergent facilitation may be a major mechanism behind observed predator extinctions and patterns of predator invasions.</Species>
<Species>Fungal secondary metabolites - strategies to activate silent gene clusters.</Species>
<Species>Filamentous fungi produce a multitude of low molecular weight bioactive compounds.</Species>
<Species>The increasing number of fungal genome sequences impressively demonstrated that their biosynthetic potential is far from being exploited.</Species>
<Species>In fungi, the genes required for the biosynthesis of a secondary metabolite are clustered.</Species>
<Species>Many of these bioinformatically newly discovered secondary metabolism gene clusters are silent under standard laboratory conditions.</Species>
<Species>Consequently, no product can be found.</Species>

<Species>This review summarizes the current strategies that have been successfully applied during the last years to activate these silent gene clusters in filamentous fungi, especially in the genus Aspergillus.</Species>

<Species>The techniques take advantage of genome mining, vary from the simple search for compounds with bioinformatically predicted physicochemical properties up to methods that exploit a probable interaction of microorganisms.</Species>

<Species>Until now, the majority of successful approaches have been based on molecular biology like the generation of gene "knock outs", promoter exchange, overexpression of transcription factors or other pleiotropic regulators.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, strategies based on epigenetics opened a new avenue for the elucidation of the regulation of secondary metabolite formation and will certainly continue to play a significant role for the elucidation of cryptic natural products.</Species>
<Species>The conditions under which a given gene cluster is naturally expressed are largely unknown.</Species>
<Species>One technique is to attempt to simulate the natural habitat by co-cultivation of microorganisms from the same ecosystem.</Species>
<Species>This has already led to the activation of silent gene clusters and the identification of novel compounds in Aspergillus nidulans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These simulation strategies will help discover new natural products in the future, and may also provide fundamental new insights into microbial communication.</Species>
<Species>Arabidopsis thaliana populations show clinal variation in a climatic gradient associated with altitude.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>* Understanding the adaptive basis of life history variation is a central goal in evolutionary ecology.</Species>

<Species>The use of model species enables the combination of molecular mechanistic knowledge with ecological and evolutionary questions, but the study of life history variation in natural environments is required to merge these disciplines.</Species>
<Species>* Here, we tested for clinal variation in life history and associated traits along an environmental and altitudinal gradient in the model species Arabidopsis thaliana.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Seventeen natural populations of A. thaliana were geo-referenced in north-eastern Spain on a gradient in which precipitation increases but maximum spring temperature and minimum winter temperature decrease with altitude.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>* One hundred and eighty-nine genotypes from the 17 populations were grown under uniform controlled conditions.</Species>

<Species>Variations in traits related to biomass allocation, fecundity, phenology and vegetative growth were tested for relationships with the altitude and climatic variables associated with the home sites.</Species>
<Species>Above-ground mass, number of rosette leaves at bolting, developmental time and seed weight increased with the home site's altitude.</Species>
<Species>Root allocation, vegetative growth during winter and number of seeds decreased with altitude.</Species>
<Species>* We suggest that the differences among home sites provide clues to the variation in adaptive strategies associated with the climatic gradient.</Species>
<Species>We compared these results with adaptations and clinal relationships reported for other species and with molecular mechanisms described in Arabidopsis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Comparison of transgene expression in Aedes aegypti generated by mariner Mos1 transposition and PhiC31 site-directed recombination.</Species>

text: <Species>Transgenic mosquitoes generated by transposable elements (TEs) often poorly express transgenes owing to position effects.</Species>
<Species>To avoid these effects, the PhiC31 site-directed recombination system was used to insert transgenes into a locus favourable for gene expression in Aedes aegypti.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We describe phenotypes of mariner Mos1 TE and PhiC31 transgenic mosquitoes expressing the enhanced green fluorescent protein (EGFP) reporter in midguts of blood-fed females.</Species>

<Species>Mosquitoes of nine TE-generated lines [estimated transformation frequency (TF): 9.3%] clearly expressed the eye-specific selection marker but only 2/9 lines robustly expressed the EGFP reporter.</Species>
<Species>The piggyBac TE-generated PhiC31 docking strain, attP26, supported recombination with attB site containing donors at an estimated TF of 1.7-4.9%.</Species>
<Species>Using a codon-optimized PhiC31 integrase mutant instead of the 'wild-type' enzyme did not affect TF.</Species>
<Species>Site-directed recombination of line attP26 with an attB-containing donor expressing EGFP from the Ae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>aegypti carboxypeptidase promoter produced one transgenic line with blood-fed females expressing the reporter in midgut tissue.</Species>
<Species>Docking strain attP26 also supported robust expression of Flock House virus B2 from the Ae.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>aegypti polyubiquitin promoter.</Species>

<Species>Our data confirm that eye-specific selection marker expression alone is not a reliable indicator for robust gene-of-interest expression in Ae. aegypti and that the PhiC31 system can ensure predictable transgene expression in this mosquito species.</Species>

text: <Species>Staphylococcus aureus ClpC divergently regulates capsule via sae and codY in strain newman but activates capsule via codY in strain UAMS-1 and in strain Newman with repaired saeS.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>ClpC is an ATPase chaperone found in most Gram-positive low-GC bacteria.</Species>
<Species>It has been recently reported that ClpC affected virulence gene expression in Staphylococcus aureus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here we report that ClpC regulates transcription of the cap operon and accumulation of capsule, a major virulence factor for S. aureus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As virulence genes are regulated by a complex regulatory network in S. aureus, we have used capsule as a model to understand this regulation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>By microarray analyses of strain Newman, we found that ClpC strongly activates transcription of the sae operon, whose products are known to negatively regulate capsule synthesis in this strain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Further studies indicated that ClpC repressed capsule production by activating the sae operon in strain Newman.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Interestingly, the clpC gene cloned into a multiple-copy plasmid vector exhibited an activation phenotype, suggesting that ClpC overexpression has a net positive effect.</Species>
<Species>In the absence of sae function, by either deletion or correction of a native mutation within saeS, we found that ClpC had a positive effect on capsule production.</Species>
<Species>Indeed, in the UAMS-1 strain, which does not have the saeS mutation, ClpC functioned as an activator of capsule production.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our microarray analyses of strain Newman also revealed that CodY, a repressor of capsule production, was repressed by ClpC. Using genetic approaches, we showed that CodY functioned downstream of ClpC, leading to capsule activation both in Newman and in UAMS-1.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Thus, ClpC functions in two opposite pathways in capsule regulation in strain Newman but functions as a positive activator in strain UAMS-1.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Dominant inhibition of Akt/protein kinase B signaling by the matrix protein of a negative-strand RNA virus.</Species>
<Species>Vesicular stomatitis virus (VSV) is a rhabdovirus that alters host nuclear and cytoplasmic function upon infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We have investigated the effect of VSV infection on cellular signaling through the phosphatidylinositol-3 kinase (PI3k)/Akt signaling pathway.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Akt phosphorylation at both threonine 308 (Thr308) and serine 473 (Ser473) was inhibited in cells infected with VSV.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This inhibition was rapid (beginning within the first 2 to 3 h postinfection) and correlated with the dephosphorylation of downstream effectors of Akt, such as glycogen synthase kinase</Species>
<Species>3Beta (GSK3Beta) and mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR).</Species>

<Species>The dephosphorylation of Akt occurred in the presence of growth factor stimulation and was not overcome through constitutive membrane targeting of Akt or high levels of phosphatidylinositol-3,4,5-triphosphate (PIP3) accumulation in the membrane.</Species>

<Species>Akt dephosphorylation was not a result of alterations in PDK1 phosphorylation or activity, changes in phosphatase and tensin homologue deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN) levels, or the downregulation of PI3k signaling.</Species>

<Species>Inactivation of Akt was caused by the expression of the viral M protein in the absence of other viral components, and an M protein mutant that does not inhibit RNA polymerase II (Pol II) transcription and nuclear/cytoplasmic transport was also defective in inhibiting Akt phosphorylation.</Species>
<Species>These data illustrate that VSV utilizes a novel mechanism to alter this central player in cell signaling and oncogenesis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It also suggests an inside-out model of signal transduction where VSV interruption of nuclear events has a rapid and significant effect on membrane signaling events.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Long-term outcomes of patients with aneurysmal subarachnoid haemorrhage.</Species>
<Species>Role of nitric oxide in hydrogen peroxide-dependent induction of abiotic stress tolerance by brassinosteroids in cucumber.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Brassinosteroids (BRs) can induce plant tolerance to a variety of abiotic stresses by triggering the generation of H(2) O(2) as a signalling molecule in cucumber leaves.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Whether nitric oxide (NO) also plays a signalling role and, if so, what is the relationship between NO and H(2) O(2) in BR-induced stress tolerance are unknown.</Species>
<Species>Involvement of NO and H(2) O(2) in BR-induced tolerance was examined.</Species>
<Species>NO accumulation and defence related gene transcripts were monitored by confocal laser-scanning microscopy and qRT-PCR, respectively.</Species>
<Species>NO content was elevated after treatment with 24-epibrassinolide (EBR) and reduced with the inhibition of BR biosynthesis.</Species>
<Species>EBR-induced NO production was blocked by pre-treatment with inhibitor of NADPH oxidase and a reactive oxygen species scavenger.</Species>
<Species>On the other hand, EBR-induced H(2) O(2) generation was not sensitive to NO scavenger or inhibitor of NO production.</Species>

<Species>Scavenging or inhibition of NO production inhibited EBR-induced tolerance to photo-oxidative and cold stress and partly blocked EBR-induced expression and activities of several antioxidant enzymes.</Species>
<Species>Pre-treatment of the exogenous NO precursor, on the other hand, led to both increased stress tolerance and increased expression of antioxidant enzymes.</Species>
<Species>These results strongly suggest that NO plays an important role in H(2) O(2) -dependent induction of plant stress tolerance by BR.</Species>

<Species>Phylogenetic validation of the genera Angomonas and Strigomonas of trypanosomatids harboring bacterial endosymbionts with the description of new species of trypanosomatids and of proteobacterial symbionts.</Species>

<Species>We comparatively examined the nutritional, molecular and optical and electron microscopical characteristics of reference species and new isolates of trypanosomatids harboring bacterial endosymbionts.</Species>
<Species>Sequencing of the V7V8 region of the small subunit of the ribosomal RNA (SSU rRNA) gene distinguished six major genotypes among the 13 isolates examined.</Species>
<Species>The entire sequences of the SSU rRNA and glycosomal glyceraldehyde phosphate dehydrogenase (gGAPDH) genes were obtained for phylogenetic analyses.</Species>

<Species>In the resulting phylogenetic trees, the symbiont-harboring species clustered as a major clade comprising two subclades that corresponded to the proposed genera Angomonas and Strigomonas.</Species>
<Species>The genus Angomonas comprised 10 flagellates including former Crithidia deanei and C. desouzai plus a new species.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The genus Strigomonas included former Crithidia oncopelti and Blastocrithidia culicis plus a new species.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Sequences from the internal transcribed spacer of ribosomal DNA (ITS rDNA) and size polymorphism of kinetoplast DNA (kDNA) minicircles revealed considerable genetic heterogeneity within the genera Angomonas and Strigomonas.</Species>
<Species>Phylogenetic analyses based on 16S rDNA and ITS rDNA sequences demonstrated that all of the endosymbionts belonged to the Betaproteobacteria and revealed three new species.</Species>
<Species>The congruence of the phylogenetic trees of trypanosomatids and their symbionts support a co-divergent host-symbiont evolutionary history.</Species>
<Species>Cryptogein, a fungal elicitor, remodels the phenylpropanoid metabolism of tobacco cell suspension cultures in a calcium-dependent manner.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Plant cells use calcium-based signalling pathways to transduce biotic and/or abiotic stimuli into adaptive responses.</Species>
<Species>However, little is known about the coupling between calcium signalling, transcriptional regulation and the downstream biochemical processes.</Species>

<Species>To understand these relationships better, we challenged tobacco BY-2 cells with cryptogein and evaluated how calcium transients (monitored through the calcium sensor aequorin) impact (1) transcript levels of phenylpropanoid genes (assessed by RT-qPCR); and (2) derived-phenolic compounds (analysed by mass spectrometry).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Most genes of the phenylpropanoid pathway were up-regulated by cryptogein and cell wall-bound phenolic compounds accumulated (mainly 5-hydroxyferulic acid).</Species>
<Species>The accumulation of both transcripts and phenolics was calcium-dependent.</Species>

<Species>The transcriptional regulation of phenylpropanoid genes was correlated in a non-linear manner with stimulus intensity and with components of the cryptogein-induced calcium signature.</Species>
<Species>In addition, calmodulin inhibitors increased the sensitivity of cells to low concentrations of cryptogein.</Species>

<Species>These results led us to propose a model of coupling between the cryptogein signal, calcium signalling and the transcriptional response, exerting control of transcription through the coordinated action of two decoding modules exerting opposite effects.</Species>
<Species>Fluorescent proteins illuminate the structure and function of the hyphal tip apparatus.</Species>
<Species>Fungal hyphae show extreme polarized growth at the tip.</Species>
<Species>Electron microscope studies have revealed a apical body called the Spitzenkorper that is thought to drive polarized growth.</Species>
<Species>Studies of polarized growth in S. cerevisiae have identified the protein components of the polarized growth machinery, that are conserved in other fungi.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Fusion of these proteins to GFP and its variants has for the first time allowed the localization of these proteins in real time to the hyphal tip without the need for drastic fixation procedures.</Species>

<Species>Such studies showed that vesicle-associated proteins localize to the Spitzenkorper and identified a second compartment located at the tip surface composed of exocyst and other proteins that mediate the fusion of secretory vesicles with the plasma membrane.</Species>
<Species>Individual differences in reproductive costs examined using multi-state methods.</Species>
<Species>1. Trade-offs among life-history traits are common because individuals have to partition limited resources between multiple traits.</Species>
<Species>Reproductive costs are generally assumed to be high, resulting in reduced survival and fecundity in the following year.</Species>
<Species>However, it is common to find positive rather than negative correlations between life-history traits.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Here, we use a data set from the individual-based study of red deer on the Isle of Rum to examine how these costs vary between individuals and at different ages, using multi-state mark-recapture methodology.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Females that had reproduced frequently in the past incurred lower costs of reproduction in terms of survival in the following year and were more likely to reproduce in two consecutive years.</Species>
<Species>Older individuals and those that had not reproduced frequently exhibited higher costs.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>These results highlight the importance of considering heterogeneity and individual quality when examining trade-offs and demonstrate the effectiveness of using detailed long-term data sets to explore life-history strategies using multi-state mark-recapture models.</Species>
<Species>Development Time and Body Size in Eupolyphaga sinensis Along a Latitudinal Gradient From China.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The responses of organisms to temperature variations may be via short term responses of the phenotype (phenotypic plasticity), or they could involve long-term evolutionary change and adaptation (via selection) to the genotype.</Species>
<Species>These could involve changes to the mean size of the animal or to the thermal reaction norm.</Species>

<Species>We examined the effects of various temperatures (of 22, 25, 28, and 31^0C) on development time, adult body size and preadult survivorship in three populations of the cockroach, Eupolyphaga sinensis (Walker), collected at different latitudes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found substantial temperature-induced plasticity in development time, body size, and preadult survivorship, indicating that developmental temperatures have strong impacts on growth and life history traits of E. sinensis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Genetic differences for development time, body size, and preadult survivorship were detected among populations, and the three traits exhibited highly significant variations in the responses of different populations to various temperature conditions, indicating genetic differences among populations in terms of thermal reaction norms.</Species>
<Species>We also found that two populations seem to support the beneficial acclimation hypothesis whereas the third mid-latitude population does not.</Species>

<Species>The results are likely because of differences in season length and voltinism, indicating that not only temperature regime but also its interactions with generation time (and development time), voltinism, and season length are likely to have considerable effects on insect development time and body size.</Species>
<Species>Overall, changes in development time, body size, and preadult survivorship in E. sinensis can all be regarded as adaptations to changing thermal regimes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Three motAB stator gene products in Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus contribute to motility of a single flagellum during predatory and prey-independent growth.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The predatory bacterium Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus uses flagellar motility to locate regions rich in Gram-negative prey bacteria, colliding and attaching to prey and then ceasing flagellar motility.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Prey are then invaded to form a "bdelloplast" in a type IV pilus-dependent process, and prey contents are digested, allowing Bdellovibrio growth and septation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>After septation, Bdellovibrio flagellar motility resumes inside the prey bdelloplast prior to its lysis and escape of Bdellovibrio progeny.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Bdellovibrio can also grow slowly outside prey as long flagellate host-independent (HI) cells, cultured on peptone-rich media.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The B. bacteriovorus HD100 genome encodes three pairs of MotAB flagellar motor proteins, each of which could potentially form an inner membrane ion channel, interact with the FliG flagellar rotor ring, and produce flagellar rotation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In 2004, Flannagan and coworkers (R. S. Flannagan, M. A. Valvano, and S. F. Koval, Microbiology 150:649-656, 2004) used antisense RNA and green fluorescent protein (GFP) expression to downregulate a single Bdellovibrio motA gene and reported slowed release from the bdelloplast and altered motility of the progeny.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here we inactivated each pair of motAB genes and found that each pair contributes to motility, both predatorily, inside the bdelloplast and during HI growth; however, each pair was dispensable, and deletion of no pair abolished motility totally.</Species>

<Species>Driving-ion studies with phenamil, carbonyl cyanide m-chlorophenylhydrazone (CCCP), and different pH and sodium conditions indicated that all Mot pairs are proton driven, although the sequence similarities of each Mot pair suggests that some may originate from halophilic species.</Species>
<Species>Thus, Bdellovibrio is a "dedicated motorist," retaining and expressing three pairs of mot genes.</Species>

text: <Species>Maternal influence on philopatry and space use by juvenile brushtail possums (Trichosurus vulpecula).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>
<Species>The causes of juvenile sex-biased philopatry and space use in mammals remain poorly understood, and results of previous research have been conflicting.</Species>
<Species>Experimental interventions and manipulations on wild populations are rare, but can play an important role in establishing the factors governing offspring space use.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>We experimentally removed mothers of independent juvenile brushtail possums from the maternal home range and examined changes in offspring space use with global positioning system collars.</Species>
<Species>We examined the influence of mother absence on philopatric behaviour, and determined whether or not maternal presence affected offspring space use.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We fitted a longitudinal linear mixed effects model to demonstrate a change over time in the home range size of juveniles following experimental treatment by the removal of their mothers.</Species>

<Species>When mothers were removed from the natal range, juveniles occupied significantly larger home range areas, with average increases of 175% in 95% kernel density estimates and 289% in minimum convex polygon estimates.</Species>
<Species>This increase occurred within the first month following mother absence and was independent of juvenile sex.</Species>
<Species>Home ranges of control juveniles did not change during the same time period.</Species>
<Species>4. Changes in the spatial structure of mammalian populations in response to removal of individuals have important implications for pest management.</Species>
<Species>The impacts of management strategies which target particular individuals in a population may counteract conservation benefits through their effect on the space use of survivors.</Species>

<Species>Studies involving experimental removals provide important information on consequences of control and also yield insights into the causes of mammalian space use, philopatric behaviours and ultimately dispersal.</Species>

text: <Species>Predicting diet and consumption rate differences between and within species using gut ecomorphology.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Rapid environmental changes and pressing human needs to forecast the consequences of environmental change are increasingly driving ecology to become a predictive science.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The need for effective prediction requires both the development of new tools and the refocusing of existing tools that may have previously been used primarily for purposes other than prediction.</Species>

<Species>One such tool that historically has been more descriptive in nature is ecomorphology (the study of relationships between ecological roles and morphological adaptations of species and individuals).</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Here, we examine relationships between diet and gut morphology for 15 species of brachyuran crabs, a group of pervasive and highly successful consumers for which trophic predictions would be highly valuable.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We show that patterns in crab stomach volume closely match some predictions of metabolic theory and demonstrate that individual diet differences and associated morphological variation reflect, at least in some instances, individual choice or diet specialization.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We then present examples of how stomach volume can be used to predict both the per cent herbivory of brachyuran crabs and the relative consumption rates of individual crabs.</Species>
<Species>Continuing challenge of infectious diseases in India.</Species>
<Species>In India, the range and burden of infectious diseases are enormous.</Species>
<Species>The administrative responsibilities of the health system are shared between the central (federal) and state governments.</Species>
<Species>Control of diseases and outbreaks is the responsibility of the central Ministry of Health, which lacks a formal public health department for this purpose.</Species>

<Species>Tuberculosis, malaria, filariasis, visceral leishmaniasis, leprosy, HIV infection, and childhood cluster of vaccine-preventable diseases are given priority for control through centrally managed vertical programmes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Control of HIV infection and leprosy, but not of tuberculosis, seems to be on track.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Early success of malaria control was not sustained, and visceral leishmaniasis prevalence has increased.</Species>
<Species>Inadequate containment of the vector has resulted in recurrent outbreaks of dengue fever and re-emergence of Chikungunya virus disease and typhus fever.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Other infectious diseases caused by faecally transmitted pathogens (enteric fevers, cholera, hepatitis A and E viruses) and zoonoses (rabies, leptospirosis, anthrax) are not in the process of being systematically controlled.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Big gaps in the surveillance and response system for infectious diseases need to be addressed.</Species>
<Species>Replication of the model of vertical single-disease control for all infectious diseases will not be efficient or viable.</Species>
<Species>India needs to rethink and revise its health policy to broaden the agenda of disease control.</Species>
<Species>A comprehensive review and redesign of the health system is needed urgently to ensure equity and quality in health care.</Species>

<Species>We recommend the creation of a functional public health infrastructure that is shared between central and state governments, with professional leadership and a formally trained public health cadre of personnel who manage an integrated control mechanism of diseases in districts that includes infectious and non-infectious diseases, and injuries.</Species>

<Species>Accelerometry estimates field metabolic rate in giant Australian cuttlefish Sepia apama during breeding.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>1. Estimating the metabolic rate of animals in nature is central to understanding the physiological, behavioural and evolutionary ecology of animals.</Species>
<Species>Doubly labelled water and heart-rate methods are the most commonly used approaches, but both have limitations that preclude their application to some systems.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>Accelerometry has emerged as a powerful tool for estimating energy expenditure in a range of animals, but is yet to be used to estimate field metabolic rate in aquatic taxa.</Species>
<Species>We combined two-dimensional accelerometry and swim-tunnel respirometry to estimate patterns of energy expenditure in giant Australian cuttlefish Sepia apama during breeding.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Both oxygen consumption rate (Vo2) and swimming speed showed strong positive associations with body acceleration, with coefficients of determination comparable to those using similar accelerometers on terrestrial vertebrates.</Species>
<Species>Despite increased activity during the day, field metabolic rate rarely approached Vo2, and night-time Vo2 was similar to that at rest.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>These results are consistent with the life-history strategy of this species, which has a poor capacity to exercise anaerobically, and a mating strategy that is visually based.</Species>

<Species>With the logistical difficulties associated with observation in aquatic environments, accelerometry is likely to prove a valuable tool for estimating energy expenditure in aquatic animals.</Species>
<Species>Host characteristics and environmental factors differentially drive the burden and pathogenicity of an ectoparasite: a multilevel causal analysis.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Understanding the ecological factors driving the burden and pathogenicity of parasites is challenging.</Species>

<Species>Indeed, the dynamics of host-parasite interactions is driven by factors organized across nested hierarchical levels (e.g. hosts, localities), and indirect effects are expected owing to interactions between levels.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>In this study, we combined Bayesian multilevel models, path analyses and a model selection procedure to account for these complexities and to decipher the relative effects of host- and environment-related factors on the burden and the pathogenicity of an ectoparasite (Tracheliastes polycolpus) on its fish host (Leuciscus leuciscus).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also tested the year-to-year consistency of the relationships linking these factors to the burden and the pathogenic effects of T. polycolpus.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We found significant relationships between the parasite burden and host-related factors: body length and age were positively related to parasite burden and heterozygous hosts displayed a higher parasite burden.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, both host- and environment-related factors were linked to pathogenic effects.</Species>

<Species>Pathogenicity was correlated negatively with host body length and positively with age; this illustrates that some factors (e.g. body length) showed inverse relationships with parasite burden and pathogenicity.</Species>
<Species>Pathogenic effects were stronger in cooler upstream sites and where host density was lower.</Species>

<Species>Path analyses revealed that these relationships between environment-related factors and pathogenic effects were direct and were not indirect relationships mediated by the host characteristics.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we found that the strength and the shape of certain relationships were consistent across years, while they were clearly not for some others.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Our study illustrates that considering conjointly causal relationships among factors and the hierarchical structure of host-parasite interactions is appropriate for dissecting the complex links between hosts, parasites and their common environment.</Species>
<Species>PB2 residue 158 is a pathogenic determinant of pandemic H1N1 and H5 influenza a viruses in mice.</Species>

Species
Species

text: <Species>Influenza A viruses are human and animal pathogens that cause morbidity and mortality, which range from mild to severe.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The 2009 H1N1 pandemic was caused by the emergence of a reassortant H1N1 subtype (H1N1pdm) influenza A virus containing gene segments that originally circulated in human, avian, and swine virus reservoirs.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The molecular determinants of replication and pathogenesis of H1N1pdm viruses in humans and other mammals are poorly understood.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Therefore, we set out to elucidate viral determinants critical to the pathogenesis of this novel reassortant using a mouse model.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that a glutamate-to-glycine substitution at residue 158 of the PB2 gene (PB2-E158G) increased the morbidity and mortality of the parental H1N1pdm virus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Results from mini-genome replication assays in human cells and virus titration in mouse tissues demonstrated that PB2-E158G is a pathogenic determinant, because it significantly increases viral replication rates.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The virus load in PB2-E158G-infected mouse lungs was 1,300-fold higher than that of the wild-type virus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our data also show that PB2-E158G had a much stronger influence on the RNA replication and pathogenesis of H1N1pdm viruses than PB2-E627K, which is a known pathogenic determinant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Remarkably, PB2-E158G substitutions also altered the pathotypes of two avian H5 viruses in mice, indicating that this residue impacts genetically divergent influenza A viruses and suggesting that this region of PB2 could be a new antiviral target.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Collectively, the data presented in this study demonstrate that PB2-E158G is a novel pathogenic determinant of influenza A viruses in the mouse model.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We speculate that PB2-E158G may be important in the adaptation of avian PB2 genes to other mammals, and BLAST sequence analysis identified a naturally occurring human H1N1pdm isolate that has this substitution.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Therefore, future surveillance efforts should include scrutiny of this region of PB2 because of its potential impact on pathogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Identification of a mastigoneme protein from Phytophthora nicotianae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Tripartite tubular hairs (mastigonemes) on the anterior flagellum of protists in the stramenopile taxon are responsible for reversing the thrust of flagellar beat and for cell motility.</Species>

<Species>Immunoprecipitation experiments using antibodies directed towards mastigonemes on the flagella of zoospores of Phytophthora nicotianae have facilitated the cloning of a gene encoding a mastigoneme shaft protein in this Oomycete.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Expression of the gene, designated PnMas2, is up-regulated during asexual sporulation, a period during which many zoospore components are synthesized.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of the sequence of the PnMas2 protein has revealed that, like other stramenopile mastigoneme proteins, PnMas2 has an N-terminal secretion signal and contains four cysteine-rich epidermal growth factor (EGF)-like domains.</Species>
<Species>Evidence from non-denaturing gels indicates that PnMas2 forms large oligomeric complexes, most likely through disulphide bridging.</Species>
<Species>Bioinformatic analysis has revealed that Phytophthora species typically contain three or four putative mastigoneme proteins containing the four EGF-like domains.</Species>

<Species>These proteins are similar in sequence to mastigoneme proteins in other stramenopile protists including the algae Ochromonas danica, Aureococcus anophagefferens and Scytosiphon lomentaria and the diatoms Thalassiosira pseudonana and T. weissflogii.</Species>

text: <Species>Modifications in the polymerase genes of a swine-like triple-reassortant influenza virus to generate live attenuated vaccines against 2009 pandemic H1N1 viruses.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>On 11 June 2009, the World Health Organization (WHO) declared that the outbreaks caused by novel swine-origin influenza A (H1N1) virus had reached pandemic proportions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The pandemic H1N1 (H1N1pdm) virus is the predominant influenza virus strain in the human population.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>It has also crossed the species barriers and infected turkeys and swine in several countries.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, the development of a vaccine that is effective in multiple animal species is urgently needed.</Species>

<Species>We have previously demonstrated that the introduction of temperature-sensitive mutations into the PB2 and PB1 genes of an avian H9N2 virus, combined with the insertion of a hemagglutinin (HA) tag in PB1, resulted in an attenuated (att) vaccine backbone for both chickens and mice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Because the new pandemic strain is a triple-reassortant (TR) virus, we chose to introduce the double attenuating modifications into a swine-like TR virus isolate, A/turkey/OH/313053/04 (H3N2) (ty/04), with the goal of producing live attenuated influenza vaccines (LAIV).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This genetically modified backbone had impaired polymerase activity and restricted virus growth at elevated temperatures.</Species>

<Species>In vivo characterization of two H1N1 vaccine candidates generated using the ty/04 att backbone demonstrated that this vaccine is highly attenuated in mice, as indicated by the absence of signs of disease, limited replication, and minimum histopathological alterations in the respiratory tract.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A single immunization with the ty/04 att-based vaccines conferred complete protection against a lethal H1N1pdm virus infection in mice.</Species>

<Species>More importantly, vaccination of pigs with a ty/04 att-H1N1 vaccine candidate resulted in sterilizing immunity upon an aggressive intratracheal challenge with the 2009 H1N1 pandemic virus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Our studies highlight the safety of the ty/04 att vaccine platform and its potential as a master donor strain for the generation of live attenuated vaccines for humans and livestock.</Species>

text: <Species>Adaptive trade-offs in juvenile salmonid metabolism associated with habitat partitioning between coho salmon and steelhead trout in coastal streams.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Adaptive trade-offs are fundamental to the evolution of diversity and the coexistence of similar taxa and occur when complimentary combinations of traits maximize efficiency of resource exploitation or survival at different points on environmental gradients.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Standard metabolic rate (SMR) is a key physiological trait that reflects adaptations to baseline metabolic performance, whereas active metabolism reflects adaptations to variable metabolic output associated with performance related to foraging, predator avoidance, aggressive interactions or migratory movements.</Species>

<Species>Benefits of high SMR and active metabolism may change along a resource (productivity) gradient, indicating that a trade-off exists among active metabolism, resting metabolism and energy intake.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We measured and compared SMR, maximal metabolic rate (MMR), aerobic scope (AS), swim performance (UCrit) and growth of juvenile hatchery and wild steelhead and coho salmon held on high- and low-food rations in order to better understand the potential significance of variation in SMR to growth, differentiation between species, and patterns of habitat use along a productivity gradient.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We found that differences in SMR, MMR, AS, swim performance and growth rate between steelhead trout and coho salmon were reduced in hatchery-reared fish compared with wild fish.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Wild steelhead had a higher MMR, AS, swim performance and growth rate than wild coho, but adaptations between species do not appear to involve differences in SMR or to trade-off increased growth rate against lower swim performance, as commonly observed for high-growth strains.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Instead, we hypothesize that wild steelhead may be trading off higher growth rate for lower food consumption efficiency, similar to strategies adopted by anadromous vs. resident brook trout and Atlantic salmon vs. brook trout.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>This highlights potential differences in food consumption and digestion strategies as cryptic adaptations ecologically differentiating salmonid species.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>We hypothesize that divergent digestive strategies, which are common and well documented among terrestrial vertebrates, may be an important but overlooked aspect of adaptive strategies of juvenile salmonids, and fish in general.</Species>
<Species>Molecular events of apical bud formation in white spruce, Picea glauca.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Bud formation is an adaptive trait that temperate forest trees have acquired to facilitate seasonal synchronization.</Species>

<Species>We have characterized transcriptome-level changes that occur during bud formation of white spruce [Picea glauca (Moench) Voss], a primarily determinate species in which preformed stem units contained within the apical bud constitute most of next season's growth.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Microarray analysis identified 4460 differentially expressed sequences in shoot tips during short day-induced bud formation.</Species>

<Species>Cluster analysis revealed distinct temporal patterns of expression, and functional classification of genes in these clusters implied molecular processes that coincide with anatomical changes occurring in the developing bud.</Species>

<Species>Comparing expression profiles in developing buds under long day and short day conditions identified possible photoperiod-responsive genes that may not be essential for bud development.</Species>

<Species>Several genes putatively associated with hormone signalling were identified, and hormone quantification revealed distinct profiles for abscisic acid (ABA), cytokinins, auxin and their metabolites that can be related to morphological changes to the bud.</Species>

<Species>Comparison of gene expression profiles during bud formation in different tissues revealed 108 genes that are differentially expressed only in developing buds and show greater transcript abundance in developing buds than other tissues.</Species>
<Species>These findings provide a temporal roadmap of bud formation in white spruce.</Species>

text: <Species>Multiple environmental gradients affect spatial variation in the productivity of a tropical bird population.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Spatial variation in habitat quality and its demographic consequences have important implications for the regulation of animal populations.</Species>

<Species>Theoretically, habitat quality is typically viewed as a single gradient from 'poor' to 'good', but in wild populations it is possible that there are multiple environmental gradients that determine spatial variation in demography.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Understanding environmental gradients is important to gain mechanistic insights into important population processes, but also to understand how populations might respond to environmental change.</Species>
<Species>Here, we explore habitat and elevation gradients and their implications for population persistence using detailed long-term data on 600 individuals of the Mauritius kestrel.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These data allow us to statistically separate spatial variation in demography from variation arising out of individual or environmental quality and explore its relationships with habitat and topography.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>Birds that breed earlier in the season have higher reproductive success, and we found that the timing of breeding varies significantly between territories.</Species>
<Species>This variation is primarily driven by elevation, with birds breeding progressively later as elevation increases.</Species>
<Species>4. Pre-fledging survival from the egg to fledgling stage (independently of timing), and recruitment, also varied significantly between territories.</Species>
<Species>This variation is driven by the habitat surrounding breeding sites with increasing agricultural encroachment causing survival and recruitment to decline.</Species>

<Species>5. Taken together, our results suggest that there are likely to be multiple environmental gradients affecting spatial variation in productivity in wild populations, and hence multiple and different routes through which environmental change might have consequences for population dynamics by modifying spatial processes.</Species>
<Species>Hydraulic constraints limit height growth in trees at high altitude.</Species>
<Species>* Low temperatures limit the fixation of photosynthates and xylogenesis.</Species>
<Species>Here, we hypothesized that reduced longitudinal growth in trees at high altitude is related to the lower hydraulic efficiency of the transport system.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Apical buds of Norway spruce (Picea abies) trees at high and low elevation were heated during 2006 and 2007.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>At the end of the experiment, trees were felled.</Species>
<Species>Longitudinal increments and tracheid lumen areas were measured along the stem.</Species>
<Species>Apical hydraulic conductivity (k) was estimated from anatomical data.</Species>

<Species>* Before heating, high-altitude trees showed fewer (P = 0.002) and smaller (P = 0.008) apical conduits, and therefore reduced k (P = 0.016) and stem elongation (P < 0.0001), in comparison with trees at low elevation.</Species>
<Species>After 2 yr of heating, k increased at both high (P = 0.014) and low (P = 0.047) elevation.</Species>
<Species>Only high-altitude trees showed increased stem elongation, which reached the same magnitude as that of controls at low elevation (P = 0.735).</Species>

<Species>Trees at high altitude are therefore prevented from building up an efficient transport system, and their reduced longitudinal growth reflects strong hydraulic limitations.</Species>

text: <Species>The sycamore lace bug, Corythucha ciliata (Say) (Hemiptera: Tingidae), is an important invasive exotic pest of Platanus (Proteales: Platanaceae) trees in China.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The objective of this study was to determine the effects of temperature on C. ciliata in the laboratory so that forecasting models based on heat accumulation units could be developed for the pest.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Development and fecundity of C. ciliata reared on leaves of London plane tree (Platanus x acerifolia) were investigated at seven constant temperatures (16, 19, 22, 26, 30, 33, and 36^0 C) and at a relative humidity of 80% with a photoperiod of 14:10 (L:D).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The developmental time was found to significantly decrease with increasing temperature.</Species>
<Species>The developmental time from egg hatching to adult emergence was respectively 47.6, 35.0, 24.1, 20.0, and 17.1 days at the temperatures of 19, 22, 26, 30, and 33^0</Species>

<Species>C. C. ciliata could not complete full development at 16^0 and 36^0 C. The developmental threshold temperature (C) estimated for egg-to-adult was 11.17^0 C, with a thermal constant of (K) 370.57 degree-days.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Longevity of females was found to be the shortest, 17.7 days at 33^0 C and the longest, 58.9 days at 16^0 C, and that of males was the shortest, 19.7 days at 33^0 C and the longest, 59.7 days at 16^0 C. Fecundity was the highest at 30^0 C, being 286.8 eggs per female over an oviposition period of 8.9 days.</Species>
<Species>Female lifetime fecundity was reduced at other temperatures, being the lowest (87.7 eggs per female) at 19^0 C.</Species>

<Species>The population trend index (I) of C. ciliata was the highest (130.1) at 30^0 C and the lowest (24.9) at 19^0 C. Therefore, the optimal developmental temperature for C. ciliata was determined to be 30^0 C.</Species>

<Species>FungiFun is the first tool offering gene set enrichment analysis including the FunCat categorization.</Species>

<Species>Blood myeloid dendritic cells from HIV-1-infected individuals display a proapoptotic profile characterized by decreased Bcl-2 levels and by caspase-3+ frequencies that are associated with levels of plasma viremia and T cell activation in an exploratory study.</Species>

text: <Species>Reduced frequencies of myeloid and plasmacytoid dendritic cell (DC) subsets (mDCs and pDCs, respectively) have been observed in the peripheral blood of HIV-1-infected individuals throughout the course of disease.</Species>

text: <Species>Accumulation of DCs in lymph nodes (LNs) may partly account for the decreased numbers observed in blood, but increased DC death may also be a contributing factor.</Species>
<Species>We used multiparameter flow cytometry to evaluate pro- and antiapoptotic markers in blood mDCs</Species>
<Species>and pDCs from untreated HIV-1-infected donors, from a subset of infected donors before and after receiving antiretroviral therapy (ART), and from uninfected control donors.</Species>
label: Species

label: Species

text: <Species>A subset of HIV-1-infected donors had elevated frequencies of proapoptotic caspase-3(+) blood mDCs, and positive correlations were observed between caspase-3(+) mDC frequencies and plasma viral load and CD8(+) T-cell activation levels.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Caspase-3(+) mDC frequencies, but not mDC Bcl-2 expression, were reduced with viral suppression on ART.</Species>

text: <Species>LN mDCs displayed higher levels of Bcl-2 and lower caspase-3(+) frequencies than did matched blood mDCs.</Species>
<Species>Conversely, LN pDCs expressed lower Bcl-2 levels than their blood counterparts.</Species>

<Species>In summary, blood mDCs from untreated HIV-1-infected subjects displayed a proapoptotic profile that was partially reversed with viral suppression, suggesting that DC death may be a factor contributing to blood DC depletion in the setting of chronic, untreated HIV disease.</Species>

text: <Species>We accurately monitored movements of 149 juveniles during a settlement and breeding period of 3 months.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>The litter size treatment had long-lasting effects on body size, life-history traits and home range size, but did not influence dispersal behaviour.</Species>
<Species>4. Different stages of dispersal were influenced by habitat quality.</Species>

<Species>In low-quality patches, females dispersed earlier, spent more time prospecting their environment before settling, and settlers had a smaller adult body size than in high-quality patches.</Species>
<Species>Preference and competition for high-quality patches is likely adaptive as it increased fitness both in terms of survival and reproduction.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>We found no interactive effect of individual condition and habitat quality on natal dispersal and habitat selection.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>These findings suggest that immediate conditions are more important determinants of dispersal decisions than conditions experienced early in life.</Species>
<Species>Altered regulation of the OmpF porin by Fis in Escherichia coli during an evolution experiment and between B and K-12 strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The phenotypic plasticity of global regulatory networks provides bacteria with rapid acclimation to a wide range of environmental conditions, while genetic changes in those networks provide additional flexibility as bacteria evolve across long time scales.</Species>
<Species>We previously identified mutations in the global regulator-encoding gene fis that enhanced organismal fitness during a long-term evolution experiment with Escherichia coli.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To gain insight into the effects of these mutations, we produced two-dimensional protein gels with strains carrying different fis alleles, including a beneficial evolved allele and one with an in-frame deletion.</Species>

<Species>We found that Fis controls the expression of the major porin-encoding gene ompF in the E. coli B-derived ancestral strain used in the evolution experiment, a relationship that has not been described before.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We further showed that this regulatory connection evolved over two different time scales, perhaps explaining why it was not observed before.</Species>
<Species>On the longer time scale, we showed that this regulation of ompF by Fis is absent from the more widely studied K-12 strain and thus is specific to the B strain.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>On a shorter time scale, this regulatory linkage was lost during 20,000 generations of experimental evolution of the B strain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Finally, we mapped the Fis binding sites in the ompF regulatory region, and we present a hypothetical model of ompF expression that includes its other known regulators.</Species>

<Species>African 2, a clonal complex of Mycobacterium bovis epidemiologically important in East Africa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have identified a clonal complex of Mycobacterium bovis isolated at high frequency from cattle in Uganda, Burundi, Tanzania, and Ethiopia.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We have named this related group of M. bovis strains the African 2 (Af2) clonal complex of M. bovis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Af2 strains are defined by a specific chromosomal deletion (RDAf2) and can be identified by the absence of spacers 3 to 7 in their spoligotype patterns.</Species>

<Species>Deletion analysis of M. bovis isolates from Algeria, Mali, Chad, Nigeria, Cameroon, South Africa, and Mozambique did not identify any strains of the Af2 clonal complex, suggesting that this clonal complex of M. bovis is localized in East Africa.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The specific spoligotype pattern of the Af2 clonal complex was rarely identified among isolates from outside Africa, and the few isolates that were found and tested were intact at the RDAf2 locus.</Species>
<Species>We conclude that the Af2 clonal complex is localized to cattle in East Africa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that strains of the Af2 clonal complex of M. bovis have, in general, four or more copies of the insertion sequence IS6110, in contrast to the majority of M. bovis strains isolated from cattle, which are thought to carry only one or a few copies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Domain structure of Lassa virus L protein.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The 200-kDa L protein of arenaviruses plays a central role in viral genome replication and transcription.</Species>

<Species>This study aimed at providing evidence for the domain structure of L protein by combining bioinformatics with a stepwise mutagenesis approach using the Lassa virus minireplicon system.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Potential interdomain linkers were predicted using various algorithms.</Species>
<Species>The prediction was challenged by insertion of flexible sequences into the predicted linkers.</Species>
<Species>Insertion of 5 or 10 amino acid residues was tolerated at seven sites (S407, G446, G467, G774, G939, S1952, and V2074 in Lassa virus AV).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At two of these sites, G467 and G939, L protein could be split into an N-terminal and a C-terminal part, which were able to trans-complement each other and reconstitute a functional complex upon coexpression.</Species>
<Species>Coimmunoprecipitation studies revealed physical interaction between the N- and C-terminal domains, irrespective of whether L protein was split at G467 or G939.</Species>

<Species>In confocal immunofluorescence microscopy, the N-terminal domains showed a dot-like, sometimes perinuclear, cytoplasmic distribution similar to that of full-length L protein, while the C-terminal domains were homogenously distributed in cytoplasm.</Species>
<Species>The latter were redistributed into the dot-like structures upon coexpression with the corresponding N-terminal domain.</Species>

<Species>In conclusion, this study demonstrates two interdomain linkers in Lassa virus L protein, at G467 and G939, suggesting that L protein is composed of at least three structural domains spanning residues 1 to 467, 467 to 939, and 939 to 2220.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The first domain seems to mediate accumulation of L protein into cytoplasmic dot-like structures.</Species>

<Species>Paralogous cyp51 genes in Fusarium graminearum mediate differential sensitivity to sterol demethylation inhibitors.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Analysis of the genome sequence of Fusarium graminearum revealed three paralogous cyp51 genes (designated cyp51A, -B, and -C) encoding 14-alpha demethylases in this fungus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Targeted gene disruption showed that the cyp51A, -B or -C disruption mutants were morphologically indistinguishable from the parent isolate on potato dextrose agar medium, which indicates that none of these genes is essential for mycelial growth.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The sensitivity of cyp51A deletion mutants to seven sterol demethylation inhibitor (DMI) fungicides increased significantly compared to the parent strain, while sensitivity of cyp51C deletion mutants increased to some but not all DMIs.</Species>
<Species>No change in DMI sensitivity was observed for cyp51B deletion mutants.</Species>
<Species>The parental phenotypes of cyp51A and cyp51C deletion mutants were completely restored by genetic complementation with the wild-type cyp51A and cyp51C genes, respectively.</Species>

<Species>The sensitivity of F. graminearum isolates increased significantly when subjected in vitro to a mixture of DMI fungicides triadimefon and tebuconazole as compared to the individual components.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results indicate that different DMI fungicides target different CYP51 proteins in F. graminearum and that a mixture of DMI fungicides can result in synergistic effects.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our findings have directly implications on chemical management strategies of plant diseases caused by Fusarium species.</Species>
<Species>The molecular and genetic basis of conidial pigmentation in Aspergillus niger.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A characteristic hallmark of Aspergillus niger is the formation of black conidiospores.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have identified four loci involved in spore pigmentation of A. niger by using a combined genomic and classical complementation approach.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>First, we characterized a newly isolated color mutant, colA, which lacked pigmentation resulting in white or colorless conidia.</Species>
<Species>Pigmentation of the colA mutant was restored by a gene (An12g03950) which encodes a putative 4'phosphopantetheinyl transferase protein (PptA).</Species>
<Species>4'Phosphopantetheinyl transferase activity is required for the activation of Polyketide Synthases (PKSs) and/or Non-Ribosomal Peptide Synthases (NRPSs).</Species>
<Species>The loci whose mutation resulted in fawn, olive, and brown color phenotypes were identified by complementation.</Species>

<Species>The fawn phenotype was complemented by a PKS protein (FwnA, An09g05730), the ovlA mutant by An14g05350 (OlvA) and the brnA mutant by An14g05370 (BrnA), the respective homologs of alb1/pksP, ayg1 and abr1 in A. fumigatus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Targeted disruption of the pptA, fwnA, olvA and brnA genes confirmed the complementation results.</Species>

<Species>Disruption of the pptA gene abolished synthesis of all polyketides and non-ribosomal peptides, while the naphtho-gamma-pyrone subclass of polyketides were specifically dependent on fwnA, and funalenone on fwnA, olvA and</Species>
<Species>brnA.</Species>
<Species>Thus, secondary metabolite profiling of the color mutants revealed a close relationship between polyketide synthesis and conidial pigmentation in A. niger.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Antiviral effects of a transgenic RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.</Species>
<Species>Transgenic expression of the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase 3D(pol) inhibited infection of Theiler's murine encephalitis virus (TMEV), a picornavirus from which it was derived.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Here, we infected 3D(pol) transgenic mice with another picornavirus, as well as an alphaherpesvirus and a rhabdovirus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>3D(pol) transgenic FVB mice had significantly lower viral loads and survived longer after infection with all three types of viruses than nontransgenic FVB mice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Viral inhibition among three different types of virus by transgenic 3D(pol) suggests that the mechanism of action is not the direct interference with picornaviral 3D(pol) but instead may be the changing of host cells to an antiviral state before or after viral infection occurs, as basal interferon levels were higher in 3D(pol) transgenic mice before infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Further study of this mechanism may open new possibilities for future antiviral therapy.</Species>
<Species>Introns, alternative splicing, spliced leader trans-splicing and differential expression of pcna and cyclin in Perkinsus marinus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To gain understanding on the structure and regulation of growth-related genes of the parasitic alveolate Perkinsus marinus, we analyzed genes encoding proliferating cell nuclear antigen (pcna) and cyclins (cyclin).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Comparison of the full-length cDNAs with the corresponding genomic sequences revealedtrans-splicing of the mRNAs of these genes with a conserved 21-22 nt spliced leader.</Species>
<Species>Over 10 copies of pcna were detected, with identical gene structures and similar nucleotide (nt) sequences (88-99%), encoding largely identical amino acid sequences (aa).</Species>
<Species>Two distinct types ofcyclin (Pmacyclin1 and Pmacyclin2) were identified, with 66-69% nt and 81-85% aa similarities.</Species>
<Species>Pmacyclin2 was organized in tandem repeats, and was alternatively spliced, giving rise to five subtypes of transcripts.</Species>
<Species>For both pcna and cyclin genes, 6-10 introns were found.</Species>

<Species>Quantitative RT-PCR assays showed that pcna and Pmacyclin2 expression levels were low with small variations during a 28-h time course, whereas Pmacyclin1 transcript abundance was 10-100 times higher, and increased markedly during active cell division, suggesting that it is a mitoticcyclinand can be a useful growth marker for this species.</Species>

<Species>The gene structure and expression features along with phylogenetic results position this organism between dinoflagellates and apicomplexans, but its definitive affiliation among alveolates requires further studies.</Species>
<Species>A caffeyl-coenzyme A synthetase initiates caffeate activation prior to caffeate reduction in the acetogenic bacterium Acetobacterium woodii.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The anaerobic acetogenic bacterium Acetobacterium woodii couples the reduction of caffeate with electrons derived from hydrogen to the synthesis of ATP by a chemiosmotic mechanism using sodium ions as coupling ions, but the enzymes involved remain to be established.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Previously, the electron transfer flavoproteins EtfA and EtfB were found to be involved in caffeate respiration.</Species>

<Species>By inverse PCR, we identified three genes upstream of etfA and etfB: carA, carB, and carC. carA encodes a potential coenzyme A (CoA) transferase, carB an acyl-CoA synthetase, and carC an acyl-CoA dehydrogenase.</Species>

<Species>carA, -B, and -C are located together with etfA/carE and etfB/carD on one polycistronic message, indicating that CarA, CarB, and CarC are also part of the caffeate respiration pathway.</Species>

<Species>The genetic data suggest an initial ATP-dependent activation of caffeate by CarB. To prove the proposed function of CarB, the protein was overproduced in Escherichia coli, and the recombinant protein was purified.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Purified CarB activates caffeate to caffeyl-CoA in an ATP- and CoA-dependent reaction.</Species>
<Species>The enzyme has broad pH and temperature optima and requires K(+) for activity.</Species>
<Species>In addition to caffeate, it can use p-coumarate, ferulate, and cinnamate as substrates, with 50, 15, and 9%, respectively, of the activity obtained with caffeate.</Species>
<Species>Expression of the car operon is induced not only by caffeate, p-coumarate, ferulate, and cinnamate but also by sinapate.</Species>
<Species>There is no induction by p-hydroxybenzoate or syringate.</Species>

<Species>Poliovirus-mediated disruption of cytoplasmic processing bodies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Metazoan cells form cytoplasmic mRNA granules such as stress granules (SG) and processing bodies (P bodies) that are proposed to be sites of aggregated, translationally silenced mRNAs and mRNA degradation.</Species>

<Species>Poliovirus (PV) is a plus-strand RNA virus containing a genome that is a functional mRNA; thus, we investigated if PV antagonizes the processes that lead to formation of these structures.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We have previously shown that PV infection inhibits the ability of cells to form stress granules by cleaving RasGAP-SH3-binding protein (G3BP).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, we show that P bodies are also disrupted during PV infection in cells by 4 h postinfection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The disruption of P bodies is more rapid and more complete than disruption of stress granules.</Species>
<Species>The kinetics of P body disruption correlated with production of viral proteinases and required substantial viral gene product expression.</Species>

<Species>The organizing mechanism that forms P body foci in cells is unknown; however, potential scaffolding, aggregating, or other regulatory proteins found in P bodies were investigated for degradation.</Species>

<Species>Two factors involved in 5'-end mRNA decapping and degradation, Xrn1 and Dcp1a, and the 3' deadenylase complex component Pan3 underwent accelerated degradation during infection, and Dcp1a may be a direct substrate of PV 3C proteinase.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Several other key factors proposed to be essential for P body formation, GW182, Edc3, and Edc4, were unaffected by poliovirus infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Since deadenylation has been reported to be required for P body formation, viral inhibition of deadenylation, through Pan3 degradation, is a potential mechanism of P body disruption.</Species>

<Species>Pyrethroid resistance in Sitophilus zeamais is associated with a mutation (T929I) in the voltage-gated sodium channel.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The maize weevil, Sitophilus zeamais, is the most important pest affecting stored grain in Brazil and its control relies heavily on the use of insecticides.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The intensive use of compounds such as the pyrethroids has led to the emergence of resistance, and previous studies have suggested that resistance to both pyrethroids and 1,1,1-trichloro-2,2-bis(p-chlorophenyl)ethane (DDT) may result from reduced sensitivity of the insecticide target, the voltage-gated sodium channel.</Species>

<Species>To identify the molecular mechanisms underlying pyrethroid resistance in S. zeamais, the domain II region of the voltage-gated sodium channel (para-orthologue) gene was amplified by PCR and sequenced from susceptible and resistant laboratory S. zeamais strains that were selected with a discriminating dose of DDT.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A single point mutation, T929I, was found in the para gene of the resistant S. zeamais populations and its presence in individual weevils was strongly associated with survival after DDT exposure.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This is the first identification of a target-site resistance mutation in S. zeamais and unusually it is a super-kdr type mutation occurring in the absence of the more common kdr (L1014F) substitution.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A high-throughput assay based on TaqMan single nucleotide polymorphism genotyping was developed for sensitive detection of the mutation and used to screen field-collected strains of S. zeamais.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This showed that the mutation is present at low frequency in field populations and is a useful tool for informing control strategies.</Species>

<Species>Laboratory and Field Evaluation of Formulated Bacillus thuringiensis var. israelensis as a Feed Additive and Using Topical Applications for Control of Musca domestica (Diptera: Muscidae) Larvae in Caged-Poultry Manure.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Infestations of house flies, Musca domestica L., are a continual problem around poultry establishments.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Acute toxicity of two commercial Bacillus thuringiensis variety israelensis (Bti) formulations (water-dispersible granules and bran formulation) was evaluated against larvae in the laboratory and against natural populations of M. domestica larvae in the field applied in feed to chickens and as topical applications in the poultry houses.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Bioassay data showed that susceptibility of M. domestica larvae increased to a given concentration of Bti as the duration of exposure increased.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In the laboratory studies, the LC(50) values of Bti for the larvae ranged between 65 and 77.4 mug/ml.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the field, a concentration of 10 g Bti/kg of feed resulted in 90% reduction of larvae at 4 wk after treatment.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A higher concentration (2 g/liter) of Bti in spray applications was not significantly more effective than the lower concentration of 1 g/liter.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Adding Bti to chicken feed is potentially an efficient measure for the management and control of house flies in caged-poultry facilities.</Species>
label: Species
Species
