text: <Species>Ste50 adaptor protein governs sexual differentiation of Cryptococcus neoformans via the pheromone-response MAPK signaling pathway.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) pathways control diverse cellular functions in pathogenic fungi, including sexual differentiation, stress response, and maintenance of cell wall integrity.</Species>

<Species>Here we characterized a Cryptococcus neoformans gene, which is homologous to the yeast Ste50 that is known to play an important role in mating pheromone response and stress response as an adaptor protein to the Ste11 MAPK kinase kinase in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The C. neoformans Ste50 was not involved in any of the stress responses or virulence factor production (capsule and melanin) that are controlled by the HOG and Ras/cAMP signaling pathways.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, Ste50 was required for mating in both serotype A and serotype D C. neoformans strains.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The ste50Delta mutant was completely defective in cell-cell fusion and mating pheromone production.</Species>

<Species>Double mutation of the STE50 gene blocked increased production of pheromone and the hyper-filamentation phenotype of cells deleted of the CRG1 gene, which encodes the RGS protein that negatively regulates pheromone responsive G-protein signaling via the MAPK pathway.</Species>

<Species>Regardless of the presence of the basidiomycota-specific SH3 domains of Ste50 that are known to be required for full virulence of Ustilago maydis, Ste50 was dispensable for virulence of C. neoformans in a murine model of cryptococcosis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In conclusion, the Ste50 adaptor protein controls sexual differentiation of C. neoformans via the pheromone-responsive MAPK pathway but is not required for virulence.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Light exerts multiple levels of influence on the Arabidopsis wound response.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Light plays important roles in modulating plant responses to attack by pests and pathogens.</Species>
<Species>Here, we test the hypothesis that darkness modifies the response to wounding, and examine possible mechanisms for such an effect.</Species>
<Species>We investigated changes in the Arabidopsis transcriptome following a light-dark transition and the response to wounding either in the light or in the dark.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The transcriptional response to the light-dark transition strongly resembles responses associated with carbon depletion.</Species>
<Species>The dark shift and wound responses acted largely independently, but more complex interactions were identified at a number of levels.</Species>

<Species>Darkness attenuates the overall transcriptional response to wounding, and we identified genes and physiological processes, such as anthocyanin accumulation, that exhibit light-dependent wound responses.</Species>
<Species>Transcriptional activation of light-dependent wound-induced genes requires a chloroplast-derived signal originating from photosynthetic electron transport.</Species>
<Species>We also present evidence of a role for the circadian clock in modifying wound responses.</Species>
<Species>Our results show that darkness impacts on the wound response at a number of levels, which may imply differences in induced herbivore defences during the day and night.</Species>
<Species>Application of the systematic "DAmP" approach to create a partially defective C. albicans mutant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>An understanding of gene function often relies upon creating multiple kinds of alleles.</Species>

<Species>Functional analysis in Candida albicans, a major fungal pathogen, has generally included characterization of mutant strains with insertion or deletion alleles and over-expression alleles.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here we use in C. albicans another type of allele that has been employed effectively in the model yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, a "Decreased Abundance by mRNA Perturbation" (DAmP) allele (Yan et al., 2008).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>DAmP alleles are created systematically through replacement of 30 noncoding regions with nonfunctional heterologous sequences, and thus are broadly applicable.</Species>

<Species>We used a DAmP allele to probe the function of Sun41, a surface protein with roles in cell wall integrity, cell-cell adherence, hyphal formation, and biofilm formation that has been suggested as a possible therapeutic target (Firon et al., 2007; Hiller et al., 2007; Norice et al., 2007).</Species>
<Species>A SUN41-DAmP allele results in approximately 10-fold reduced levels of SUN41 RNA, and yields intermediate phenotypes in most assays.</Species>
<Species>We report that a sun41Delta/Delta mutant is defective in biofilm formation in vivo, and that the SUN41-DAmP allele complements that defect.</Species>
<Species>This finding argues that Sun41 may not be an ideal therapeutic target for biofilm inhibition, since a 90% decrease in activity has little effect on biofilm formation in vivo.</Species>
<Species>We anticipate that DAmP alleles of C. albicans genes will be informative for analysis of other prospective drug targets, including essential genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Association of TRIM22 with the type 1 interferon response and viral control during primary HIV-1 infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Type 1 interferons (IFNs) induce the expression of the tripartite interaction motif (TRIM) family of E3 ligases, but the contribution of these antiviral factors to HIV pathogenesis is not completely understood.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We hypothesized that the increased expression of select type 1 IFN and TRIM isoforms is associated with a significantly lower likelihood of HIV-1 acquisition and viral control during primary HIV-1 infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We measured IFN-alpha, IFN-Beta, myxovirus resistance protein</Species>

<Species>A (MxA), human TRIM5alpha (huTRIM5alpha), and TRIM22 mRNA levels in peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) of high-risk, HIV-1-uninfected participants and HIV-1-positive study participants.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Samples were available for 32 uninfected subjects and 28 infected persons, all within 1 year of infection.</Species>

<Species>HIV-1-positive participants had higher levels of IFN-Beta (P = 0.0005), MxA (P = 0.007), and TRIM22 (P = 0.01) and lower levels of huTRIM5alpha (P < 0.001) than did HIV-1-negative participants.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>TRIM22</Species>
<Species>but not huTRIM5alpha correlated positively with type 1 IFN (IFN-alpha, IFN-Beta, and MxA) (all P < 0.0001).</Species>
<Species>In a multivariate model, increased MxA expression showed a significant positive association with viral load (P = 0.0418).</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, TRIM22 but not huTRIM5alpha, IFN-alpha, IFN-Beta, or MxA showed a negative correlation with plasma viral load (P = 0.0307) and a positive correlation with CD4(+)</Species>
<Species>T-cell counts (P = 0.0281).</Species>
<Species>In vitro studies revealed that HIV infection induced TRIM22 expression in PBMCs obtained from HIV-negative donors.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Stable TRIM22 knockdown resulted in increased HIV-1 particle release and replication in Jurkat reporter cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Collectively, these data suggest concordance between type 1 IFN and TRIM22 but not huTRIM5alpha expression in PBMCs and that TRIM22 likely acts as an antiviral effector in vivo.</Species>

<Species>The cell cycle gene MoCDC15 regulates hyphal growth, asexual development and plant infection in the rice blast pathogen Magnaporthe oryzae.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Rice blast, caused by the pathogen Magnaporthe oryzae, is a serious hindrance to rice production and has emerged as an important model for the characterization of molecular mechanisms relevant to pathogenic development in plants.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Similar to other pathogenic fungi, conidiation plays a central role in initiation of M.oryzae infection and spread over a large area.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, relatively little is known regarding the molecular mechanisms that underlie conidiation in M. oryzae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To better characterize these mechanisms, we identified a conidiation-defective mutant, ATMT0225B6 (MoCDC15(T-DNA)), in which a T-DNA insertion disrupted a gene that encodes a homolog of fission yeast cdc15, and generated a second strain containing a disruption in the same allele (DeltaMoCDC15(T-DNA)).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The cdc15 gene has been shown to act as a coordinator of the cell cycle in yeast.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Functional analysis of the MoCDC15(T-DNA) and DeltaMoCDC15(T-DNA) mutants revealed that MoCDC15 is required for conidiation, preinfection development and pathogenicity in M. oryzae.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Conidia from these mutants were viable, but failed to adhere to hydrophobic surface, a crucial step required for subsequent pathogenic development.</Species>
<Species>All phenotypic defects observed in mutants were rescued in a strain complemented with wild type MoCDC15.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Together, these data indicate that MoCDC15 functions as a coordinator of several biological processes important for pathogenic development in M. oryzae.</Species>

text: <Species>The immunologic mechanisms underlying the faster progression of hepatitis C virus (HCV) disease in the presence of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) coinfection are not clearly understood.</Species>

text: <Species>T-cell cross-reactivity between HCV and influenza virus-specific epitopes has been associated with rapid progression of HCV disease (S. Urbani, B. Amadei, P. Fisicaro, M. Pilli, G. Missale, A. Bertoletti, and C. Ferrari, J. Exp.</Species>

text: <Species>Med.</Species>
<Species>We asked whether T-cell cross-reactivity between HCV and HIV could exist during HCV/HIV coinfection and affect pathogenesis.</Species>

text: <Species>Two methane-producing archaea, designated Mic5c12(T) and Mic6c05(T), were isolated from sludge deposited in a crude oil storage tank and a tubercle on the interior of a pipe transporting natural gas-containing brine, respectively.</Species>
<Species>The isolates were Gram-staining-variable, non-motile rods and grew only on H(2)/CO(2).</Species>
<Species>Strain Mic6c05(T) produced methane from some alcohols without showing any growth; strain Mic5c12(T) did not utilize alcohols.</Species>
<Species>The optimum growth conditions for strain Mic5c12(T) were 35 ^0C, pH 6.5 and 0-0.68 M NaCl and for strain Mic6c05(T) were 40 ^0C, pH 6.0-7.5 and 0.34 M NaCl.</Species>
<Species>Strain Mic5c12(T) was halotolerant and strain Mic6c05(T) was halophilic.</Species>

<Species>Comparative 16S rRNA gene sequence analysis revealed that strains Mic5c12(T) and Mic6c05(T) belonged to the genus Methanobacterium and their closest relative was Methanobacterium subterraneum A8p(T) (97.3 and 97.9 % 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity, respectively).</Species>

text: <Species>Host translational control is a viral strategy to exploit host cellular resources.</Species>

<Species>Two host translation inhibitory factors (HTIFs) have been proposed in Cotesia plutellae bracovirus (CpBV).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Parasitization by C. plutellae inhibited storage protein 1 (SP1) synthesis of Plutella xylostella at post-transcriptional level.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>One HTIF, CpBV15Beta, inhibited the translation of SP1 mRNA in an in vitro translation assay using rabbit reticulocyte lysate, but did not inhibit its own mRNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To further analyse the discrimination of target and nontarget mRNAs of the inhibitory effect of HTIF, 5' untranslated regions (UTRs) of SP1 and CpBV15Beta mRNA were reciprocally exchanged.</Species>
<Species>In the presence of HTIFs, the chimeric CpBV15Beta mRNA that contained SP1 5' UTR was not translated, whereas the chimeric SP1 mRNA that contained CpBV15Beta 5' UTR was translated.</Species>
<Species>There was a difference in the 5' UTR secondary structures between target (SP1) and nontarget (CpBV15alpha and CpBV15Beta) mRNAs in terms of thermal stability.</Species>
<Species>Different mutant 5' UTRs of SP1 mRNA were prepared by point mutations to modify their secondary structures.</Species>
<Species>The constructs containing 5' UTRs of high thermal stability in their secondary structures were inhibited by HTIF, but those of low thermal stability were not.</Species>
<Species>Immunoprecipitation with CpBV15Beta antibody coprecipitated eIF4A, which would be required for unwinding the secondary structure of the 5' UTR.</Species>
<Species>These results indicate that the viral HTIF discriminates between host mRNAs according to their dependency on eIF4A to form a functional initiation complex for translation.</Species>

<Species>Dinoflagellates associated with freshwater sponges from the ancient lake baikal.</Species>
<Species>Dinoflagellates are a diverse group of protists that are common in both marine and freshwater environments.</Species>
<Species>While the biology of marine dinoflagellates has been the focus of several recent studies, their freshwater relatives remain little-investigated.</Species>

<Species>In the present study we explore the diversity of dinoflagellates in Lake Baikal by identifying and analyzing dinoflagellate sequences for 18S rDNA and ITS-2 from total DNA extracted from three species of endemic Baikalian sponges (Baikalospongia intermedia, Baikalospongia recta and Lubomirskia incrustans).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Phylogenetic analyses of these sequences revealed extensive dinoflagellate diversity in Lake Baikal.</Species>
<Species>We found two groups of sequences clustering within the order Suessiales, known for its symbiotic relationships with various invertebrates.</Species>
<Species>Thus they may be regarded as potential symbionts of Baikalian sponges.</Species>

<Species>In addition,Gyrodinium helveticum, representatives from the genus Gymnodinium, dinoflagellates close to the family Pfiesteriaceae, and a few dinoflagellates without definite affiliation were detected.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>No pronounced difference in the distribution of dinoflagellates among the studied sponges was found, except for the absence of the Piscinoodinium-like dinoflagellates in L. incrustans.</Species>

<Species>To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study of the diversity of dinoflagellates in freshwater sponges, the first systematic investigation of dinoflagellate molecular diversity in Lake Baikal and the first finding of members of the order Suessiales as symbionts of freshwater invertebrates.</Species>
<Species>Cross-talk between light and glucose regulation controls toxin production and morphogenesis in Aspergillus nidulans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Light is a major environmental stimulus that has a broad effect on organisms, triggering a cellular response that results in an optimal adaptation enhancing fitness and survival.</Species>
<Species>In fungi, light affects growth, and causes diverse morphological changes such as those leading to reproduction.</Species>
<Species>Light can also affect fungal metabolism, including the biosynthesis of natural products.</Species>
<Species>In this study we show that in Aspergillus nidulans the effect of light on the production of the sterigmatocystin (ST) toxin depends on the glucose concentration.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In cultures grown with 1% glucose and exposed to light, ST production was lower than when grown in the dark.</Species>
<Species>This lower ST production coincided with an elevated rate of cellular damage with partial loss of nuclear integrity and vacuolated cytoplasm.</Species>
<Species>However, in cultures grown with 2% glucose these effects were reversed and light enhanced ST production.</Species>

<Species>Glucose abundance also affected the light-dependent subcellular localization of the VeA (velvet) protein, a key regulator necessary for normal light-dependent morphogenesis and secondary metabolism in Aspergilli and other fungal genera.</Species>

<Species>The role of other VeA-associated proteins, particularly the blue-light-sensing proteins LreA and LreB (WC-1 and WC-2 orthologs), on conidiation could also be modified by the abundance of glucose.</Species>
<Species>We also show that LreA and LreB, as well as the phytochrome FphA, modulate not only the synthesis of sterigmatocystin, but also the production of the antibiotic penicillin.</Species>

text: <Species>New insights into the mechanism of light modulated signaling by heterotrimeric G-proteins: ENVOY acts on gna1 and gna3 and adjusts cAMP levels in Trichoderma reesei (Hypocrea jecorina).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Sensing of environmental signals is often mediated by G-protein coupled receptors and their cognate heterotrimeric G-proteins.</Species>

<Species>In Trichoderma reesei (Hypocrea jecorina) the signals transmitted via the G-protein alpha subunits GNA1 and GNA3 cause considerable modulation of cellulase transcript levels and the extent of this adjustment is dependent on the light status.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We therefore intended to elucidate the underlying mechanism connecting light response and heterotrimeric G-protein signaling.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of double mutant strains showed that constitutive activation of GNA1 or GNA3 in the absence of the PAS/LOV domain protein ENVOY (ENV1) leads to the phenotype of constitutive G-alpha activation in darkness.</Species>
<Species>In light, however the deletion-phenotype of Deltaenv1 was observed with respect to growth, conidiation and cellulase gene transcription.</Species>
<Species>Additionally deletion of env1 causes decreased intracellular cAMP accumulation, even upon constitutive activation of GNA1 or GNA3.</Species>

<Species>While supplementation of cAMP caused an even more severe growth phenotype of all strains lacking env1 in light, addition of the phosphodiesterase inhibitor caffeine rescued the growth phenotype of these strains.</Species>

<Species>ENV1 is consequently suggested to connect the light response pathway with nutrient signaling by the heterotrimeric G-protein cascade by adjusting transcript levels of gna1 and gna3 and action on cAMP levels - presumably through inhibition of a phosphodiesterase.</Species>

text: <Species>A root is a root is a root? Water uptake rates of Citrus root orders.</Species>
<Species>Knowledge about the physiological function of root orders is scant.</Species>
<Species>In this study, a system to monitor the water flux among root orders was developed using miniaturized chambers.</Species>
<Species>Different root orders of 4-year-old Citrus volkameriana trees were analysed with respect to root morphology and water flux.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The eight root orders showed a broad overlap in diameter, but differences in tissue densities and specific root area (SRA) were clearly distinguishable.</Species>
<Species>Thirty per cent of the root branch biomass but 50% of the surface area (SA) was possessed by the first root order, while the fifth accounted for 5% of the SA (20% biomass).</Species>
<Species>The root order was identified as a determinant of water flux.</Species>
<Species>First-order roots showed a significantly higher rate of water uptake than the second and third root orders, whereas the fourth and fifth root orders showed water excess.</Species>
<Species>The water excess suggested the occurrence of hydraulic redistribution (HR) as a result of differences in osmotic potentials.</Species>
<Species>We suggest that plants may utilize hydraulic redistribution to prevent coarse root desiccation and/or to increase nutrient acquisition.</Species>

<Species>Our study showed that the novel 'miniature depletion chamber' method enabled direct measurement of water fluxes per root order and can be a major tool for future studies on root order traits.</Species>
<Species>Labeling and enzyme studies of the central carbon metabolism in Metallosphaera sedula.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Metallosphaera sedula (Sulfolobales, Crenarchaeota) uses the 3-hydroxypropionate/4-hydroxybutyrate cycle for autotrophic carbon fixation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this pathway, acetyl-coenzyme A (CoA) and succinyl-CoA are the only intermediates that can be considered common to the central carbon metabolism.</Species>
<Species>We addressed the question of which intermediate of the cycle most biosynthetic routes branch off.</Species>
<Species>We labeled autotrophically growing cells by using 4-hydroxy[1-^1^4C]butyrate and [1,4-^1^3C1]succinate, respectively, as precursors for biosynthesis.</Species>

<Species>The labeling patterns of protein-derived amino acids verified the operation of the proposed carbon fixation cycle, in which 4-hydroxybutyrate is converted to two molecules of acetyl-CoA.</Species>
<Species>The results also showed that major biosynthetic flux does not occur via acetyl-CoA, except for the formation of building blocks that are directly derived from acetyl-CoA.</Species>
<Species>Notably, acetyl-CoA is not assimilated via reductive carboxylation to pyruvate.</Species>
<Species>Rather, our data suggest that the majority of anabolic precursors are derived from succinyl-CoA, which is removed from the cycle via oxidation to malate and oxaloacetate.</Species>
<Species>These C4intermediates yield pyruvate and phosphoenolpyruvate (PEP).</Species>
<Species>Enzyme activities that are required for forming intermediates from succinyl-CoA were detected, including enzymes catalyzing gluconeogenesis from PEP.</Species>

<Species>This study completes the picture of the central carbon metabolism in autotrophic Sulfolobales by connecting the autotrophic carbon fixation cycle to the formation of central carbon precursor metabolites.</Species>

text: <Species>Sex serves a pivotal role in genetic exchange and it contributes to the fitness and genetic diversity for eukaryotic populations.</Species>

<Species>Although the importance of the canonical bisexual mating has been widely accepted, the significance of the evolution and maintenance of unisexual mating observed in some eukaryotes is unclear.</Species>

<Species>The recent discovery of same-sex mating in the human fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans and the revelation of its impact on the Cryptococcus global population structure provide a platform to elucidate the molecular mechanisms and significance of unisexual mating.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Here, we review the evidence of unisexual mating in Cryptococcus and provide some perspective on the biological significance of this life style on the survival of this important fungal pathogen in the environment and in animal hosts.</Species>
<Species>We also summarize our current understanding of the molecular mechanisms governing this unconventional mode of reproduction.</Species>

text: <Species>Newly emerging viruses often circulate as a heterogeneous swarm in wild animal reservoirs prior to their emergence in humans, and their antigenic identities are often unknown until an outbreak situation.</Species>

text: <Species>The newly emerging severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) and reemerging influenza virus cause disproportionate disease in the aged, who are also notoriously difficult to successfully vaccinate, likely due to immunosenescence.</Species>

text: <Species>To protect against future emerging strains, vaccine platforms should induce broad cross-reactive immunity that is sufficient to protect from homologous and heterologous challenge in all ages.</Species>
<Species>From initial studies, we hypothesized that attenuated Venezuelan equine encephalitis virus (VEE) replicon particle (VRP) vaccine glycoproteins mediated vaccine failure in the aged.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We then compared the efficacies of vaccines bearing attenuated (VRP(3014)) or wild-type VEE glycoproteins (VRP(3000)) in young and aged mice within novel models of severe SARS-CoV pathogenesis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Aged animals receiving VRP(3000)-based vaccines were protected from SARS-CoV disease, while animals receiving the VRP(3014)-based vaccines were not.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The superior protection for the aged observed with VRP(3000)-based vaccines was confirmed in a lethal influenza virus challenge model.</Species>

<Species>While the VRP(3000) vaccine's immune responses in the aged were sufficient to protect against lethal homologous and heterologous challenge, our data suggest that innate defects within the VRP(3014) platform mediate vaccine failure.</Species>

<Species>Exploration into the mechanism(s) of successful vaccination in the immunosenescent should aid in the development of successful vaccine strategies for other viral diseases disproportionately affecting the elderly, like West Nile virus, influenza virus, norovirus, or other emerging viruses of the future.</Species>

text: <Species>The physiological traits underlying the apparent drought resistance of 'Tomatiga de Ramellet' (TR) cultivars, a population of Mediterranean tomato cultivars with delayed fruit deterioration (DFD) phenotype and typically grown under non-irrigation conditions, are evaluated.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Eight different tomato accessions were selected and included six TR accessions, one Mediterranean non-TR accession (NTR(M)) and a processing cultivar (NTR(O)).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Among the TR accessions two leaf morphology types, normal divided leaves and potato-leaf, were selected.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Plants were field grown under well-watered (WW) and water-stressed (WS) treatments, with 30 and 10% of soil water capacity, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Accessions were clustered according to the leaf type and TR phenotype under WW and WS, respectively.</Species>

<Species>Correlation among parameters under the different water treatments suggested that potential improvements in the intrinsic water-use efficiency (A(N)/g(s)) are possible without negative impacts on yield.</Species>

<Species>Under WS TR accessions displayed higher A(N)/g(s), which was not due to differences in Rubisco-related parameters, but correlated with the ratio between the leaf mesophyll and stomatal conductances (g(m)/g(s)).</Species>

<Species>The results confirm the existence of differential traits in the response to drought stress in Mediterranean accessions of tomato, and demonstrate that increases in the g(m)/g(s) ratio would allow improvements in A(N)/g(s) in horticultural crops.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Financing health care for all: challenges and opportunities.</Species>
<Species>Spirochaeta perfilievii sp. nov., an oxygen-tolerant, sulfide-oxidizing, sulfur- and thiosulfate-reducing spirochaete isolated from a saline spring.</Species>

<Species>A novel strain of fermenting, aerotolerant, chemo-organoheterotrophic spirochaete designated P(T) was isolated from a sulfur 'Thiodendron' mat in a saline spring at the Staraya Russa resort (Novgorod Region, Russia).</Species>
<Species>Cells of strain P(T) exhibited a helical shape.</Species>

<Species>The spirochaete required sulfide in the growth medium and was able to oxidize it non-enzymically to elemental sulfur via the interaction of H(2)O(2) with sulfide and deposit it in the periplasmic space.</Species>
<Species>Growth occurred at 4-32 ^0C (optimum at 28-30 ^0C), pH 6.0-8.5 (optimum pH 7.0-7.5), and in 0.1-1 M NaCl (optimum 0.35 M).</Species>
<Species>The isolate used several sugars and polysaccharides as carbon or energy sources but did not use peptides, amino acids, organic acids or alcohols.</Species>
<Species>The products of glucose fermentation were formate, acetate, ethanol, pyruvate, CO(2) and H(2).</Species>
<Species>The genomic DNA G+C content was 41.7 mol%.</Species>

<Species>16S rRNA gene sequence analysis showed that strain P(T) fell within a group of species in the genus Spirochaeta, including Spirochaeta litoralis, S. isovalerica and S. cellobiosiphila, with which it shared less then 89 % sequence similarity.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>On the basis of its morphology, physiology and other phenotypic properties, as well as its phylogenetic position, the new isolate is considered to represent a novel species of the genus Spirochaeta, for which the name Spirochaeta perfilievii sp. nov. is proposed.</Species>
<Species>The type strain is P(T)</Species>
<Species>(=DSM 19205(T) =VKM B-2514(T)).</Species>
<Species>Natural history and intragenomic dynamics of the Transib transposon Hztransib in the cotton bollworm Helicoverpa zea.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>Hztransib, recently identified from Helicoverpa zea, represents the first intact and transcriptionally active Transib element.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Its open reading frame was detected in Helicoverpa armigera, from which H. zea evolved, and in Helicoverpa assulta, the common ancestor of H. zea and H. armigera, but its remaining parts were found only in H. armigera.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Thirty-nine Hztransib insertion sites, all of which are polymorphic, were detected from eight populations of H. zea.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Out of the 39 insertion sites, 35 were not frequently occupied, with 1-33 occurrences in a total of 128 individuals from the eight populations (16 larvae per population).</Species>
<Species>Its copy number ranged from 5.8 to 14.2 per individual, with putative intact copies always more abundant than internally deleted ones.</Species>

<Species>Taking this evidence together, Hztransib probably transferred to H. zea from H. armigera and most likely still retains its capacity to maintain structural integrity, increase copy number and remobilize in H. zea.</Species>

text: <Species>T cell-mediated protection against lethal 2009 pandemic H1N1 influenza virus infection in a mouse model.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Genetic mutation and reassortment of influenza virus gene segments, in particular those of hemagglutinin (HA) and neuraminidase (NA), that lead to antigenic drift and shift are the major strategies for influenza virus to escape preexisting immunity.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The most recent example of such phenomena is the first pandemic of H1N1 influenza of the 21st century, which started in 2009.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cross-reactive antibodies raised against H1N1 viruses circulating before 1930 show protective activity against the 2009 pandemic virus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Cross-reactive T-cell responses can also contribute to protection, but in vivo support of this view is lacking.</Species>

<Species>To explore the protection mechanisms in vivo, we primed mice with H1 and H3 influenza virus isolates and rechallenged them with a virus derived from the 2009 H1N1 A/CA/04/09 virus, named CA/E3/09.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We found that priming with influenza viruses of both H1 and H3 homo- and heterosubtypes protected against lethal CA/E3/09 virus challenge.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Convalescent-phase sera from these primed mice conferred no neutralization activity in vitro and no protection in vivo.</Species>
<Species>However, T-cell depletion studies suggested that both CD4 and CD8 T cells contributed to the protection.</Species>

<Species>Taken together, these results indicate that cross-reactive T cells established after initial priming with distally related viruses can be a vital component for prevention of disease and control of pandemic H1N1 influenza virus infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our results highlight the importance of establishing cross-reactive T-cell responses for protecting against existing or newly emerging pandemic influenza viruses.</Species>
<Species>Towards achievement of universal health care in India by 2020: a call to action.</Species>

<Species>To sustain the positive economic trajectory that India has had during the past decade, and to honour the fundamental right of all citizens to adequate health care, the health of all Indian people has to be given the highest priority in public policy.</Species>

<Species>We propose the creation of the Integrated National Health System in India through provision of universal health insurance, establishment of autonomous organisations to enable accountable and evidence-based good-quality health-care practices and development of appropriately trained human resources, the restructuring of health governance to make it coordinated and decentralised, and legislation of health entitlement for all Indian people.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The key characteristics of our proposal are to strengthen the public health system as the primary provider of promotive, preventive, and curative health services in India, to improve quality and reduce the out-of-pocket expenditure on health care through a well regulated integration of the private sector within the national health-care system.</Species>

<Species>Dialogue and consensus building among the stakeholders in the government, civil society, and private sector are the next steps to formalise the actions needed and to monitor their achievement.</Species>
<Species>In our call to action, we propose that India must achieve health care for all by 2020.</Species>
<Species>Development of an IgM-capture ELISA for Coxsackievirus A16 infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Diagnosis of Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) infection in China relies mainly on reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) that require expensive equipment and special trained personnel, thus making its wide application in health care settings unlikely.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In this study, a novel IgM anti-CA16 assay was developed for the detection of IgM antibodies to CA16 in serum.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The responses and diagnostic value of IgM for the CA16 infection were assessed by testing 1970 serum samples.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The results showed that sensitivity of IgM test was 84.6% (259/306, 95% CI: 80.1-88.5), and specificity in control subjects and patients with CA16 HFMD was 99.2% (1508/1520, 95% CI: 98.6-99.6) and 90.3% (14/144, 95% CI: 84.2-94.6), respectively.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The IgM positive rate reached 56.3% in the sera collected within the first day after onset, increased continuously to 95.3% at day 5 to day 7 after onset, and then reached 100% after more than 8 days.</Species>
<Species>The cross-reaction rate in patients infected with other non-CA16 enteroviruses was 9.7% (14/144).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results suggest that the IgM anti-CA16 assay offers a rapid, convenient, and reliable method to detect acute CA16 infections.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Compatible interaction with its rice host leads to enhanced expression of the gamma subunit of oligosaccharyl transferase in the Asian rice gall midge, Orseolia oryzae.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The Asian rice gall midge, Orseolia oryzae, is a fast evolving, damaging pest of rice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Understanding the underlying molecular mechanism of interaction between the gall midge and rice will help in devising strategies to control and manage the pest.</Species>
<Species>The present study aims to identify rice-responsive genes in the gall midge that aid pest survival.</Species>

<Species>The abundance of transcripts coding for enzymes related to glycosylation, in a cDNA library prepared from maggots of the rice gall midge feeding on susceptible hosts, indicated their probable involvement in the gall midge-rice interaction.</Species>
<Species>Hence, a full-length transcript for a gamma subunit of the oligosaccharyl transferase gene (OoOST) from the gall midge was cloned and characterized.</Species>
<Species>It has 72% similarity to its orthologue cloned from Aedes aegypti.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Tissue-specific analysis of the expression of OoOST revealed an increase (> sevenfold) in the transcripts of the gene in the salivary glands of maggots in susceptible plants when compared with the transcript level in the salivary glands of maggots feeding on resistant hosts.</Species>

<Species>Using quantitative PCR, performed on different developmental stages of the maggots in two susceptible and two resistant hosts, we observed similar expression patterns (i.e. overexpression in the compatible interaction).</Species>
<Species>These results indicate the involvement of OoOST in maggot survival and establishment in the susceptible host.</Species>
<Species>In order to identify polymorphism in the gene, OoOST was cloned from three gall midge biotypes GMB1, GMB4 and GMB4M.</Species>
<Species>PRP8 intein in Ajellomycetaceae family pathogens: sequence analysis, splicing evaluation and homing endonuclease activity.</Species>
<Species>Inteins are intervening sequences that are transcribed and translated with flanking host protein sequences and then self-excised by protein splicing.</Species>
<Species>Bi-functional inteins also contain a homing endonuclease responsible for their genetic mobility.</Species>
<Species>The PRP8 intein, the most widespread among fungi, occurs in important pathogens such as Histoplasma capsulatum and Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, from the Ajellomycetaceae family.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Herein, we describe the bi-functional PRP8 intein in two other Ajellomycetacean pathogens, Blastomyces dermatitidis and Emmonsia parva.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Sequence analysis and experimental evidence suggest that the homing endonuclease from PbrPRP8 is inactive.</Species>

<Species>The splicing activity of the PRP8 intein from the B. dermatitidis, E. parva and P. brasiliensis species complex was demonstrated in a non-native protein context in Escherichia coli.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Since the PRP8 intein is located in a functionally essential nuclear protein, it can be considered a promising therapeutic target for anti-fungal drugs, because inhibition of intein splicing should inhibit proliferation of intein-containing pathogens.</Species>
<Species>Structural and hydraulic correlates of heterophylly in Ginkgo biloba.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This study investigates the functional significance of heterophylly in Ginkgo biloba, where leaves borne on short shoots are ontogenetically distinct from those on long shoots.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Short shoots are compact, with minimal internodal elongation; their leaves are supplied with water through mature branches.</Species>
<Species>Long shoots extend the canopy and have significant internodal elongation; their expanding leaves receive water from a shoot that is itself maturing.</Species>

<Species>Morphology, stomatal traits, hydraulic architecture, Huber values, water transport efficiency, in situ gas exchange and laboratory-based steady-state hydraulic conductance were examined for each leaf type.</Species>
<Species>Both structure and physiology differed markedly between the two leaf types.</Species>
<Species>Short-shoot leaves were thinner and had higher vein density, lower stomatal pore index, smaller bundle sheath extensions and lower hydraulic conductance than long-shoot leaves.</Species>
<Species>Long shoots had lower xylem area:leaf area ratios than short shoots during leaf expansion, but this ratio was reversed at shoot maturity.</Species>
<Species>Long-shoot leaves had higher rates of photosynthesis, stomatal conductance and transpiration than short-shoot leaves.</Species>
<Species>We propose that structural differences between the two G. biloba leaf types reflect greater hydraulic limitation of long-shoot leaves during expansion.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In turn, differences in physiological performance of short- and long-shoot leaves correspond to their distinct ontogeny and architecture.</Species>
<Species>Growth and reproductive costs of larval defence in the aposematic lepidopteran Pieris brassicae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Utilization of plant secondary compounds for antipredator defence is common in immature herbivorous insects.</Species>
<Species>Such defences may incur a cost to the animal, either in terms of survival, growth rate or in the reproductive success.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>A common defence in lepidopterans is the regurgitation of semi-digested material containing the defensive compounds of the food plant, a defence which has led to gut specialization in this order.</Species>
<Species>Regurgitation is often swift in response to cuticular stimulation and deters predators from consuming or parasitizing the larva.</Species>
<Species>The loss of food and other gut material seems likely to impact on fitness, but evidence is lacking.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Here, we raised larvae of the common crop pest Pieris brassicae on commercial cabbage leaves, simulated predator attacks throughout the larval period, and measured life-history responses.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We found that the probability of survival to pupation decreased with increasing frequency of attacks, but this was because of regurgitation rather than the stimulation itself.</Species>
<Species>There was a growth cost to the defence such that the more regurgitant that individuals produced over the growth period, the smaller they were at pupation.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>The number of mature eggs in adult females was positively related to pupal mass, but this relationship was only found when individuals were not subjected to a high frequency of predator simulation.</Species>
<Species>This suggests that there might be cryptic fitness costs to common defensive responses that are paid despite apparent growth rate being maintained.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>

<Species>Our results demonstrate a clear life-history cost of an antipredator defence in a model pest species and show that under certain conditions, such as high predation threat, the expected relationship between female body size and potential fecundity can be disrupted.</Species>
<Species>Altering sexual reproductive mode by interspecific exchange of MAT loci.</Species>
<Species>Sexual fungi can be self-sterile (heterothallic, requiring genetically distinct partners) or self-fertile (homothallic, no partner required).</Species>
<Species>In most ascomycetes, a single mating type locus (MAT) controls the ability to reproduce sexually.</Species>

<Species>In the genus Cochliobolus, all heterothallic species have either MAT1-1 or MAT1-2 (but never both) in different individuals whereas all homothallic species carry both MAT1-1 and MAT1-2 in the same nucleus of an individual.</Species>

<Species>It has been demonstrated, previously, that a MAT gene from homothallic Cochliobolus luttrellii can confer self-mating ability on a mat-deleted strain of its heterothallic relative, Cochliobolus heterostrophus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In this reciprocal study, we expressed, separately, the heterothallic C. heterostrophus MAT1-1-1 and MAT1-2-1 genes in a mat-deleted homothallic C. luttrellii strain and asked if this converts homothallic C. luttrellii to heterothallism.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We report that: (1) A C. luttrellii transgenic strain carrying C. heterostrophus MAT1-1-1 and a C. luttrellii transgenic strain carrying C. heterostrophus MAT1-2-1 can mate in a heterothallic manner and the fertility of the cross is similar to that of a wild type C. luttrellii self.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Full tetrads are always found.</Species>

<Species>(2) A C. luttrellii transgenic strain carrying C. heterostrophus MAT1-1-1 can mate with the parental wild type C. luttrellii MAT1-1;MAT1-2 strain, indicating the latter is able to outcross, a result which was expected but has not been demonstrated previously.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>(3) A C. luttrellii transgenic strain carrying C. heterostrophus MAT1-2-1 cannot mate with the parental wild type C. luttrellii MAT1-1;MAT1-2 strain, indicating outcrossing specificity.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>(4) Each transgenic C. luttrellii strain, carrying only a single C. heterostrophus MAT gene, is able to self, although all pseudothecia produced are smaller than those of wild type and fertility is low (about 4-15% of the number of wild type asci).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These data support the argument that in Cochliobolus spp., the primary determinant of reproductive mode is MAT itself, and that a heterothallic strain can be made homothallic or a homothallic strain can be made heterothallic by exchange of MAT genes.</Species>

<Species>The selfing ability of transgenic C. luttrellii strains also suggests that both MAT1-1-1 and MAT1-2-1 genes of C. heterostrophus carry equivalent transcription regulatory activities, each capable of promoting sexual development when alone, in a suitable genetic background.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The role of abscisic acid and water stress in root herbivore-induced leaf resistance.</Species>
<Species>* Herbivore-induced systemic resistance occurs in many plants and is commonly assumed to be adaptive.</Species>

<Species>The mechanisms triggered by leaf-herbivores that lead to systemic resistance are largely understood, but it remains unknown how and why root herbivory also increases resistance in leaves.</Species>
<Species>* To resolve this, we investigated the mechanism by which the root herbivore Diabrotica virgifera induces resistance against lepidopteran herbivores in the leaves of Zea mays.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>*</Species>
<Species>Diabrotica virgifera infested plants suffered less aboveground herbivory in the field and showed reduced growth of Spodoptera littoralis caterpillars in the laboratory.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Root herbivory did not lead to a jasmonate-dependent response in the leaves, but specifically triggered water loss and abscisic acid (ABA) accumulation.</Species>
<Species>The induction of ABA by itself was partly responsible for the induction of leaf defenses, but not for the resistance against S. littoralis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Root-herbivore induced hydraulic changes in the leaves, however, were crucial for the increase in insect resistance.</Species>
<Species>* We conclude that the induced leaf resistance after root feeding is the result of hydraulic changes, which reduce the quality of the leaves for chewing herbivores.</Species>
<Species>This finding calls into question whether root-herbivore induced leaf-resistance is an evolved response.</Species>
<Species>Human resources for health in India.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>India has a severe shortage of human resources for health.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It has a shortage of qualified health workers and the workforce is concentrated in urban areas.</Species>
<Species>Bringing qualified health workers to rural, remote, and underserved areas is very challenging.</Species>
<Species>Many Indians, especially those living in rural areas, receive care from unqualified providers.</Species>
<Species>The migration of qualified allopathic doctors and nurses is substantial and further strains the system.</Species>
<Species>Nurses do not have much authority or say within the health system, and the resources to train them are still inadequate.</Species>

<Species>Little attention is paid during medical education to the medical and public health needs of the population, and the rapid privatisation of medical and nursing education has implications for its quality and governance.</Species>
<Species>Such issues are a result of underinvestment in and poor governance of the health sector--two issues that the government urgently needs to address.</Species>
<Species>A comprehensive national policy for human resources is needed to achieve universal health care in India.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The public sector will need to redesign appropriate packages of monetary and non-monetary incentives to encourage qualified health workers to work in rural and remote areas.</Species>

<Species>Such a policy might also encourage task-shifting and mainstreaming doctors and practitioners who practice traditional Indian medicine (ayurveda, yoga and naturopathy, unani, and siddha) and homoeopathy to work in these areas while adopting other innovative ways of augmenting human resources for health.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>At the same time, additional investments will be needed to improve the relevance, quantity, and quality of nursing, medical, and public health education in the country.</Species>

<Species>Differences in MinC/MinD sensitivity between polar and internal Z rings in Escherichia coli.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In Escherichia coli the Z ring has the potential to assemble anywhere along the cell length but is restricted to midcell by the action of negative regulatory systems, including Min.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the current model for the Min system, the MinC/MinD division inhibitory complex is evenly distributed on the membrane and can disrupt Z rings anywhere in the cell; however, MinE spatially regulates MinC/MinD by restricting it to the cell poles, thus allowing Z ring formation at midcell.</Species>

<Species>This model assumes that Z rings formed at different cellular locations have equal sensitivity to MinC/MinD in the absence of MinE. However, here we report evidence that differences in MinC/MinD sensitivity between polar and nonpolar Z rings exists even when there is no MinE. MinC/MinD at proper levels is able to block minicell production in Deltamin strains without increasing the cell length, indicating that polar Z rings are preferentially blocked.</Species>

<Species>In the FtsZ-I374V strain (which is resistant to MinC(C)/MinD), wild-type morphology can be easily achieved with MinC/MinD in the absence of MinE. We also show that MinC/MinD at proper levels can rescue the lethal phenotype of a min slmA double deletion mutant, which we think is due to the elimination of polar Z rings (or FtsZ structures), which frees up FtsZ molecules for assembly of Z rings at internal sites to rescue division and growth.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Taken together, these data indicate that polar Z rings are more susceptible to MinC/MinD than internal Z rings, even when MinE is absent.</Species>
<Species>Nitric oxide participates in cold-responsive phosphosphingolipid formation and gene expression in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Chilling triggers rapid molecular responses that permit the maintenance of plant cell homeostasis and plant adaptation.</Species>
<Species>Recent data showed that nitric oxide (NO) is involved in plant acclimation and tolerance to cold.</Species>
<Species>The participation of NO in the early transduction of the cold signal in Arabidopsis thaliana was investigated.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The production of NO after a short exposure to cold was assessed using the NO-sensitive fluorescent probe 4, 5-diamino fluoresceine diacetate and chemiluminescence.</Species>

<Species>Pharmacological and genetic approaches were used to analyze NO sources and NO-mediated changes in cold-regulated gene expression, phosphatidic acid (PtdOH) synthesis and sphingolipid phosphorylation.</Species>
<Species>NO production was detected after 1-4h of chilling.</Species>
<Species>It was impaired in the nia1nia2 nitrate reductase mutant.</Species>
<Species>Moreover, NO accumulation was not observed in H7 plants overexpressing the A. thaliana nonsymbiotic hemoglobin Arabidopsis haemoglobin 1 (AHb1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cold-regulated gene expression was affected in nia1nia2 and H7 plants.</Species>
<Species>The synthesis of PtdOH upon chilling was not modified by NO depletion.</Species>

<Species>By contrast, the formation of phytosphingosine phosphate and ceramide phosphate, two phosphorylated sphingolipids that are transiently synthesized upon chilling, was negatively regulated by NO.</Species>
<Species>Taken together, these data suggest a new function for NO as an intermediate in gene regulation and lipid-based signaling during cold transduction.</Species>
<Species>Climate effects on population fluctuations of the white-throated dipper Cinclus cinclus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Climate change may have profound consequences for many organisms.</Species>

<Species>We have studied fluctuations in a population of the white-throated dipper Cinclus cinclus during 31 years (1978-2008) in a river system in southern Norway in relation to both large-scale and local weather conditions occurring during the non-breeding season.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>2.</Species>
<Species>Multiple regression and partial least squares regression were used to model the growth rate of the population, accounting for population size in the previous year.</Species>

<Species>3. Population growth was influenced by North Atlantic Oscillation (NAO), mean winter temperature, precipitation and timing of ice formation on the main lake in the river system in autumn.</Species>
<Species>These variables explained 84% of the variation in population growth over the 31-year study period.</Species>
<Species>4. Local winter conditions played a prominent role in explaining the population fluctuations, which is plausible because the dipper depends on open water for foraging.</Species>
<Species>In the study area, winters can be harsh and rivers and lakes may freeze and severely affect the subsequent population size of the dipper in spring.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>The breeding population of the dipper does not seem yet to have reached a level where all possible territories in the area have been occupied, even after mild winters, and the estimated carrying capacity is also decidedly lower (66 breeding pairs) than the number of available territories.</Species>
<Species>If the trend of milder winters continues, the population might increase in the future.</Species>
<Species>However, strong climate variation is expected to continue in the future, and hence periods of rapid growth of the dipper population will probably be followed by severe declines.</Species>
<Species>Jasmonate biosynthesis in legume and actinorhizal nodules.</Species>
<Species>Jasmonic acid (JA) is a plant signalling compound that has been implicated in the regulation of mutualistic symbioses.</Species>

<Species>In order to understand the spatial distribution of JA biosynthetic capacity in nodules of two actinorhizal species, Casaurina glauca and Datisca glomerata, and one legume, Medicago truncatula, we determined the localization of allene oxide cyclase (AOC) which catalyses a committed step in JA biosynthesis.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In all nodule types analysed, AOC was detected exclusively in uninfected cells.</Species>
<Species>The levels of JA were compared in the roots and nodules of the three plant species.</Species>

<Species>The nodules and noninoculated roots of the two actinorhizal species, and the root systems of M. truncatula, noninoculated or nodulated with wild-type Sinorhizobium meliloti or with mutants unable to fix nitrogen, did not show significant differences in JA levels.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, JA levels in all plant organs examined increased significantly on mechanical disturbance.</Species>

<Species>To study whether JA played a regulatory role in the nodules of M. truncatula, composite plants containing roots expressing an MtAOC1-sense or MtAOC1-RNAi construct were inoculated with S. meliloti.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Neither an increase nor reduction in AOC levels resulted in altered nodule formation.</Species>
<Species>These data suggest that jasmonates are not involved in the development and function of root nodules.</Species>

text: <Species>In vitro, oocysts of both species are susceptible to the protease pepsin, and sporocysts and sporozoites can be excysted in a similar way.</Species>
<Species>Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) revealed a collapse of the oocysts wall at both polar ends after pepsin treatment.</Species>
<Species>This occurs without any visible damage of the outer wall.</Species>
<Species>Using fluorescence and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) we observed that pepsin enters sporulated oocysts at both polar ends and causes degradation of the inner oocyst wall.</Species>
<Species>Using scanning electron microscopy we could identify two polar caps in both investigated rodent Eimeria species, but only one is harbouring the micropyle.</Species>
<Species>Thus the polar caps are the entry site for the pepsin.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, we provide evidence that the oocyst cap and micropyle are functionally different structures.</Species>
<Species>This study complements the morphological description of both Eimeria species and is of relevance for other coccidian species.</Species>

text: <Species>This trait is controlled by a single recessive allele located at qCdT7.</Species>

<Species>El Nino in the warm tropics: local sea temperature predicts breeding parameters and growth of blue-footed boobies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>
<Species>There is increasing interest in the impacts of El Nino Southern Oscillation (ENSO) on reproduction of apical predators such as seabirds and marine mammals.</Species>

<Species>Long-term studies documenting ENSO effects on reproduction of seabirds in the warm tropics are scarce, and differential sensitivity of breeding parameters to ENSO has rarely been explored.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Analysis of 18 years of breeding data from a colony of the blue-footed booby Sula nebouxii (Milne-Edwards) showed a delay in onset of breeding when the global Southern Oscillation Index was negative; each unit of the atmospheric pressure differential (hPa) across the Pacific Ocean meant a delay of 7 days.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3. ENSO conditions also produced declines in breeding participation, clutch size, brood size, hatching success and fledging success, especially when surface waters surrounding the colony were warmer during winter and spring.</Species>
<Species>Each additional degree (^0C) of water temperature produced a reduction of 0.45 fledglings per nest.</Species>
<Species>Different breeding parameters were sensitive to ENSO indices in different blocks of months.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Warming of local waters during the winter was associated with decline in ocean productivity in the current year and the following year, consistent with ENSO impacts on breeding parameters being mediated by effects on local productivity and prey availability.</Species>
<Species>However, there was no evidence of lagged effects of ENSO on any breeding parameter.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Comparison of 5 years revealed that when local surface waters were warm, chicks grew more slowly, but no effects of ENSO on weight and size of eggs were evident in data of 9 and 7 years, respectively.</Species>

<Species>6. Our findings extend evidence of impacts of ENSO on seabird reproduction to the eastern tropical Pacific and indicate that several breeding parameters of blue-footed boobies (but not egg size) are affected in the short term by ENSO conditions, particularly by local anomalies in sea surface temperature associated with decline in ocean productivity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A small protein required for the switch from {sigma}F to {sigma}G during sporulation in Bacillus subtilis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A cascade of alternative sigma factors governs the program of developmental gene expression during sporulation in Bacillus subtilis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Little is known, however, about how the early-acting sigma factors are inactivated and replaced by the later-acting factors.</Species>

<Species>Here we identify a small protein, Fin (formerly known as YabK), that is required for efficient switching from sigma(F)- to sigma(G)-directed gene expression in the forespore compartment of the developing sporangium.</Species>
<Species>The fin gene, which is conserved among Bacillus species and species of related genera, is transcribed in the forespore under the control of both sigma(F) and sigma(G).</Species>
<Species>Cells mutant for fin are unable to fully deactivate sigma(F) and, conversely, are unable to fully activate sigma(G).</Species>

<Species>Consistent with their deficiency in sigma(G)-directed gene expression, fin cells are arrested in large numbers following the engulfment stage of sporulation, ultimately forming 50-fold fewer heat-resistant spores than the wild type.</Species>

<Species>Based in part on the similarity of Fin to the anti-sigma(G) factor CsfB (also called Gin), we speculate that Fin is an anti-sigma(F) factor which, by disabling sigma(F), promotes the switch to late developmental gene expression in the forespore.</Species>
<Species>Evaluation of an immunoglobulin M-specific capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay for rapid diagnosis of dengue infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Various assays have been developed to diagnose dengue virus infection, relying on techniques from the fields of serology and molecular biology.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Many of these assays have been successful, but there is still an urgent need for accurate, simple and rapid diagnostic assays to diagnose dengue virus infection and to assist in patient management.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Using a panel of well-characterized sera and a collection of retrospective samples obtained during the dengue epidemics that occurred in Belem, Brazil, between 2002 and 2009, a modified immunoglobulin M-specific capture enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (Rapid-MAC-ELISA) was evaluated and compared with the "gold standard" MAC-ELISA, in order to assess the specificity, sensitivity, stability, reproducibility and cost-effectiveness of this new assay.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results demonstrated that the Rapid-MAC-ELISA is comparable to the MAC-ELISA in terms of sensitivity and specificity and is highly reproducible; additionally, it is easily performed, less expensive than other available formats and can be completed within three hours.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, the Rapid-MAC-ELISA can be used for the diagnosis of dengue virus infections in resource-limited areas where dengue is endemic.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Soil nutrient status determines how elephant utilize trees and shape environments.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Elucidation of the mechanism determining the spatial scale of patch selection by herbivores has been complicated by the way in which resource availability at a specific scale is measured and by vigilance behaviour of the herbivores themselves.</Species>
<Species>To reduce these complications, we studied patch selection by an animal with negligible predation risk, the African elephant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2.</Species>
<Species>We introduce the concept of nutrient load as the product of patch size, number of patches and local patch nutrient concentration.</Species>
<Species>Nutrient load provides a novel spatially explicit expression of the total available nutrients a herbivore can select from.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We hypothesized that elephant would select nutrient-rich patches, based on the nutrient load per 2500 m(2) down to the individual plant scale, and that this selection will depend on the nitrogen and phosphorous contents of plants.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We predicted that elephant would cause more adverse impact to trees of lower value to them in order to reach plant parts with higher nutrient concentrations such as bark and root.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, elephant should maintain nutrient-rich trees by inducing coppicing of trees through re-utilization of leaves.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5. Elephant patch selection was measured in a homogenous tree species stand by manipulating the spatial distribution of soil nutrients in a large field experiment using NPK fertilizer.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>6.</Species>
<Species>Elephant were able to select nutrient-rich patches and utilized Colophospermum mopane trees inside these patches more than outside, at scales ranging from 2500 down to 100 m(2) .</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>7.</Species>

<Species>Although both nitrogen and phosphorus contents of leaves from C. mopane trees were higher in fertilized and selected patches, patch choice correlated most strongly with nitrogen content.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>As predicted, stripping of leaves occurred more in nutrient-rich patches, while adverse impact such as uprooting of trees occurred more in nutrient-poor areas.</Species>
<Species>8.</Species>

<Species>Our results emphasize the necessity of including scale-dependent selectivity in foraging studies and how elephant foraging behaviour can be used as indicators of change in the availability of nutrients.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Acyl-homoserine lactone binding to and stability of the orphan Pseudomonas aeruginosa quorum-sensing signal receptor QscR.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Pseudomonas aeruginosa transcription factor QscR responds to a variety of fatty acyl-homoserine lactones (HSLs), including N-3-oxododecanoyl-HSL (3OC12-HSL), which is produced and detected by the P. aeruginosa quorum-sensing circuit LasI and LasR. As is true for LasR and many other acyl-HSL-dependent transcription factors, production of soluble QscR in sufficient amounts for purification requires growth of recombinant bacteria in the presence of an appropriate acyl-HSL. QscR is thought to bind 3OC12-HSL relatively weakly compared to LasR, and unlike LasR, binding of purified QscR to target DNA was shown to strongly depend on exogenously added 3OC12-HSL.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We show that purified QscR is dimeric at sufficiently high concentrations and monomeric at lower concentrations.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, QscR bound 3OC12-HSL more tightly than previously believed.</Species>
<Species>Purified QscR retained 3OC12-HSL, and at sufficiently high concentrations, it bound target DNA in the absence of added 3OC12-HSL.</Species>

<Species>We also obtained soluble QscR from recombinant Escherichia coli grown in the presence of N-3-oxohexanoyl-HSL (3OC6-HSL) instead of 3OC12-HSL, and because 3OC6-HSL bound much more loosely to QscR than other acyl-HSLs tested, we were able to exchange 3OC6-HSL with other acyl-HSLs in vitro and then estimate binding affinities of QscR for different acyl-HSLs and for target DNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our data support a model whereby QscR polypeptides fold properly in the absence of an acyl-HSL, but soluble, acyl-HSL-free QscR does not accumulate because it is subject to rapid aggregation or proteolysis.</Species>
<Species>Short-Term Population Redistribution of Pseudacteon tricuspis (Diptera: Phoridae) From Point Source Releases.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>There is a need for quantitative data on patterns and rates of movement of organisms to understand their movement behavior and predict their rates of spread.</Species>
<Species>Opportunities for studying movement of biological control agents are presented during release programs.</Species>
<Species>However, despite these opportunities, patterns and range of dispersal are often not considered.</Species>

<Species>For example, information about effects of wind on dispersal patterns and heterogeneities in rates of movement is critical to predicting future range expansion of biological control agents and determining proximity of multiple releases.</Species>
<Species>Here, the pattern and range of movement of a fire ant parasitoid, Pseudacteon tricuspis Borgmeier, was investigated by performing a series of mass-release-resighting experiments.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Flies were released at a central location surrounded by radial transects containing trays of host ants at variable distances along four axes.</Species>
<Species>Resighted flies were censused at these trays at 30 min intervals, up to 2 h postrelease.</Species>
<Species>The dispersal pattern of P. tricuspis in the short term was consistent with a simple diffusion model.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>On average, 50% of P. tricuspis dispersed =<10 m, and 95% dispersed =<29 m. Diffusion rates were variable, depending on release densities, but tended to decline over time after release.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Drift of dispersing flies was detected in several trials, and was attributed to prevailing wind dynamics.</Species>
<Species>Data from this assessment of the short term redistribution pattern of P. tricuspis could be useful in determining proximity of releases of this, and other fire ant parasitoids.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Detection of Tomato black ring virus by real-time one-step RT-PCR.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A TaqMan-based real-time one-step RT-PCR assay was developed for the rapid detection of Tomato black ring virus (TBRV), a significant plant pathogen which infects a wide range of economically important crops.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Primers and a probe were designed against existing genomic sequences to amplify a 72 bp fragment from RNA-2.</Species>
<Species>The assay amplified all isolates of TBRV tested, but no amplification was observed from the RNA of other nepovirus species or healthy host plants.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The detection limit of the assay was estimated to be around nine copies of the TBRV target region in total RNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A comparison with conventional RT-PCR and ELISA, indicated that ELISA, the current standard test method, lacked specificity and reacted to all nepovirus species tested, while conventional RT-PCR was approximately ten-fold less sensitive than the real-time RT-PCR assay.</Species>

<Species>Finally, the real-time RT-PCR assay was tested using five different RT-PCR reagent kits and was found to be robust and reliable, with no significant differences in sensitivity being found.</Species>
<Species>The development of this rapid assay should aid in quarantine and post-border surveys for regulatory agencies.</Species>
<Species>Projectin PEVK domain, splicing variants and domain structure in basal and derived insects.</Species>
<Species>The third elastic filament of striated muscles consists of giant proteins: titin (in vertebrates) and kettin/projectin (in insects).</Species>
<Species>In all three proteins, elasticity is at least partly associated with the so-called PEVK domain.</Species>
<Species>The projectin PEVK domains of diverse insects are highly divergent compared with an otherwise conserved protein organization.</Species>
<Species>We present the characterization of the PEVK domain in two dragonflies and in human lice.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A conserved segment at the end of the PEVK, the NH(2)-terminal conserved segment-1 (NTCS-1), may serve as an anchor point for projectin to either myosin or actin, providing a mechanical link.</Species>

<Species>The analysis of alternative splicing variants identifies the shortest PEVK isoform as the predominant form in the flight muscles of several insects, possibly contributing to myofibrillar stiffness.</Species>
<Species>PsOr1, a potential target for RNA interference-based pest management.</Species>

<Species>Insect pests cause billions of dollars in agricultural losses, and attempts to kill them have resulted in growing threats from insecticide resistance, dietary pesticide pollution and environmental destruction.</Species>
<Species>New approaches to control refractory insect pests are therefore needed.</Species>
<Species>The host-plant preferences of insect pests rely on olfaction and are mediated via a seven transmembrane-domain odorant receptor (Or) family.</Species>

<Species>The present study reports the cloning and characterization of PsOr1, the first candidate member of the Or gene family from Phyllotreta striolata, a devastating beetle pest that causes damage worldwide.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>PsOr1 is remarkably well conserved with respect to other insect orthologues, including DmOr83b from Drosophila melanogaster.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These insect orthologues form an essential non-conventional Or sub-family and may play an important and generalized role in insect olfaction.</Species>
<Species>We designed double-stranded (ds) RNA directly against the PsOr1 gene and exploited RNA interference (RNAi) to control P. striolata.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The chemotactic behavioural measurements showed that adult beetles were unable to sense the attractant or repellent odour stimulus after microinjection of dsRNA against PsOr1.</Species>
<Species>Reverse Transcription (RT)-PCR analysis showed specific down-regulation of mRNA transcript levels for this gene.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, host-plant preference experiments confirmed that silencing PsOr1 by RNAi treatment impaired the host-plant preferences of P. striolata for cruciferous vegetables.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These results demonstrate that this insect control approach of using RNAi to target PsOr1 and its orthologues might be effective in blocking host-plant-seeking behaviours in diverse insect pests.</Species>
<Species>The results also support the theory that this unique receptor type plays an essential general role in insect olfaction.</Species>
<Species>Sunflower stem weevil and its larval parasitoids in native sunflowers: is parasitoid abundance and diversity greater in the u.s. Southwest?</Species>
<Species>Classical biological control programs often target a pest's region of origin as a likely source for new biological control agents.</Species>

<Species>Here, we use this approach to search for biological control agents of the sunflower stem weevil (Cylindrocopturus adspersus LeConte), an economically important pest of commercial sunflower.</Species>

<Species>We conducted surveys of weevil natural enemy diversity and abundance across a transect running from the northern Great Plains to the southwestern U.S. (the presumed area of endemism of annual sunflower species in the genus Helianthus).</Species>

<Species>Accordingly, natural enemy diversity and abundance were expected to be greater in the southwestern U.S. C. adspersus and their larval parasitoids were collected from stems of four native sunflower species (Helianthus annuus, H. nuttallii, H. pauciflorus, and H. petiolaris) from 147 sites across eight states.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Native H. annuus constituted the majority of the sunflower populations.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Mean weevil densities were significantly higher in sunflower stalks that were larger in diameter.</Species>
<Species>Mean weevil densities within sites did not differ across the range of longitudes and latitudes sampled.</Species>
<Species>After accounting for the effects of stalk diameter and location, weevil densities did not differ among the four sunflower species nor did they differ as a function of elevation.</Species>
<Species>C. adspersus in H. annuus and H. petiolaris were attacked by seven species of parasitoids.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>No parasitoids were found attacking C. adspersus in H. nuttallii or H. pauciflorus stalks.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>C. adspersus were twice as likely to be attacked by a parasitoid when feeding on H. petiolaris than H. annuus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, the likelihood that C. adspersus would be parasitized decreased with increasing elevation and increasing stem diameters.</Species>
<Species>All parasitoid species have been previously reported attacking C. adspersus larvae in cultivated sunflower.</Species>
<Species>Species richness was less diverse in these collections than from previous studies of cultivated sunflower.</Species>
<Species>Our findings suggest that the species of larval parasitoids attacking C. adspersus in native sunflowers have successfully made the transition to cultivated sunflower.</Species>
<Species>Synganglion transcriptome and developmental global gene expression in adult females of the American dog tick, Dermacentor variabilis (Acari: Ixodidae).</Species>

text: <Species>454 Pyrosequencing was used to characterize the expressed genes from the synganglion and associated neurosecretory organs of unfed and partially fed virgin and mated replete females of the American dog tick, Dermacentor variabilis.</Species>
label: Species
