Species

text: <Species>Three protozoal cultivation media were tested to determine the medium which best facilitated growth and viability of key B-type ciliates isolated from the sheep rumen.</Species>
<Species>Entodinium caudatum and Eudiplodinium maggii were grown anaerobically in 50-ml flasks for 32 days in Caudatum-type (C), Kisidayova (K) or Dehority (M) medium.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>On day 32, in media K and M, E. caudatum cell counts were high with 5.6x10(3) and 7.8x10(3) mL(-1), respectively, and the proportion of dead cells was low with 0.6 and 1.4%, respectively.</Species>

text: <Species>E. maggii concentrations when grown in medium M and C were 2.7x10(3) and 2.4x10(3) mL(-1), respectively, with 3.9 and 14.1% dead cells.</Species>

text: <Species>Medium M, which favoured growth of both protozoa species, was tested again and Epidinium ecaudatum was included.</Species>

text: <Species>Protozoa were grown for a 4-month period and samples were taken in the last two months on days 1, 7, 35 and 57.</Species>
<Species>Average cell concentrations were 10.0, 0.8 and 0.5x10(3) mL(-1) for E. caudatum, E. maggii, and E. ecaudatum, respectively.</Species>
label: Species

Species

text: <Species>In conclusion, medium M would appear to be the best choice for cultivating these three species in one medium.</Species>
<Species>Gene expression analysis of wounding-induced root-to-shoot communication in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Root-to-shoot communication plays an important role in the adaptation to environmental stress.</Species>
<Species>In this study, we established a model system for root-to-shoot signalling to observe global gene expression in Arabidopsis thaliana.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The roots of Arabidopsis seedlings were wounded and the expression in the shoots of 68 and 5 genes was up-regulated threefold at 30 min and 6 h post-injury, respectively.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These genes were designated early and late Root-to-Shoot responsive (RtS) genes, respectively.</Species>
<Species>Many of the early RtS genes were found to encode transcription factors such as AtERFs, whereas others were associated with jasmonic acid (JA) and ethylene (ET).</Species>
<Species>Some of the late RtS genes were shown to be regulated by 12-oxo-phytodienoic acid (OPDA).</Species>
<Species>In fact, elevated levels of JA and OPDA were detected in the shoots of seedlings 30 min and 6 h, respectively, after wounding of the roots.</Species>
<Species>A mutant analysis revealed that JA and ET are involved in the expression of the early RtS genes.</Species>
<Species>Thus, root-to-shoot communication for many RtS genes is associated with the systemic production of JA, OPDA and possibly ET.</Species>

<Species>Simian immunodeficiency virus from the sooty mangabey and rhesus macaque is modified with O-linked carbohydrate.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Although stretches of serine and threonine are sometimes sites for O-linked carbohydrate attachment, specific sequence and structural determinants for O-linked attachment remain ill defined.</Species>
<Species>The gp120 envelope protein of SIVmac239 contains a serine-threonine-rich stretch of amino acids at positions 128 to 139.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here we show that lectin protein from jackfruit seed (jacalin), which binds to non- and monosialylated core 1 O-linked carbohydrate, potently inhibited the replication of SIVmac239.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Selection of a jacalin-resistant SIVmac239 variant population resulted in virus with specific substitutions within amino acids 128 to 139.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cloned simian immunodeficiency virus (SIV) variants with substitutions in the 128-to-139 region had infectivities equivalent to, or within 1 log unit of, that of SIVmac239 and were resistant to the inhibitory effects of jacalin.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Characterization of the SIVmac239 gp120 O-linked glycome showed the presence of core 1 and core 2 O-linked carbohydrate; a 128-to-139-substituted variant gp120 from jacalin-resistant SIV lacked O-linked carbohydrate.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Unlike that of SIVmac239, the replication of HIV-1 strain NL4-3 was resistant to inhibition by jacalin.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Purified gp120s from four SIVmac and SIVsm strains bound jacalin strongly in an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, while nine different HIV-1 gp120s, two SIVcpz gp120s, and 128-to-139-substituted SIVmac239 gp120 did not bind jacalin.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The ability or inability to bind jacalin thus correlated with the presence of the serine-threonine-rich stretch in the SIVmac and SIVsm gp120s and the absence of such stretches in the SIVcpz and HIV-1 gp120s.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Consistent with sequence predictions, two HIV-2 gp120s bound jacalin, while one did not.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These data demonstrate the presence of non- and monosialylated core 1 O-linked carbohydrate on the gp120s of SIVmac and SIVsm and the lack of these modifications on HIV-1 and SIVcpz gp120s.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Complex regulation of symbiotic functions is coordinated by MucR and quorum sensing in Sinorhizobium meliloti.</Species>

<Species>In Sinorhizobium meliloti, the production of exopolysaccharides such as succinoglycan and exopolysaccharide II (EPS II) enables the bacterium to invade root nodules on Medicago sativa and establish a nitrogen-fixing symbiosis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>While extensive research has focused on succinoglycan, less is known concerning the regulation of EPS II or the mechanism by which it mediates entrance into the host plant.</Species>
<Species>Previously, we reported that the ExpR/Sin quorum-sensing system is required to produce the symbiotically active low-molecular-weight fraction of this exopolysaccharide.</Species>

<Species>Here, we show that this system induces EPS II production by increasing expression of the expG-expC operon, encoding both a transcriptional regulator (ExpG) and a glycosyl transferase (ExpC).</Species>

<Species>ExpG derepresses EPS II production at the transcriptional level from MucR, a RosR homolog, while concurrently elevating expression of expC, resulting in the synthesis of the low-molecular-weight form.</Species>

<Species>While the ExpR/Sin system abolishes the role of MucR on EPS II production, it preserves a multitude of other quorum-sensing-independent regulatory functions which promote the establishment of symbiosis.</Species>

<Species>In planktonic S. meliloti, MucR properly coordinates a diverse set of bacterial behaviors by repressing a variety of genes intended for expression during symbiosis and enhancing the bacterial ability to induce root nodule formation.</Species>

<Species>Quorum sensing precisely modulates the functions of MucR to take advantage of both the production of symbiotically active EPS II as well as the proper coordination of bacterial behavior required to promote symbiosis.</Species>

<Species>Comparative Impact of Artificial Selection for Fungicide Resistance on Beauveria bassiana and Metarhizium brunneum.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Hypocreales fungi such as Beauveria bassiana (Balsamo) Vuillemin and Metarhizium brunneum Petch can be negatively affected by fungicides thereby reducing their biocontrol potential.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In a previous study, we demonstrated enhanced fungicide resistance in B. bassiana through artificial selection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, it is not clear if the enhanced resistance was because of improved germination, vegetative growth, or both.</Species>

<Species>Additionally, the enhanced fungicide resistance has only been demonstrated in B. bassiana, and therefore it is of interest to investigate the potential to enhance resistance in other fungi.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Thus, the objectives in this study were to determine the potential to enhance fungicide resistance in M. brunneum through artificial selection, and investigate if selection is based on germination, vegetative growth, or both in B. bassiana and M. brunneum.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Selection for resistance to fenbuconazole, and triphenyltin hydroxide was assessed through inhibition evaluations on solid media, and germination and mycelial growth in liquid media.</Species>
<Species>Increased resistance after selection was observed for all fungicide-fungus combinations on solid and or liquid media.</Species>

<Species>Selection resulted in increased resistance to fenbuconazole in both fungi in solid and liquid media; in liquid culture fungicide resistance in B. bassiana was manifested by increased germination and mycelial growth, whereas in M. brunneum fungicide resistance concerned only mycelial growth.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Selection for resistance to triphenyltin hydroxide varied in the different media.</Species>
<Species>For B. bassiana, triphenyltin hydroxide resistance was enhanced on solid media but not in liquid, whereas enhanced resistance of M. brunneum was detected in both media.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Fungicide sensitivity and selection potential differs based on the medium and fungal species.</Species>

<Species>Selection for fungicide resistance, had negative effects on other beneficial traits when fungicide pressure was removed, for example, some selected populations showed decreased germination or growth, relative to their nonselected control populations.</Species>
<Species>Additionally, reduced virulence to the greater wax moth, Galleria mellonella (L.), was observed in all fungal populations that were exposed to fungicide resistance regimes.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We conclude that it is possible to use genetic selection to enhance fungicide resistance in B. bassiana and M. brunneum, but before use the resulting populations should be screened for inadvertent negative impacts on beneficial traits.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Multiplex RT-PCR for rapid detection and differentiation of class I and class II Newcastle disease viruses.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A multiplex RT-PCR was developed for detection and differentiation of class I and class II strains of Newcastle disease virus (NDV).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The method was shown to have high specificity and sensitivity.</Species>

<Species>The results obtained from the multiplex RT-PCR for a total of 67 NDV field isolates obtained in 2009 were consistent with those obtained by nucleotide sequencing and phylogenetic analysis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>A phylogenetic tree based on the partial sequences of the F gene revealed that the 67 field isolates of NDV could be divided into two classes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Twenty-seven NDV isolates were grouped into class I, and two genotypes were identified.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Most of the class I isolates were determined to be of genotype 3, with the exception of isolate NDV09-034, which belonged to genotype 2.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Forty class II NDV isolates were divided into three genotypes, namely genotype VII (27 isolates), genotype I (2 isolates) and genotype II (11 isolates).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Isolates of genotypes I and II in class II were shown to be related to commercial vaccine strains used commonly in China.</Species>
<Species>All isolates of genotype VII were predicted to be virulent, on the basis of the sequence motif at the cleavage site of the F gene.</Species>
<Species>This genotype has become predominantly responsible for most outbreaks of ND in China in recent years.</Species>
<Species>In conclusion, this multiplex RT-PCR provides a new assay for rapid detection and differentiation of both classes of NDV isolates.</Species>

text: <Species>Antibiotics and UV radiation induce competence for natural transformation in Legionella pneumophila.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Natural transformation by competence is a major mechanism of horizontal gene transfer in bacteria.</Species>
<Species>Competence is defined as the genetically programmed physiological state that enables bacteria to actively take up DNA from the environment.</Species>
<Species>The conditions that signal competence development are multiple and elusive, complicating the understanding of its evolutionary significance.</Species>

<Species>We used expression of the competence gene comEA as a reporter of competence development and screened several hundred molecules for their ability to induce competence in the freshwater living pathogen Legionella pneumophila.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that comEA expression is induced by chronic exposure to genotoxic molecules such as mitomycin C and antibiotics of the fluoroquinolone family.</Species>
<Species>These results indicated that, in L. pneumophila, competence may be a response to genotoxic stress.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Sunlight-emitted UV light represents a major source of genotoxic stress in the environment and we found that exposure to UV radiation effectively induces competence development.</Species>
<Species>For the first time, we show that genetic exchanges by natural transformation occur within an UV-stressed population.</Species>
<Species>Genotoxic stress induces the RecA-dependent SOS response in many bacteria.</Species>
<Species>However, genetic and phenotypic evidence suggest that L. pneumophila lacks a prototypic SOS response and competence development in response to genotoxic stress is RecA independent.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our results strengthen the hypothesis that competence may have evolved as a DNA damage response in SOS-deficient bacteria.</Species>
<Species>This parasexual response to DNA damage may have enabled L. pneumophila to acquire and propagate foreign genes, contributing to the emergence of this human pathogen.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Cryptococcus neoformans is a heterothallic basidiomycete that grows vegetatively as yeast and filamentous hyphae are produced in the sexual state.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>Previous studies have shown that C. neoformans Cwc1 and Cwc2 are two central photoregulators which form a complex to inhibit the production of sexual filaments upon light treatment.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To reveal the detailed regulatory mechanisms, a genome wide mutagenesis screen was conducted and components in the Cwc1/Cwc2 complex mediated pathway have been identified.</Species>

<Species>In this study, one suppressor mutant, DJ22, is characterized and T-DNA is found to disrupt the C. neoformans CRK1 gene, a homologue of Saccharomyces cerevisiae IME2 and Ustilago maydis crk1.</Species>

text: <Species>Ime2 is a meiosis-specific gene with the conserved Ser/Thr kinase domain and TXY dual phosphorylation site.</Species>
<Species>Consistent with the findings of other suppressors in our screen, C. neoformans Crk1 plays a negative role in the mating process.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Dikaryotic filaments, basidia, and basidiospores are produced earlier in the crk1 mutant crosses and mating efficiency is also increased.</Species>
<Species>Artificial elevation of the CRK1 mRNA level inhibits mating.</Species>
<Species>Interestingly, monokaryotic fruiting is defective both in the MATalpha crk1 mutant and CRK1 overexpression strains.</Species>
<Species>Our studies demonstrate that C. neoformans CRK1 gene functions as a negative regulator in the mating differentiation.</Species>

text: <Species>Detection and quantitation of infectious human adenoviruses and JC polyomaviruses in water by immunofluorescence assay.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Human adenoviruses (HAdV) and JC polyomaviruses (JCPyV) have been proposed as markers of fecal/urine contamination of human origin.</Species>
label: Species

Species

text: <Species>An indirect immunofluorescence assay has been developed to quantify infectious human adenoviruses types 2 and 41 and JC polyomaviruses strain Mad-4 in water samples.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The immunofluorescence assay was compared with other quantitative techniques used commonly such as plaque assay, tissue culture infectious dose-50 and quantitative PCR (qPCR).</Species>
<Species>The immunofluorescence assays showed to be specific for the detection of infectious viruses, obtaining negative results when UV or heat-inactivated viruses were analyzed.</Species>
<Species>The assays required less time and showed higher sensitivity for the detection of infectious viral particles than other cell culture techniques (1 log(10) more) evaluated.</Species>
<Species>River water samples spiked previously with human adenoviruses and raw sewage samples were also analyzed using the proposed immunofluorescence assay as well as by qPCR.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The results show quantitations with 2 log(10) reduction in the numbers of infectious viruses compared with the number of genome copies detected by qPCR.</Species>
<Species>The immunofluorescence assay developed is fast, sensitive, specific, and a standardizable technique for the quantitation and detection of infectious viruses in water samples.</Species>

<Species>Cataloging and profiling genes expressed in Lentinula edodes fruiting body by massive cDNA pyrosequencing and LongSAGE.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This study investigated the molecular mechanism of the fruiting body development and sporulation in the cap of the Shiitake mushroom, Lentinula edodes.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Although there has been much research into L. edodes, there remain significant gaps in our knowledge of how the species reproduces.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In order to provide molecular resources and to understand the molecular mechanism of the fruiting body development in basidiomycete comprehensively, we searched for the genes which are important for fruiting body development and sporulation in the cap of mature fruiting body of L. edodes by using the whole-genome approach.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Massive cDNA pyrosequencing was used to generate >7000 sequence contigs from mature fruiting bodies.</Species>
<Species>We used Gene Ontology to categorize the contigs to form the catalog of genes expressed at the stage of the mature fruiting body.</Species>
<Species>We also assigned the contigs into the KEGG pathways.</Species>

<Species>The catalog of expressed genes indicates that the mature fruiting bodies (1) sense the external environment, (2) transmit signals to express genes through regulatory systems, (3) produce many proteins, (4) degrade unwanted proteins, (5) perform extensive biosynthesis, (6) generate energy, (7) regulate the internal environment, (8) transport molecules, (9) carry out cell division, and (10) differentiate and develop.</Species>

<Species>After establishing the catalog of expressed genes in L. edodes, we used the LongSAGE approach to analyze the expression levels of genes found in mature fruiting bodies before (FB) and after (FBS) spores appeared.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Gene-expression patterns according to GO categories were similar in these two stages.</Species>
<Species>We have also successfully identified genes differentially expressed in FB and FBS.</Species>
<Species>Fold-changes in expression levels of selected genes based on LongSAGE tag counts were similar to those obtained by real-time RT-PCR.</Species>
<Species>The consistency between real-time RT-PCR and LongSAGE results indicates reliability of the LongSAGE results.</Species>

<Species>Overall, this study provides valuable information on the fruiting processes of L. edodes through a combination of massive cDNA pyrosequencing and LongSAGE sequencing, and the knowledge thereby obtained may provide insight into the improvement of the yield of commercially grown Shiitake mushrooms.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The effects of dsRNA mycoviruses on growth and murine virulence of Aspergillus fumigatus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Some isolates of the opportunistic human pathogenic fungus Aspergillus fumigatus are known to be infected with mycoviruses.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The dsRNA genomes of two of these mycoviruses, which include a chrysovirus and a partitivirus, have been completely sequenced and an RT-PCR assay for the viruses has been developed.</Species>

<Species>Through curing virus-infected A. fumigatus isolates by cycloheximide treatment and transfecting virus-free isolates with purified virus, as checked by RT-PCR, isogenic virus-free and virus-infected lines of the fungus were generated whose phenotypes and growth have been directly compared.</Species>

<Species>Modulation of fungal sensitivity to staurosporine by targeting proteins identified by transcriptional profiling.</Species>
<Species>An analysis of the time-dependent genetic response to the death-inducer staurosporine was performed in Neurospora crassa by transcriptional profiling.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Staurosporine induced two major genes encoding an ABC transporter and a protein with similarity to regulatory subunits of potassium channels.</Species>
<Species>The transcriptional response is dependent on the activity of a novel transcription factor.</Species>
<Species>Deletion mutants in differentially expressed genes displayed altered sensitivity to staurosporine, underscoring significant proteins involved in the response to the drug.</Species>

<Species>A null-mutant of the ABC transporter (abc3) is extremely sensitive to staurosporine, accumulates more staurosporine than the wild type strain and is defective in energy-dependent export of the drug, indicating that the ABC3 protein is the first described staurosporine transporter.</Species>
<Species>It was located in the plasma membrane by immunofluorescence microscopy.</Species>

<Species>The combination of inhibitors of ABC transporters or of potassium channels with staurosporine leads to an enhanced activity against N. crassa and pathogenic fungi paving the way to the development of more potent and specific antifungals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our results highlight the general use of transcriptional profiling for the identification of novel proteins involved in cell death and their potential use as drug targets.</Species>
<Species>Clinical management of Staphylococcus aureus bacteraemia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Staphylococcus aureus bacteraemia is one of the most common serious bacterial infections worldwide.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the UK alone, around 12,500 cases each year are reported, with an associated mortality of about 30%, yet the evidence guiding optimum management is poor.</Species>
<Species>To date, fewer than 1500 patients with S aureus bacteraemia have been recruited to 16 controlled trials of antimicrobial therapy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Consequently, clinical practice is driven by the results of observational studies and anecdote.</Species>
<Species>Here, we propose and review ten unanswered clinical questions commonly posed by those managing S aureus bacteraemia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our findings define the major areas of uncertainty in the management of S aureus bacteraemia and highlight just two key principles.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>First, all infective foci must be identified and removed as soon as possible.</Species>
<Species>Second, long-term antimicrobial therapy is required for those with persistent bacteraemia or a deep, irremovable focus.</Species>

<Species>Beyond this, the best drugs, dose, mode of delivery, and duration of therapy are uncertain, a situation compounded by emerging S aureus strains that are resistant to old and new antibiotics.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We discuss the consequences on clinical practice, and how these findings define the agenda for future clinical research.</Species>
<Species>Spiral architecture of the nucleoid in Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We present a cryo-electron tomographic analysis of the three-dimensional architecture of a strain of the Gram-negative bacterium Bdellovibrio bacteriovorus in which endogenous MreB2 was replaced with monomeric teal fluorescent protein (mTFP)-labeled MreB2.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast to wild-type Bdellovibrio cells that predominantly displayed a compact nucleoid region, cells expressing mTFP-labeled MreB2 displayed a twisted spiral organization of the nucleoid.</Species>
<Species>The more open structure of the MreB2-mTFP nucleoids enabled clear in situ visualization of ribosomes decorating the periphery of the nucleoid.</Species>
<Species>Ribosomes also bordered the edges of more compact nucleoids from both wild-type cells and mutant cells.</Species>

<Species>Surprisingly, MreB2-mTFP localized to the interface between the spiral nucleoid and the cytoplasm, suggesting an intimate connection between nucleoid architecture and MreB arrangement.</Species>

<Species>Further, in contrast to wild-type cells, where a single tight chemoreceptor cluster localizes close to the single polar flagellum, MreB2-mTFP cells often displayed extended chemoreceptor arrays present at one or both poles and displayed multiple or inaccurately positioned flagella.</Species>

<Species>Our findings provide direct structural evidence for spiral organization of the bacterial nucleoid and suggest a possible role for MreB in regulation of nucleoid architecture and localization of the chemotaxis apparatus.</Species>
<Species>High homologous gene conservation despite extreme autopolyploid redundancy in sugarcane.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Modern sugarcane (Saccharum spp.) is the leading sugar crop and a primary energy crop.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>It has the highest level of 'vertical' redundancy (2n=12x=120) of all polyploid plants studied to date.</Species>
<Species>It was produced about a century ago through hybridization between two autopolyploid species, namely S. officinarum and S. spontaneum.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In order to investigate the genome dynamics in this highly polyploid context, we sequenced and compared seven hom(oe)ologous haplotypes (bacterial artificial chromosome clones).</Species>
<Species>Our analysis revealed a high level of gene retention and colinearity, as well as high gene structure and sequence conservation, with an average sequence divergence of 4% for exons.</Species>

<Species>Remarkably, all of the hom(oe)ologous genes were predicted as being functional (except for one gene fragment) and showed signs of evolving under purifying selection, with the exception of genes within segmental duplications.</Species>

<Species>By contrast, transposable elements displayed a general absence of colinearity among hom(oe)ologous haplotypes and appeared to have undergone dynamic expansion in Saccharum, compared with sorghum, its close relative in the Andropogonea tribe.</Species>
<Species>These results reinforce the general trend emerging from recent studies indicating the diverse and nuanced effect of polyploidy on genome dynamics.</Species>
<Species>The alphaherpesvirus US3/ORF66 protein kinases direct phosphorylation of the nuclear matrix protein matrin 3.</Species>

<Species>The protein kinase found in the short region of alphaherpesviruses, termed US3 in herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1) and pseudorabies virus (PRV) and ORF66 in varicella-zoster virus (VZV), affects several viral and host cell processes, and its specific targets remain an area of active investigation.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Reports suggesting that HSV-1 US3 substrates overlap with those of cellular protein kinase A (PKA) prompted the use of an antibody specific for phosphorylated PKA substrates to identify US3/ORF66 targets.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>HSV-1, VZV, and PRV induced very different substrate profiles that were US3/ORF66 kinase dependent.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The predominant VZV-phosphorylated 125-kDa species was identified as matrin 3, one of the major nuclear matrix proteins.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Matrin 3 was also phosphorylated by HSV-1 and PRV in a US3 kinase-dependent manner and by VZV ORF66 kinase at a novel residue (KRRRT150EE).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Since VZV-directed T150 phosphorylation was not blocked by PKA inhibitors and was not induced by PKA activation, and since PKA predominantly targeted matrin 3 S188, it was concluded that phosphorylation by VZV was PKA independent.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, purified VZV ORF66 kinase did not phosphorylate matrin 3 in vitro, suggesting that additional cellular factors were required.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In VZV-infected cells in the absence of the ORF66 kinase, matrin 3 displayed intranuclear changes, while matrin 3 showed a pronounced cytoplasmic distribution in late-stage cells infected with US3-negative HSV-1 or PRV.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>This work identifies phosphorylation of the nuclear matrix protein matrin 3 as a new conserved target of this kinase group.</Species>
<Species>Fitness effects of endemic malaria infections in a wild bird population: the importance of ecological structure.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Parasites can have important effects on host populations influencing either fecundity or mortality, but understanding the magnitude of these effects in endemic host-parasite systems is challenging and requires an understanding of ecological processes affecting both host and parasite.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>Avian blood parasites (Haemoproteus and Plasmodium) have been much studied, but the effects of these parasites on hosts in areas where they are endemic remains poorly known.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We used a multistate modelling framework to explore the effects of chronic infection with Plasmodium on survival and recapture probability in a large data set of breeding blue tits, involving 3424 individuals and 3118 infection diagnoses over nine years.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>

<Species>We reveal strong associations between chronic malaria infection and both recapture and survival, effects that are dependent on the clade of parasite, on host traits and on the local risk of infection.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Infection with Plasmodium relictum was associated with reduced recapture probability and increased survival, compared to P. circumflexum, suggesting that these parasites have differing virulence and cause different types of selection on this host.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>6.</Species>
<Species>Our results suggest a large potential survival cost of acute infections revealed by modelling host survival as a function of the local risk of infection.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>

<Species>Our analyses suggest not only that endemic avian malaria may have multiple fitness effects on their hosts and that these effects are species dependent, but also that adding ecological structure (in this case parasite species and spatial variation in disease occurrence) to analyses of host-parasite interactions is an important step in understanding the ecology and evolution of these systems.</Species>
<Species>Independent duplications of alpha-amylase in different strains of Aspergillus oryzae.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Aspergillus oryzae is a filamentous fungus that has arisen through the ancient domestication of Aspergillus flavus for making traditional oriental foods and beverages.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In the many centuries A. oryzae has been used for fermenting the starch in rice to simple sugars, it has undergone selection for increased secretion of starch-degrading enzymes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In particular, all A. oryzae strains investigated thus far have two or more copies of a gene encoding alpha-amylase, whereas A. flavus has only one.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Here we investigate the duplications leading to these copies in three A. oryzae strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We find evidence of at least three separate duplications of alpha-amylase, an example of parallel evolution in a micro-organism under artificial selection.</Species>
<Species>At least two of these duplications appear to be associated with activity of transposable elements of the Tc1/mariner class.</Species>

<Species>Both involve a 9.1 kb element that terminates in inverted repeats, encodes a putative transposase and another putative protein of unknown function, and contains an unusual arrangement of four short internal imperfect repeats.</Species>

<Species>Although "unusual Mariners" of this size have previously been identified in A. oryzae, Aspergillus fumigatus and Aspergillus nidulans, this is the first evidence we know of that at least some of them are active in modern times and that their activity can contribute to beneficial genetic changes.</Species>

text: <Species>Individuals who control an initial HIV infection are therefore still at risk for subsequent infection with divergent viruses, but the barriers to such superinfection remain unclear.</Species>

text: <Species>Here we tested long-term nonprogressors' (LTNPs') susceptibility to superinfection using Indian rhesus macaques that express the major histocompatibility complex class I (MHC-I) allele Mamu-B 17, which is associated with control of the pathogenic AIDS virus SIVmac239.</Species>

text: <Species>The Mamu-B 17-restricted CD8(+) T cell repertoire is focused almost entirely on 5 epitopes.</Species>
<Species>We engineered a series of SIVmac239 variants bearing mutations in 3, 4, or all 5 of these epitopes and used them to serially challenge 2 Mamu-B 17-positive LTNPs.</Species>
<Species>None of the escape variants caused breakthrough replication in LTNPs, although they readily infected Mamu-B 17-negative naive macaques.</Species>
<Species>In vitro competing coculture assays and examination of viral evolution in hosts lacking Mamu-B 17 suggested that the mutant viruses had negligible defects in replicative fitness.</Species>

text: <Species>T cells and neutralizing antibodies.</Species>
<Species>Our results suggest that escape mutations in epitopes bound by "protective" MHC-I molecules may not be sufficient to establish superinfection in LTNPs.</Species>
<Species>The pH regulatory factor Pac1 regulates Tri gene expression and trichothecene production in Fusarium graminearum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Fungi manage the adaptation to extra-cellular pH through the PacC transcription factor, a key component of the pH regulatory system.</Species>
<Species>PacC regulates the production of various secondary metabolites in filamentous fungi.</Species>
<Species>In the important cereal pathogen Fusarium graminearum, the production of trichothecene is induced only under acidic pH conditions.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, we examined the role of the PacC homologue from F. graminearum, FgPac1, on the regulation of trichothecene production.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>An FgDeltaPac1 deletion mutant was constructed in F. graminearum which showed a reduced development under neutral and alkaline pH, increased sensitivity to H(2)O(2) and an earlier Tri gene induction and toxin accumulation at acidic pH. A strain expressing the FgPac1(c) constitutively active form of Pac1 exhibited a strongly repressed Tri gene expression and reduced toxin accumulation at acidic pH. These results demonstrate that Pac1 negatively regulates Tri gene expression and toxin production in F. graminearum.</Species>

text: <Species>Regulation and function of Escherichia coli sugar efflux transporter A (SetA) during glucose-phosphate stress.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Accumulation of certain nonmetabolizable sugar-phosphates (including alpha-methyl glucoside-6-phosphate) in Escherichia coli is growth inhibitory and elicits the glucose-phosphate stress response.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The transcription factor SgrR activates transcription of the small RNA SgrS under stress conditions.</Species>
<Species>SgrS represses translation of mRNAs encoding sugar transporters.</Species>

<Species>The sgrR and sgrS genes are located directly upstream of setA, and this gene organization is conserved in numerous enteric species, prompting the hypothesis that SetA contributes to the glucose-phosphate stress response.</Species>
<Species>SetA is a proton motive force-driven efflux pump capable of transporting various sugars and sugar analogs in vitro.</Species>

<Species>This study demonstrates that setA expression is induced in response to glucose-phosphate stress, and this requires SgrR. Under stress conditions, setA is cotranscribed with sgrS from the sgrS promoter.</Species>

<Species>A setA mutant exhibits a growth defect under stress conditions that can be complemented by setA in trans, suggesting that SetA contributes to the optimal cellular recovery from stress.</Species>

<Species>Despite previous in vitro evidence that SetA can promote efflux of the stress-causing glucose analog alpha-methyl glucoside, in vivo data in this study indicate that SetA is not the major efflux pump responsible for removal of alpha-methyl glucoside under stress conditions.</Species>

<Species>Thermally contingent plasticity: temperature alters expression of predator-induced colour and morphology in a Neotropical treefrog tadpole.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Behavioural, morphological and coloration plasticity are common responses of prey to predation risk.</Species>
<Species>Theory predicts that prey should respond to the relative magnitude of risk, rather than a single level of response to any risk level.</Species>

<Species>In addition to conspecific and predator densities, prey growth and differentiation rates affect the duration of vulnerability to size- and stage-limited predators and therefore the relative value of defences.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>We reared tadpoles of the Neotropical treefrog Dendropsophus ebraccatus with or without cues from a predator (Belostoma sp.) in ecologically relevant warm or cool temperatures.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To track phenotypic changes, we measured morphology, tail coloration and developmental stage at three points during the larval period.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Cues from predators interacted with growth conditions causing tadpoles to alter their phenotype, changing only tail colour in response to predators in warm water, but both morphology and colour in cool growth conditions.</Species>
<Species>Tadpoles with predators in warm water altered coloration early but converged on the morphology of predator-free controls.</Species>
<Species>Water temperature alone had no effect on tadpole phenotype.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>We demonstrate that seemingly small variation in abiotic environmental conditions can alter the expression of phenotypic plasticity, consistent with predictions about how growth rate affects risk.</Species>
<Species>Predator-induced tadpole phenotypes depended on temperature, with strong expression only in temperatures that slow development.</Species>
<Species>Thermal modulation of plastic responses to predators may be broadly relevant to poikilotherm development.</Species>
<Species>It is important to include a range of realistic growth conditions in experiments to more fully understand the ecological and evolutionary significance of plasticity.</Species>
<Species>Mapping interactions between germinants and Clostridium difficile spores.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Germination of Clostridium difficile spores is the first required step in establishing C. difficile-associated disease (CDAD).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Taurocholate (a bile salt) and glycine (an amino acid) have been shown to be important germinants of C. difficile spores.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In the present study, we tested a series of glycine and taurocholate analogs for the ability to induce or inhibit C. difficile spore germination.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Testing of glycine analogs revealed that both the carboxy and amino groups are important epitopes for recognition and that the glycine binding site can accommodate compounds with more widely separated termini.</Species>
<Species>The C. difficile germination machinery also recognizes other hydrophobic amino acids.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In general, linear alkyl side chains are better activators of spore germination than their branched analogs.</Species>
<Species>However, L-phenylalanine and L-arginine are also good germinants and are probably recognized by distinct binding sites.</Species>
<Species>Testing of taurocholate analogs revealed that the 12-hydroxyl group of taurocholate is necessary, but not sufficient, to activate spore germination.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, the 6- and 7-hydroxyl groups are required for inhibition of C. difficile spore germination.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Similarly, C. difficile spores are able to detect taurocholate analogs with shorter, but not longer, alkyl amino sulfonic acid side chains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, the sulfonic acid group can be partially substituted with other acidic groups.</Species>
<Species>Finally, a taurocholate analog with an m-aminobenzenesulfonic acid side chain is a strong inhibitor of C. difficile spore germination.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In conclusion, C. difficile spores recognize both amino acids and taurocholate through multiple interactions that are required to bind the germinants and/or activate the germination machinery.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Contrasting patterns of individual specialization and trophic coupling in two marine apex predators.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Apex predators are often assumed to be dietary generalists and, by feeding on prey from multiple basal nutrient sources, serve to couple discrete food webs.</Species>
<Species>But there is increasing evidence that individual level dietary specialization may be common in many species, and this has not been investigated for many marine apex predators.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Because of their position at or near the top of many marine food webs, and the possibility that they can affect populations of their prey and induce trophic cascades, it is important to understand patterns of dietary specialization in shark populations.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Stable isotope values from body tissues with different turnover rates were used to quantify patterns of individual specialization in two species of 'generalist' sharks (bull sharks, Carcharhinus leucas, and tiger sharks, Galeocerdo cuvier).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>
<Species>Despite wide population-level isotopic niche breadths in both species, isotopic values of individual tiger sharks varied across tissues with different turnover rates.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The population niche breadth was explained mostly by variation within individuals suggesting tiger sharks are true generalists.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast, isotope values of individual bull sharks were stable through time and their wide population level niche breadth was explained by variation among specialist individuals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>
<Species>Relative resource abundance and spatial variation in food-predation risk tradeoffs may explain the differences in patterns of specialization between shark species.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>

<Species>The differences in individual dietary specialization between tiger sharks and bull sharks results in different functional roles in coupling or compartmentalizing distinct food webs.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>7.</Species>

<Species>Individual specialization may be an important feature of trophic dynamics of highly mobile marine top predators and should be explicitly considered in studies of marine food webs and the ecological role of top predators.</Species>

<Species>Predation is associated with variation in colour pattern, but not body shape or colour reflectance, in a rainbowfish (Melanotaenia australis).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>In freshwater fishes, inter-population variation in male phenotype is often associated with differences in predation intensity, but these effects can be difficult to disentangle from environmental influences.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>The western rainbowfish Melanotaenia australis exhibits marked sexual dimorphism - females are plain with a slender body, while males have striking coloration and are deeper in the body.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Male traits differ in expression among populations, but this has not been described or explored in the literature.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>This paper describes a study designed to test for geographic structuring of male phenotype in M. australis and to determine whether between-population variation in male phenotype is attributable to variation in predation regime, after accounting for environment.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We collected data describing habitat, and the size, activity and abundance of predators at sites containing M. australis populations.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We then used photography, spectrometry and geometric morphometrics to describe colour pattern, spectral reflectance and body shape in males from these populations.</Species>
<Species>Finally, we used permutation-based multivariate statistics to partition variance in these traits according to environment and predation regime.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>Downstream environments posed higher predation risk to M. australis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, males from these sites consistently exhibited larger cheek spots and fewer coloured lateral stripes than those from upstream sites.</Species>
<Species>Variation in predation regime accounted for a significant proportion of the total variance in these traits (30*9%), after controlling for the effects of environment.</Species>
<Species>6. Variation in predation regime did not explain variation in reflectance or shape.</Species>

<Species>Environmental variation, however, explained a significant portion of the total variance in reflectance (74*9%), and there was a strong trend towards it explaining a portion of the total variance in body shape (34*9%).</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>

<Species>We conclude that natural selection by predators may be an important determinant of the evolution of colour pattern variation in M. australis, but not of that of body shape or colour reflectance.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>8.</Species>
<Species>Further study of M. australis will complement existing models, which show complex relationships between predation regime, environment and phenotype.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Understanding these relationships is prerequisite to predicting the evolution of phenotypic variation in natural systems.</Species>
<Species>Arbuscular mycorrhizal hyphopodia and germinated spore exudates trigger Ca2+ spiking in the legume and nonlegume root epidermis.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>

<Species>The aim of this study was to investigate Ca(2+) responses to endosymbiotic arbuscular mycorrhizal (AM) fungi in the host root epidermis following pre-infection hyphopodium formation in both legumes and nonlegumes, and to determine to what extent these responses could be mimicked by germinated fungal spore exudate.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>* Root organ cultures of both Medicago truncatula and Daucus carota, expressing the nuclear-localized cameleon reporter NupYC2.1, were used to monitor AM-elicited Ca(2+) responses in host root tissues.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>* Ca(2+) spiking was observed in cells contacted by AM hyphopodia for both hosts, with highest frequencies correlating with the epidermal nucleus positioned facing the fungal contact site.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Treatment with AM spore exudate also elicited Ca(2+) spiking within the AM-responsive zone of the root and, in both cases, spiking was dependent on the M. truncatula common SYM genes DMI1/2, but not on the rhizobial Nod factor perception gene NFP.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>*</Species>

<Species>These findings support the conclusion that AM fungal root penetration is preceded by a SYM pathway-dependent oscillatory Ca(2+) response, whose evolutionary origin predates the divergence between asterid and rosid clades.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Our results further show that fungal symbiotic signals are already generated during spore germination, and that cameleon-expressing root organ cultures represent a novel AM-specific bio-assay for such signals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Stable isotope labelling and zinc distribution in grains studied by laser ablation ICP-MS in an ear culture system reveals zinc transport barriers during grain filling in wheat.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Zinc (Zn) deficiency has been recognized as a potential risk for human health in many developing regions where staple food with low micronutrient density represents a major proportion of the diet.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The success of strategies to increase Zn content in the edible part of crops requires better understanding of Zn transport to, and distribution within, the grains.</Species>

<Species>The transfer of Zn from the growth medium to wheat (Triticum aestivum) grains in an ear culture system was investigated by using the stable Zn isotope (70) Zn, and the spatial distribution of Zn within the grains was studied by laser ablation-inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry (LA-ICP-MS).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Zinc was readily transported in the stem up to the rachis.</Species>
<Species>More Zn accumulated in the stem when higher amounts of Zn were supplied to the medium.</Species>
<Species>Once Zn was transported into the grain, Zn accumulated particularly in the crease vascular tissue.</Species>
<Species>The gradient of (70) Zn concentration between crease vascular tissue, aleurone layer and endosperm demonstrates that Zn is distributed within grain through the crease phloem.</Species>
<Species>These results suggest that two barriers of Zn transport into wheat grains may exist: between the stem tissue rachis and the grain, and the maternal and filial tissues in the grain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Influence of helix 12 of Ultraspiracle on Drosophila melanogaster ecdysone receptor function.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Although it has no ligand, helix 12 in the ligand binding domain of Ultraspiracle (USP) is locked in an antagonistic position.</Species>
<Species>To investigate whether this position is of functional importance, we enhanced the flexibility of helix 12 by mutating two amino acids (259, located in L1-3 and F491 in helix 12).</Species>

<Species>Mutated USP reduces the stability of USP and all isoforms of the ecdysone receptor (EcR) and impairs nuclear localization and DNA binding of EcR/USP(L259A/F491/A), resulting in lower levels of basal transcriptional activity.</Species>
<Species>Although the affinity of the ligand ponasterone A to EcR/USP(L259/F491) is moderately diminished, hormone-induced stimulation of transcriptional activity is normal.</Species>

<Species>Potentiation of the ecdysone response by juvenile hormone (JH) is selectively increased in mutated heterodimers with EcR-B1, demonstrating that the antagonistic position impairs functional interaction of the EcR complex with JHIII.</Species>
<Species>The Burkholderia cenocepacia LysR-type transcriptional regulator ShvR influences expression of quorum-sensing, protease, type II secretion, and afc genes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Burkholderia cenocepacia is a significant opportunistic pathogen in individuals with cystic fibrosis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>ShvR, a LysR-type transcriptional regulator, has previously been shown to influence colony morphology, biofilm formation, virulence in plant and animal infection models, and some quorum-sensing-dependent phenotypes.</Species>
<Species>In the present study, it was shown that ShvR negatively regulates its own expression, as is typical for LysR-type regulators.</Species>

<Species>The production of quorum-sensing signal molecules was detected earlier in growth in the shvR mutant than in the wild type, and ShvR repressed expression of the quorum-sensing regulatory genes cepIR and cciIR.</Species>

<Species>Microarray analysis and transcriptional fusions revealed that ShvR regulated over 1,000 genes, including the zinc metalloproteases zmpA and zmpB. The shvR mutant displayed increased gene expression of the type II secretion system and significantly increased protease and lipase activities.</Species>

<Species>Both ShvR and CepR influence expression of a 24-kb genomic region adjacent to shvR that includes the afcA and afcC operons, required for the production of an antifungal agent; however, the reduction in expression was substantially greater in the shvR mutant than in the cepR mutant.</Species>
<Species>Only the shvR mutation resulted in reduced antifungal activity against Rhizoctonia solani.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>ShvR, but not CepR, was shown to directly regulate expression of the afcA and afcC promoters.</Species>
<Species>In summary, ShvR was determined to have a significant influence on the expression of quorum-sensing, protease, lipase, type II secretion, and afc genes.</Species>

text: <Species>A role for endosomal proteins in alphavirus dissemination in mosquitoes.</Species>
<Species>Little is known about endosomal pathway proteins involved in arthropod-borne virus (arbovirus) assembly and cell-to-cell spread in vector mosquitoes.</Species>
<Species>UNC93A and synaptic vesicle-2 (SV2) proteins are involved in intracellular transport in mammals.</Species>
<Species>They show amino acid sequence conservation from mosquitoes to humans, and their transcripts are highly enriched in Aedes aegypti during arbovirus infection.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Transient gene silencing of SV2 or UNC93A in mosquitoes infected with the recombinant alphavirus Sindbis MRE16-enhanced green fluorescent protein (SINV; family Togaviridae) resulted in the accumulation of viral positive- and negative-strand RNA, congregation of virus envelope antigen in intracellular networks, and reduced virus dissemination outside of the midgut.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Further, UNC93A silencing, but not SV2 silencing, resulted in a 10-fold reduction in viral titres at 4 days post-infection.</Species>
<Species>Together, these data support a role for UNC93A and SV2 in virus assembly or budding.</Species>
<Species>Cis-regulatory elements (CREs) were identified at the 5'-ends of genes from the original data set in which SV2 and UNC93A were identified.</Species>

<Species>Common CREs at the 5'-end genomic regions of a subset of enriched transcripts support the hypothesis that UNC93A transcription may be co-regulated with that of other ion transport and endosomal trafficking proteins.</Species>
<Species>Characterizing the role of the microtubule binding protein Bim1 in Cryptococcus neoformans.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>During sexual development the human fungal pathogen Cryptococcus neoformans undergoes a developmental transition from yeast-form growth to filamentous growth.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This transition requires cellular restructuring to form a filamentous dikaryon.</Species>
<Species>Dikaryotic growth also requires tightly controlled nuclear migration to ensure faithful replication and dissemination of genetic material to spore progeny.</Species>
<Species>Although the gross morphological changes that take place during dikaryotic growth are largely known, the molecular underpinnings that control this process are uncharacterized.</Species>

<Species>Here we identify and characterize a C. neoformans homolog of the Saccharomyces cerevisiae BIM1 gene, and establish the importance of BIM1 for proper filamentous growth of C. neoformans.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Deletion of BIM1 leads to truncated sexual development filaments, a severe defect in diploid formation, and a block in monokaryotic fruiting.</Species>
<Species>Our findings lead to a model consistent with a critical role for BIM1 in both filament integrity and nuclear congression that is mediated through the microtubule cytoskeleton.</Species>
<Species>Characterizing demographic variation and contributions to population growth rate in a declining population.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Understanding how demographic variation translates into variation in population growth rate (lambda) is central to understanding population dynamics.</Species>

<Species>Such understanding ideally requires knowledge of the mean, variance and covariance among all demographic rates, allowing the potential and realized contribution of each rate to lambda to be estimated.</Species>

<Species>Such studies require integrated monitoring of all demographic rates across multiple years and are consequently rare, particularly in declining populations and for species with less tractable life histories.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>We used 12 years of comprehensive demographic data from a declining ring ouzel (Turdus torquatus) population to estimate the mean, variance and covariance in all major demographic rates and estimate potential and realized demographic contributions to lambda.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>
<Species>Population size decreased from 39 to 13 breeding pairs (-67%) and mean lambda was 0*91 during 1998-2009.</Species>

<Species>This decrease did not reflect a substantial concurrent decrease in any single key demographic rate, but reflected varying combinations of demographic rates that consistently produced lambda < 1. 4.</Species>

<Species>Basic prospective elasticity analysis indicated that lambda was most sensitive to adult survival, closely followed by early season reproductive success and early brood first-year survival.</Species>

<Species>In contrast, integrated elasticity analysis, accounting for estimated demographic covariance, indicated that lambda was most sensitive to early brood first-year survival, closely followed by re-nesting rate, early season reproductive success, late-brood first-year survival and adult survival.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>Retrospective decomposition of variance suggested that first-year survival contributed most to observed variation in lambda.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>

<Species>However, demographic comparison with other related species suggested that adult survival, but not reproductive success or post-fledging survival, averaged lower than expected throughout the 12-year study.</Species>
<Species>7.</Species>

<Species>These data demonstrate that multiple approaches, including comprehensive demographic and comparative analyses and due consideration of conflicting answers, may be necessary to accurately diagnose the demographic basis of population change.</Species>

<Species>Profile of the mosaic element BTMR1 in the genome of the bumble bee Bombus terrestris (Hymenoptera: Apidae).</Species>

text: <Species>Co-evolution involving a mariner transposon, Botmar1 and the other repeats contained in the Bombus terrestris genome was investigated.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that the 5'-region of Botmar1 forms one of the components of a mosaic element, known as B. terrestris mosaic repeat 1 (BTMR1), which is also composed of inner segments originating from two different retrotransposons and a pseudogene corresponding to an RNA methyltransferase cDNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The fact that BTMR1 is interspersed within chromosomes and the differences in its abundance in different species indicate that it is very probably a mobile element.</Species>

<Species>Nevertheless, the absences of direct or inverted repeats at its ends and of target site duplication indicate that its mobility is not ensured by a cardinal transposable element, but putatively by a Crypton-like element.</Species>
<Species>Endogenous regulation of the growth-rate responses of a spring-dwelling strain of the freshwater alga, Chlorella minutissima, to light and temperature.</Species>

text: <Species>The paper presents a laboratory investigation of the temperature- and light- dependence of autotrophic growth of the alga Chlorella minutissima.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It was isolated from the storage basin of a spring in the mountains of the Massif Central, France.</Species>
<Species>The alga was grown at temperatures between (10 and 35 ^0C) and under irradiances from 30 to 550 mumol m(-2)</Species>
<Species>s(-1), under a light/dark cycle.</Species>

<Species>The results were fitted to selected descriptive models, seeking to express, as far as possible, the observed physiological behaviour of the strain and the minimum irradiance required to sustain net growth.</Species>

<Species>At all temperatures, the maximum rates of growth observed are strikingly slower than those of other Chlorella strains and of other small algae, reported in the literature, even when correction is made for continuous light.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The Q10 statistic for growth at temperatures>20 ^0C rates is also noticeably lower than in other species, while the apparent threshold of any growth is about 8 ^0C. Growth rates are readily light-saturated at all temperatures but with little evidence of adaptation of photosynthesis to low photon-flux rates.</Species>
<Species>No short-term flexibility in these properties (over a time-scale of days) was demonstrated during the course of our experiments.</Species>

<Species>We deduce that the algal strain had become genetically adapted to the relatively constant, even-temperature and low-light conditions of the spring-water habitat whence it was originally isolated.</Species>

text: <Species>Burkholderia rhizoxinica is an intracellular symbiont of the phytopathogenic fungus Rhizopus microsporus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The vertically transmitted endosymbiont not only delivers the antimitotic macrolide rhizoxin to its host but is also essential for vegetative spore formation of the fungus.</Species>

<Species>To shed light on the genetic equipment of this model organism, we sequenced the whole genome of B. rhizoxinica HKI 0454, thus providing the first genomic insight into an intracellular mutualist of a fungal species.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The 3.75-Mb genome consists of a chromosome and two strain-specific plasmids.</Species>
<Species>The primary metabolism appears to be specialized for the uptake of fungal metabolites.</Species>

<Species>Besides the rhizoxin biosynthesis gene cluster, there are 14 loci coding for nonribosomal peptide synthetase (NRPS) assembly lines, which represent novel targets for genomic mining of cryptic natural products.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, the endosymbionts are equipped with a repertoire of virulence-related factors, which can now be studied to elucidate molecular mechanisms underlying bacterial-fungal interaction.</Species>
<Species>Type I signal peptidase and protein secretion in Staphylococcus epidermidis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Bacterial protein secretion is a highly orchestrated process that is essential for infection and virulence.</Species>
<Species>Despite extensive efforts to predict or experimentally detect proteins that are secreted, the characterization of the bacterial secretome has remained challenging.</Species>

<Species>A central event in protein secretion is the type I signal peptidase (SPase)-mediated cleavage of the N-terminal signal peptide that targets a protein for secretion via the general secretory pathway, and the arylomycins are a class of natural products that inhibit SPase, suggesting that they may be useful chemical biology tools for characterizing the secretome.</Species>

<Species>Here, using an arylomycin derivative, along with two-dimensional gel electrophoresis and liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS), we identify 11 proteins whose secretion from stationary-phase Staphylococcus epidermidis is dependent on SPase activity, 9 of which are predicted to be translated with canonical N-terminal signal peptides.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In addition, we find that the presence of extracellular domains of lipoteichoic acid synthase (LtaS) and the Beta-lactam response sensor BlaR1 in the medium is dependent on SPase activity, suggesting that they are cleaved at noncanonical sites within the protein.</Species>

<Species>In all, the data define the proteins whose stationary-phase secretion depends on SPase and also suggest that the arylomycins should be valuable chemical biology tools for the study of protein secretion in a wide variety of different bacteria.</Species>

text: <Species>Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) is a neurotropic alphaherpesvirus.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>VZV infection of human dorsal root ganglion (DRG) xenografts in immunodeficient mice models the infection of sensory ganglia.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We examined DRG infection with recombinant VZV (recombinant Oka [rOka]) and the following gE mutants: gEDelta27-90, gEDeltaCys, gE-AYRV, and gE-SSTT.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>gEDelta27-90, which lacks the gE domain that interacts with a putative receptor insulin-degrading enzyme (IDE), replicated as extensively as rOka, producing infectious virions and significant cytopathic effects within 14 days of inoculation.</Species>
<Species>Since neural cells express IDE, the gE/IDE interaction was dispensable for VZV neurotropism.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast, gEDeltaCys, which lacks gE/gI heterodimer formation, was significantly impaired at early times postinfection; viral genome copy numbers increased slowly, and infectious virus production was not detected until day 28.</Species>
<Species>Delayed replication was associated with impaired cell-cell spread in ganglia, similar to the phenotype of a gI deletion mutant (rOkaDeltagI).</Species>

<Species>However, at later time points, infection of satellite cells and other supportive nonneuronal cells resulted in extensive DRG tissue damage and cell loss such that cytopathic changes observed at day 70 were more severe than those for rOka-infected DRG.</Species>

<Species>The replication of gE-AYRV, which is impaired for trans-Golgi network (TGN) localization, and the replication of gE-SSTT, which contains mutations in an acidic cluster, were equivalent to that of rOka, causing significant cytopathic effects and infectious virus production by day 14; genome copy numbers were equivalent to those of rOka.</Species>

<Species>These experiments suggest that the gE interaction with cellular IDE, gE targeting to TGN sites of virion envelopment, and phosphorylation at SSTT are dispensable for VZV DRG infection, whereas the gE/gI interaction is critical for VZV neurovirulence.</Species>

text: <Species>Thermal performance curves of Paramecium caudatum: a model selection approach.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The ongoing climate change has motivated numerous studies investigating the temperature response of various organisms, especially that of ectotherms.</Species>
<Species>To correctly describe the thermal performance of these organisms, functions are needed which sufficiently fit to the complete optimum curve.</Species>
<Species>Surprisingly, model-comparisons for the temperature-dependence of population growth rates of an important ectothermic group, the protozoa, are still missing.</Species>
<Species>In this study, temperature reaction norms of natural isolates of the freshwater protist Paramecium caudatum were investigated, considering nearly the entire temperature range.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These reaction norms were used to estimate thermal performance curves by applying a set of commonly used model functions.</Species>
<Species>An information theory approach was used to compare models and to identify the best ones for describing these data.</Species>
<Species>Our results indicate that the models which can describe negative growth at the high- and low-temperature branch of an optimum curve are preferable.</Species>
<Species>This is a prerequisite for accurately calculating the critical upper and lower thermal limits.</Species>
<Species>While we detected a temperature optimum of around 29 ^0C for all investigated clonal strains, the critical thermal limits were considerably different between individual clones.</Species>
<Species>Here, the tropical clone showed the narrowest thermal tolerance, with a shift of its critical thermal limits to higher temperatures.</Species>

text: <Species>To further investigate the distribution of ploidy in methanogenic archaea, species of two additional genera-Methanosarcina acetivorans and Methanococcus maripaludis-were investigated.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>M. acetivorans was found to be polyploid during fast growth (t(D) =</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>6 h; 17 genome copies) and oligoploid during slow growth (doubling time = 49 h; 3 genome copies).</Species>
<Species>M. maripaludis has the highest ploidy level found for any archaeal species, with up to 55 genome copies in exponential phase and ca.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>30 in stationary phase.</Species>

<Species>A compilation of archaeal species with quantified ploidy levels reveals a clear dichotomy between Euryarchaeota and Crenarchaeota: none of seven euryarchaeal species of six genera is monoploid (haploid), while, in contrast, all six crenarchaeal species of four genera are monoploid, indicating significant genetic differences between these two kingdoms.</Species>
<Species>Polyploidy in asexual species should lead to accumulation of inactivating mutations until the number of intact chromosomes per cell drops to zero (called "Muller's ratchet").</Species>
<Species>A mechanism to equalize the genome copies, such as gene conversion, would counteract this phenomenon.</Species>

<Species>Making use of a previously constructed heterozygous mutant strain of the polyploid M. maripaludis we could show that in the absence of selection very fast equalization of genomes in M. maripaludis took place probably via a gene conversion mechanism.</Species>

text: <Species>In addition, it was shown that the velocity of this phenomenon is inversely correlated to the strength of selection.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>Colicin M (ColM), which is produced by some Escherichia coli strains to kill competitor strains from the same or related species, was recently shown to inhibit cell wall peptidoglycan biosynthesis through enzymatic degradation of its lipid II precursor.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>ColM-producing strains are protected from the toxin that they produce by coexpression of a specific immunity protein, named Cmi, whose mode of action still remains to be identified.</Species>
<Species>We report here the resolution of the crystal structure of Cmi, which is composed of four Beta strands and four alpha helices.</Species>
<Species>This rather compact structure revealed a disulfide bond between residues Cys31 and Cys107.</Species>

<Species>Interestingly, these two cysteines and several other residues appeared to be conserved in the sequences of several proteins of unknown function belonging to the YebF family which exhibit 25 to 35% overall sequence similarity with Cmi.</Species>

<Species>Site-directed mutagenesis was performed to assess the role of these residues in the ColM immunity-conferring activity of Cmi, which showed that the disulfide bond and residues from the C-terminal extremity of the protein were functionally essential.</Species>
<Species>The involvement of DsbA oxidase in the formation of the Cmi disulfide bond is also demonstrated.</Species>

text: <Species>PMKT (Pichia membranifaciens killer toxin) reportedly has antimicrobial activity against yeasts and filamentous fungi.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>In previous research we posited that high PMKT concentrations pose a serious challenge for cell survival by disrupting plasma membrane electrochemical gradients, inducing a transcriptional response similar to that of certain stimuli such as hyperosmotic shock.</Species>
<Species>This response was related to the HOG-pathway with Hog1p phosphorylation and a transitional increase in intracellular glycerol accumulation.</Species>
<Species>Such a response was consistent with the notion that the effect induced by high PMKT concentrations lies in an alteration to the ionic homeostasis of the sensitive cell.</Species>

<Species>By contrast, the evidence presented here shows that low PMKT doses lead to a cell death process in Saccharomyces cerevisiae accompanied by cytological and biochemical indicators of apoptotic programmed cell death, namely, the production of reactive oxygen species, DNA strand breaks, metacaspase activation and cytochrome c release.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, dying cells progressed from an apoptotic state to a secondary necrotic state, and the rate at which this change occurred was proportional to the intensity of the stimulus.</Species>
<Species>We have explored the global gene expression response of S. cerevisiae during that stimulus.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The results obtained from DNA microarrays indicate that genes related with an oxidative stress response were induced in response to proapoptotic concentrations of PMKT, showing that the coordinated transcriptional response is not coincident with that obtained when ionophoric concentrations of PMKT are used.</Species>

<Species>By contrast, cwp2Delta mutants showed no signs of apoptosis, indicating that the initial steps of the killer mechanism coincide when proapoptotic (low) or ionophoric (high) PMKT concentrations are used.</Species>
<Species>Additionally, low dosages of PMKT promoted Hog1p phosphorylation and glycerol accumulation.</Species>

<Species>A model-driven approach to quantify migration patterns: individual, regional and yearly differences.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Animal migration has long intrigued scientists and wildlife managers alike, yet migratory species face increasing challenges because of habitat fragmentation, climate change and over-exploitation.</Species>

<Species>Central to the understanding migratory species is the objective discrimination between migratory and nonmigratory individuals in a given population, quantifying the timing, duration and distance of migration and the ability to predict migratory movements.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Here, we propose a uniform statistical framework to (i) separate migration from other movement behaviours, (ii) quantify migration parameters without the need for arbitrary cut-off criteria and (iii) test predictability across individuals, time and space.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>We first validated our novel approach by simulating data based on established theoretical movement patterns.</Species>

<Species>We then formulated the expected shapes of squared displacement patterns as nonlinear models for a suite of movement behaviours to test the ability of our method to distinguish between migratory movement and other movement types.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>We then tested our approached empirically using 108 wild Global Positioning System (GPS)-collared moose Alces alces in Scandinavia as a study system because they exhibit a wide range of movement behaviours, including resident, migrating and dispersing individuals, within the same population.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Applying our approach showed that 87% and 67% of our Swedish and Norwegian subpopulations, respectively, can be classified as migratory.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Using nonlinear mixed effects models for all migratory individuals we showed that the distance, timing and duration of migration differed between the sexes and between years, with additional individual differences accounting for a large part of the variation in the distance of migration but not in the timing or duration.</Species>
<Species>Overall, the model explained most of the variation (92%) and also had high predictive power for the same individuals over time (69%) as well as between study populations (74%).</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>

<Species>The high predictive ability of the approach suggests that it can help increase our understanding of the drivers of migration and could provide key quantitative information for understanding and managing a broad range of migratory species.</Species>
