Species

text: <Species>2.</Species>
<Species>Both Arctic charr and brown trout reduced resting metabolic rate under simulated ice-cover (darkness) in the laboratory, compared to no ice (6-h daylight).</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>However, in contrast to brown trout, Arctic charr was able to obtain positive growth rate in darkness and had higher food intake in tank experiments than brown trout.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Arctic charr also performed better (lower energy loss) under simulated ice-cover in a semi-natural environment with natural food supply.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>When comparing brown trout biomass across 190 Norwegian lakes along a climate gradient, longer ice-covered duration decreased the biomass only in lakes where brown trout lived together with Arctic charr.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>We were not able to detect any effect of ice-cover on brown trout biomass in lakes where brown trout was the only fish species.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Similarly, a 25-year time series from a lake with both brown trout and Arctic charr showed that brown trout population growth rate depended on the interaction between ice breakup date and Arctic charr abundance.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>High charr abundance was correlated with low trout population growth rate only in combination with long winters.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>

<Species>In conclusion, the two species differed in performance under ice, and the observed outcome of competition in natural populations was strongly dependent on duration of the ice-covered period.</Species>
<Species>Our study shows that changes in ice phenology may alter species interactions in Northern aquatic systems.</Species>
<Species>Increased knowledge of how adaptations to winter conditions differ among coexisting species is therefore vital for our understanding of ecological impacts of climate change.</Species>
<Species>Identification and expression analysis of nervous wreck, which is preferentially expressed in the brain of the male silkworm moth, Bombyx mori.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Sexually dimorphic neural circuits are essential for reproductive behaviour.</Species>
<Species>The molecular basis of sexual dimorphism in the silkworm moth (Bombyx mori) brain, however, is unclear.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We conducted cDNA subtraction screening and identified nervous wreck (Bmnwk), a synaptic growth regulatory gene, whose expression is higher in the male brain than in the female brain of the silkworm.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Bmnwk was preferentially expressed in the brain at the late pupae and adult stages.</Species>
<Species>In situ hybridization revealed that Bmnwk is highly expressed in the optic lobe of the male moth brain.</Species>
<Species>These findings suggest that Bmnwk has a role in the development and/or maintenance of the optic lobe in the male silkworm brain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Regulation of virulence factors, carbon utilization and virulence by SNF1 in Cryptococcus neoformans JEC21 and divergent actions of SNF1 between cryptococcal strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We describe here the functions of a Snf1/AMPK homolog in the human pathogenic yeast Cryptococcus neoformans, strain JEC21.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We found that JEC21 SNF1 is a key regulator for the biosynthesis of the major virulence factors, stress resistance and alternative carbon source utilization.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Disruption of JEC21 SNF1 results in defects of laccase activity and capsule production, sensitivity to cation stress.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Especially, we found that JEC21 SNF1 is essential for growth at elevated temperature and for thermotolerance.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To our knowledge, a role for Snf1 proteins in thermotolerance has not been reported.</Species>
<Species>Furthermore, we observed a functional divergence between JEC21 SNF1 and its equivalent from serotype A strain H99.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>A high temperature is needed for H99 SNF1 to function in stress response and carbon source preference, but not for the JEC21 SNF1.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Our results confirmed a critical role of JEC21 SNF1 in regulation of stress response and virulence.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Revelation of divergent actions of SNF1 may help to understand the evolution of cryptococcal pathogenesis and provides insights into the strain-associated biosynthesis of virulence factors.</Species>
<Species>Insights into the extracytoplasmic stress response of Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris: role and regulation of {sigma}E-dependent activity.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Xanthomonas campestris pv. campestris is an epiphytic bacterium that can become a vascular pathogen responsible for black rot disease of crucifers.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To adapt gene expression in response to ever-changing habitats, phytopathogenic bacteria have evolved signal transduction regulatory pathways, such as extracytoplasmic function (ECF) sigma factors.</Species>
<Species>The alternative sigma factor sigma(E), encoded by rpoE, is crucial for envelope stress response and plays a role in the pathogenicity of many bacterial species.</Species>
<Species>Here, we combine different approaches to investigate the role and mechanism of sigma(E)-dependent activation in X. campestris pv. campestris.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We show that the rpoE gene is organized as a single transcription unit with the anti-sigma gene rseA and the protease gene mucD and that rpoE transcription is autoregulated.</Species>
<Species>rseA and mucD transcription is also controlled by a highly conserved sigma(E)-dependent promoter within the sigma(E) gene sequence.</Species>

<Species>The sigma(E)-mediated stress response is required for stationary-phase survival, resistance to cadmium, and adaptation to membrane-perturbing stresses (elevated temperature and ethanol).</Species>
<Species>Using microarray technology, we started to define the sigma(E) regulon of X. campestris pv. campestris.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These genes encode proteins belonging to different classes, including periplasmic or membrane proteins, biosynthetic enzymes, classical heat shock proteins, and the heat stress sigma factor sigma(H).</Species>
<Species>The consensus sequence for the predicted sigma(E)-regulated promoter elements is GGAACTN(15-17)GTCNNA.</Species>
<Species>Determination of the rpoH transcription start site revealed that rpoH was directly regulated by sigma(E) under both normal and heat stress conditions.</Species>
<Species>Finally, sigma(E) activity is regulated by the putative regulated intramembrane proteolysis (RIP) proteases RseP and DegS, as previously described in many other bacteria.</Species>
<Species>However, our data suggest that RseP and DegS are not only dedicated to RseA cleavage and that the proteolytic cascade of RseA could involve other proteases.</Species>
<Species>A heme peroxidase of the ascomyceteous lichen Leptogium saturninum oxidizes high-redox potential substrates.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Lichens belonging to the order Peltigerales display strong activity of multi-copper oxidases (e.g. tyrosinase) as well as heme-containing peroxidases.</Species>
<Species>The lichen peroxidase was purified to homogeneity from the thallus of Leptogium saturninum (LsaPOX) by fast protein liquid chromatography and then partially characterized.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The oligomeric protein occurs as both 79kDa dimeric and 42kDa monomeric forms, and displayed broad substrate specificity.</Species>

<Species>In addition to an ability to oxidize classic peroxidase substrates (e.g. 2,6-dimethoxyphenol), the enzyme could convert recalcitrant compounds such as synthetic dyes (e.g. Azure B and Reactive Blue 5), 4-nitrophenol and non-phenolic methoxylated aromatics (e.g. veratryl alcohol).</Species>

<Species>Comparing LsaPOX with a basidiomycete dye-decolorizing (DyP)-type peroxidase from Auricularia auricula-judae showed that the lichen enzyme has a high-redox potential, with oxidation capabilities ranging between those of known plant and fungal peroxidases.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Internal peptide fragments show homology (up to 60%) with putative proteins from free-living ascomycetes (e.g. Penicillium marneffei and Neosartorya fischeri), but not to sequences of algal or cyanobacterial peptides or to known fungal, bacterial or plant peroxidases.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>LsaPOX is the first heme peroxidase purified from an ascomyceteous lichen that may help the organism to successfully exploit the extreme micro-environments in which they often grow.</Species>
<Species>Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.</Species>
<Species>Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is an idiopathic, fatal neurodegenerative disease of the human motor system.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In this Seminar, we summarise current concepts about the origin of the disease, what predisposes patients to develop the disorder, and discuss why all cases of ALS are not the same.</Species>
<Species>In the 150 years since Charcot originally described ALS, painfully slow progress has been made towards answering these questions.</Species>

<Species>We focus on what is known about ALS and where research is heading-from the small steps of extending longevity, improving therapies, undertaking clinical trials, and compiling population registries to the overarching goals of establishing the measures that guard against onset and finding the triggers for this neurodegenerative disorder.</Species>
<Species>Systemic virus-induced gene silencing allows functional characterization of maize genes during biotrophic interaction with Ustilago maydis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Infection of maize (Zea mays) plants with the corn smut fungus Ustilago maydis leads to the formation of large tumors on the stem, leaves and inflorescences.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>In this biotrophic interaction, plant defense responses are actively suppressed by the pathogen, and previous transcriptome analyses of infected maize plants showed massive and stage-specific changes in host gene expression during disease progression.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>To identify maize genes that are functionally involved in the interaction with U. maydis, we adapted a virus-induced gene silencing (VIGS) system based on the brome mosaic virus (BMV) for maize.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Conditions were established that allowed successful U. maydis infection of BMV-preinfected maize plants.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This set-up enabled quantification of VIGS and its impact on U. maydis infection using a quantitative real-time PCR (qRT-PCR)-based readout.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In proof-of-principle experiments, an U. maydis-induced terpene synthase was shown to negatively regulate disease development while a protein involved in cell death inhibition was required for full virulence of U. maydis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The results suggest that this system is a versatile tool for the rapid identification of maize genes that determine compatibility with U. maydis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Identification of a novel mitochondrial protein, short postembryonic roots 1 (SPR1), involved in root development and iron homeostasis in Oryza sativa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>*</Species>
<Species>A rice mutant, Oryza sativa short postembryonic roots 1 (Osspr1), has been characterized.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>It has short postembryonic roots, including adventitious and lateral roots, and a lower iron content in its leaves.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>OsSPR1 was identified by map-based cloning.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It encodes a novel mitochondrial protein with the Armadillo-like repeat domain.</Species>
<Species>* Osspr1 mutants exhibited decreased root cell elongation.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The iron content of the mutant shoots was significantly altered compared with that of wild-type shoots.</Species>
<Species>A similar pattern of alteration of manganese and zinc concentrations in shoots was also observed.</Species>
<Species>Complementation of the mutant confirmed that OsSPR1 is involved in post-embryonic root elongation and iron homeostasis in rice.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>OsSPR1 was found to be ubiquitously expressed in various tissues throughout the plant.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The transcript abundance of various genes involved in iron uptake and signaling via both strategies I and II was similar in roots of wild-type and mutant plants, but was higher in the leaves of mutant plants.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Thus, a novel mitochondrial protein that is involved in root elongation and plays a role in metal ion homeostasis has been identified.</Species>
<Species>argC Orthologs from Rhizobiales show diverse profiles of transcriptional efficiency and functionality in Sinorhizobium meliloti.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Several factors can influence ortholog replacement between closely related species.</Species>

<Species>We evaluated the transcriptional expression and metabolic performance of ortholog substitution complementing a Sinorhizobium meliloti argC mutant with argC from Rhizobiales (Agrobacterium tumefaciens, Rhizobium etli, and Mesorhizobium loti).</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The argC gene is necessary for the synthesis of arginine, an amino acid that is central to protein and cellular metabolism.</Species>
<Species>Strains were obtained carrying plasmids with argC orthologs expressed under the speB and argC (S. meliloti) and lac (Escherichia coli) promoters.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Complementation analysis was assessed by growth, transcriptional activity, enzymatic activity, mRNA levels, specific detection of ArgC proteomic protein, and translational efficiency.</Species>

<Species>The argC orthologs performed differently in each complementation, reflecting the diverse factors influencing gene expression and the ability of the ortholog product to function in a foreign metabolic background.</Species>

<Species>Optimal complementation was directly related to sequence similarity with S. meliloti, and was inversely related to species signature, with M. loti argC showing the poorest performance, followed by R. etli and A. tumefaciens.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Different copy numbers of genes and amounts of mRNA and protein were produced, even with genes transcribed from the same promoter, indicating that coding sequences play a role in the transcription and translation processes.</Species>

<Species>These results provide relevant information for further genomic analyses and suggest that orthologous gene substitutions between closely related species are not completely functionally equivalent.</Species>
<Species>Genetic analysis of B55alpha/Cdc55 protein phosphatase 2A subunits: association with the adenovirus E4orf4 protein.</Species>
<Species>The human adenovirus E4orf4 protein is toxic in both human tumor cells and Saccharomyces cerevisiae.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Previous studies indicated that most of this toxicity is dependent on an interaction of E4orf4 protein with the B55 class of regulatory subunits of protein phosphatase 2A (PP2A) and in yeast with the B55 homolog Cdc55.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have found previously that E4orf4 inhibits PP2A activity against at least some substrates.</Species>

<Species>In an attempt to understand the mechanism of this inhibition, we used a genetic approach to identify residues in the seven-bladed Beta-propeller proteins B55alpha and Cdc55 required for E4orf4 binding.</Species>
<Species>In both cases, amino-terminal polypeptides composed only of blade 1 and at least part of blade 2 were found to bind E4orf4 and overexpression blocked E4orf4 toxicity in yeast.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, certain amino acid substitutions in blades 1 and 2 within full-length B55alpha and Cdc55 resulted in loss of E4orf4 binding.</Species>

<Species>Recent mutational analysis has suggested that segments of blades 1 and 2 present on the top face of B55alpha form part of the "substrate-binding groove." Additionally, these segments are in close proximity to the catalytic C subunit of the PP2A holoenzyme.</Species>
<Species>Thus, our results are consistent with the hypothesis that E4orf4 binding could affect the access of substrates, resulting in the failure to dephosphorylate some PP2A substrates.</Species>
<Species>Role of RNase MRP in viral RNA degradation and RNA recombination.</Species>
<Species>RNA degradation, together with RNA synthesis, controls the steady-state level of viral RNAs in infected cells.</Species>

<Species>The endoribonucleolytic cleavage of viral RNA is important not only for viral RNA degradation but for RNA recombination as well, due to the participation of some RNA degradation products in the RNA recombination process.</Species>
<Species>To identify host endoribonucleases involved in degradation of Tomato bushy stunt virus (TBSV) in a Saccharomyces cerevisiae model host, we tested eight known endoribonucleases.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Here we report that downregulation of SNM1, encoding a component of the RNase MRP, and a temperature-sensitive mutation in the NME1 gene, coding for the RNA component of RNase MRP, lead to reduced production of the endoribonucleolytically cleaved TBSV RNA in yeast.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We also show that the highly purified yeast RNase MRP cleaves the TBSV RNA in vitro, resulting in TBSV RNA degradation products similar in size to those observed in yeast cells.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Knocking down the NME1 homolog in Nicotiana benthamiana also led to decreased production of the cleaved TBSV RNA, suggesting that in plants, RNase MRP is involved in TBSV RNA degradation.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>Altogether, this work suggests a role for the host endoribonuclease RNase MRP in viral RNA degradation and recombination.</Species>
<Species>The Serengeti food web: empirical quantification and analysis of topological changes under increasing human impact.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>1.</Species>

<Species>To address effects of land use and human overexploitation on wildlife populations, it is essential to better understand how human activities have changed species composition, diversity and functioning.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Theoretical studies modelled how network properties change under human-induced, non-random species loss.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>However, we lack data on realistic species-loss sequences in threatened, real-world food webs to parameterize these models.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>
<Species>Here, we present a first size-structured topological food web of one of the most pristine terrestrial ecosystems in the world, the Serengeti ecosystem (Tanzania).</Species>
<Species>The food web consists of 95 grouped nodes and includes both invertebrates and vertebrates ranging from body masses between 10(-7) and 10(4) kg.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>

<Species>We study the topological changes in this food web that result from the simulated IUCN-based species-loss sequence representing current species vulnerability to human disturbances in and around this savanna ecosystem.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We then compare this realistic extinction scenario with other extinction sequences based on body size and connectance and perform an analysis of robustness of this savanna food web.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>
<Species>We demonstrate that real-world species loss in this case starts with the biggest (mega) herbivores and top predators, causing higher predator-prey mass ratios.</Species>

<Species>However, unlike theoretically modelled linear species deletion sequences, this causes poor-connected species to be lost first, while more highly connected species become lost as human impact progresses.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>This food web shows high robustness to decreasing body size and increasing connectance deletion sequences compared with a high sensitivity to the decreasing connectance deletion scenario.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>

<Species>Furthermore, based on the current knowledge of the Serengeti ecosystem, we discuss how the focus on food web topology alone, disregarding nontrophic interactions, may lead to an underestimation of human impacts on wildlife communities, with the number of trophic links affected by a factor of two.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>6.</Species>

<Species>This study underlines the importance of integrative efforts between the development of food web theory and basic field work approaches in the quantification of the structure of interaction networks to sustain natural ecosystems in a changing world.</Species>
<Species>Inactivation of the RluD pseudouridine synthase has minimal effects on growth and ribosome function in wild-type Escherichia coli and Salmonella enterica.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The Escherichia coli rluD gene encodes a pseudouridine synthase responsible for the pseudouridine (Psi) modifications at positions 1911, 1915, and 1917 in helix 69 of 23S rRNA.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>It has been reported that deletion of rluD in K-12 strains of E. coli is associated with extremely slow growth, increased readthrough of stop codons, and defects in 50S ribosomal subunit assembly and 30S-50S subunit association.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Suppressor mutations in the prfB and prfC genes encoding release factor 2 (RF2) and RF3 that restore the wild type-growth rate and also correct the ribosomal defects have now been isolated.</Species>
<Species>These suppressors link helix 69 Psi residues with the termination phase of protein synthesis.</Species>

<Species>However, further genetic analysis reported here also reveals that the slow growth and other defects associated with inactivation of rluD in E. coli K-12 strains are due to a defective RF2 protein, with a threonine at position 246, which is present in all K-12 strains.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>This is in contrast to the more typical alanine found at this position in most bacterial RF2s, including those of other E. coli strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Inactivation of rluD in E. coli strains containing the prfB allele from E. coli B or in Salmonella enterica, both carrying an RF2 with Ala246, has negligible effects on growth, termination, or ribosome function.</Species>
label: Species
Species
Species

text: <Species>The results indicate that, in contrast to those in wild bacteria, termination functions in E. coli K-12 strains carrying a partially defective RF2 protein are especially susceptible to perturbation of ribosome-RF interactions, such as that caused by loss of h69 Psi modifications.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Response assessment in neuro-oncology (a report of the RANO group): assessment of outcome in trials of diffuse low-grade gliomas.</Species>
<Species>Density-dependent population dynamics and dispersal in heterogeneous metapopulations.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>

<Species>Metapopulation microcosms were constructed to test the effect of four different types of habitat heterogeneity on the dynamics and dispersal in spatially extended systems; homogeneity, spatial heterogeneity, temporal heterogeneity and spatio-temporal heterogeneity.</Species>
<Species>Resources were distributed across discrete habitat patches in bruchid beetle (Callosobruchus maculatus) metapopulations, and long-term time series were recorded.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>2.</Species>
<Species>Mathematical models were fitted to the long-term time series from the experimental systems using a maximum likelihood approach.</Species>
<Species>Models were composed of separate birth, death, emigration and immigration terms all of which incorporated stochasticity drawn from different probability distributions.</Species>

<Species>Models with density-dependent and density-independent birth, death and emigration terms were investigated and, in each case, the model that best described the empirical data was identified.</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>At the local scale, population sizes differed between patches depending on the type of heterogeneity.</Species>
<Species>Larger populations were associated with higher resource availabilities.</Species>
<Species>As a result of this, the variation between local population sizes was greatest when there was spatial heterogeneity in which mean resource abundance varied from patch to patch.</Species>
<Species>Variation in population sizes within patches was largest when there was temporal heterogeneity.</Species>

<Species>4. Density-dependent processes leading to the regulation of local population dynamics in our experimental systems were strongest in homogeneity or temporal heterogeneity treatments.</Species>
<Species>Associated with this, we found that these systems were best described using mathematical models with density dependence acting on mortality.</Species>
<Species>In contrast, spatial and spatio-temporal time series were adequately described using density-independent population processes.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>Experimental metapopulations showed varying degrees of density-dependent dispersal.</Species>
<Species>Local net dispersal each week was primarily driven by the local population size and secondarily affected by neighbourhood population density.</Species>
<Species>Mathematical population models illustrated the importance of explicit description of density-dependent dispersal in all systems except the homogeneous metapopulations.</Species>
<Species>Treatment implications of the emerging molecular classification system for melanoma.</Species>
<Species>Hormone receptor-like in 96 and Broad-Complex modulate phenobarbital induced transcription of cytochrome P450 CYP6D1 in Drosophila S2 cells.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Phenobarbital (PB) is a prototypical inducer for studies of xenobiotic responses in animals.</Species>

<Species>In mammals, the nuclear receptors constitutive androstane receptor (CAR) and pregnane X receptor (PXR) have been identified as key transcription factors regulating PB induced transcription of xenobiotic responsive genes.</Species>

<Species>In insects, much less is known about the transcription factors involved in regulating PB induced transcription, although CAR and PXR have a single orthologue hormone receptor-like in 96 (HR96) in Drosophila melanogaster.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Using dual luciferase reporter assays in Drosophila Schneider (S2) cells, constructs containing variable lengths of the promoter of the PB inducible cytochrome P450 CYP6D1 were evaluated in the presence and absence of PB.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The promoter region between -330 and -280 (relative to the position of transcription start site, +1) was found to be critical for PB induction.</Species>
<Species>Putative binding sites for Drosophila Broad-Complex (BR-C) and deformed (Dfd) were identified within this promoter region using TFsearch.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>RNA interference (RNAi) treatment of S2 cells in conjunction with CYP6D1 promoter assays showed that suppression of Drosophila HR96 and BR-C transcription in S2 cells resulted in a significant decrease and increase, respectively, of PB induction.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Effects of HR96 and BR-C in mediating PB induction were PB specific and PB dependent.</Species>
<Species>This represents new functional evidence that Drosophila HR96 and BR-C can act as an activator and repressor, respectively, in regulating PB induced transcription in insects.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Evaluating aggregation membership and copulatory success in the stink bug, Euschistus conspersus, using field and laboratory experiments.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The aggregation and mating behavior of the stink bug, Euschistus conspersus Uhler (Hemiptera: Pentatomidae) was investigated in a series of field and laboratory experiments.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Marking of E. conspersus mating in aggregations in the field demonstrated that both sexes mate multiple times within aggregations on successive nights and with different partners, although = 20% of the individuals of both sexes returned to aggregations but did not mate.</Species>
<Species>Further analysis of mating patterns in caged aggregations revealed that heavy males and light females mated more frequently than their respective counterparts.</Species>
<Species>Data are interpreted in terms of elucidating the function of benefits of multiple mating within aggregations for males and females.</Species>
<Species>Genome-wide inventory of metal homeostasis-related gene products including a functional phytochelatin synthase in the hypogeous mycorrhizal fungus Tuber melanosporum.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Ectomycorrhizal fungi are thought to enhance mineral nutrition of their host plants and to confer increased tolerance toward toxic metals.</Species>
<Species>However, a global view of metal homeostasis-related genes and pathways in these organisms is still lacking.</Species>

<Species>Building upon the genome sequence of Tuber melanosporum and on transcriptome analyses, we set out to systematically identify metal homeostasis-related genes in this plant-symbiotic ascomycete.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Candidate gene products (101) were subdivided into three major functional classes: (i) metal transport (58); (ii) oxidative stress defence (32); (iii) metal detoxification (11).</Species>

<Species>The latter class includes a small-size metallothionein (TmelMT) that was functionally validated in yeast, and phytochelatin synthase (TmelPCS), the first enzyme of this kind to be described in filamentous ascomycetes.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Recombinant TmelPCS was shown to support GSH-dependent, metal-activated phytochelatin synthesis in vitro and to afford increased Cd/Cu tolerance to metal hypersensitive yeast strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Metal transporters, especially those related to Cu and Zn trafficking, displayed the highest expression levels in mycorrhizae, suggesting extensive translocation of both metals to root cells as well as to fungal metalloenzymes (e.g., laccase) that are strongly upregulated in symbiotic hyphae.</Species>
<Species>Surface and flagella morphology of the motile form of Chromera velia revealed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Chromera velia (Chromerida; Alveolata) is an autotrophic protist isolated from stony corals.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Ch. velia possesses a chloroplast thought to be most closely related to the apicoplasts of non-photosynthetic apicomplexa.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Phylogenetic analyses place Ch. velia as a close relative of parasitic apicomplexa and predatory colpodellids.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We have used field-emission scanning electron microscopy of cells sputter-coated with gold or chromium and non-coated cells to characterise the surface ultrastructure of the motile form of Ch. velia.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In overall morphology the biflagellated Ch. velia cells resemble the colpodellid Colpodella edax, but with some notable differences.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>The ventral side of the flagellated Ch. velia cell has two grooves extending from the anterior flagella insertion point with a ridge rising towards the anterior apex of the cell.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The anterior flagellum is shorter than the posterior flagellum and possesses a distinct, small curved appendage.</Species>
<Species>The insertion point of the anterior flagellum is partly enclosed by a flap extending from the cell.</Species>
<Species>The posterior flagellum is approximately four times the length of the cell and possesses mastigonemes.</Species>

text: <Species>Growth-mediated stress escape: convergence of signal transduction pathways activated upon exposure to two different environmental stresses.</Species>
<Species>* Plants can escape from specific environmental stresses through active growth strategies.</Species>
<Species>Here, we compared two such stress-escape syndromes to investigate whether plants use conserved signal transduction pathways to escape from different stresses.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>
<Species>Full submergence is a threat to terrestrial plants as it cuts off their access to oxygen and CO(2).</Species>
<Species>Proximate neighbors, in contrast, take away resources such as light.</Species>
<Species>Both submergence and shade can be escaped through rapid shoot elongation.</Species>
<Species>We analysed the precise kinetics and physiological control of petiole elongation responses to shade and submergence in the flood-tolerant species Rumex palustris.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>* We found that petiole elongation induced by submergence and that induced by shade occurred with similar kinetics, both involving cell expansion.</Species>
<Species>These responses were induced by two different signals, elevated ethylene and a reduced red : far-red light ratio (R : FR), respectively.</Species>
<Species>A downstream target for ethylene was abscisic acid, but low R :</Species>
<Species>FR appeared to act independently of this hormone.</Species>
<Species>Gibberellin, however, appeared to be essential to both ethylene- and low R : FR-induced petiole elongation.</Species>
<Species>*</Species>

<Species>We propose that gibberellin and expansins, a family of cell wall-loosening proteins, represent elements of a conserved growth machinery that is activated by stress-specific signaling events to regulate escape from stress.</Species>

text: <Species>Aphidicolin (APH), an inhibitor of DNA polymerase alpha, arrested cell divisions in Tetrahymena thermophila.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Surprisingly, low concentrations of APH induced an increase of macronuclear DNA content and cell size in non-dividing cells.</Species>
<Species>In spite of the cell size increase, most proliferation of basal bodies, ciliogenesis and development of new oral primordia were prevented by the APH treatment.</Species>
<Species>The division arrest induced by APH was partly overridden by caffeine (CAF) treatment, which caused the fragmentation ("pulverization") of the chromosomes in G2 micronuclei.</Species>
<Species>Somatic progeny of dividers with pulverized micronuclei (APH+CAF strains) contained aneuploid and amicronucleate cells.</Species>

<Species>The amicronucleate cells, after losing their oral structures and most of their cilia, and undergoing progressive disorganization of cortical structures, assumed an irregular shape ("crinkled") and were nonviable.</Species>
<Species>"Crinkled" cells were not formed after APH + CAF treatment of the amicronuclear BI3840 strain, which contains some mic-specific sequences in its macronucleus.</Species>

<Species>Most of the APH +CAF strains had a typical "*"- like conjugation phenotype: they did not produce pronuclei, but received them unilaterally from their mates and retained old macronuclei.</Species>
<Species>However, 4 among 100 APH+CAF clones induced arrest at meiotic metaphase I in their wt mates.</Species>
<Species>It is likely that the origin of such clones was enhanced by chromosome pulverization.</Species>
<Species>Identification and characterization of genes responsible for biosynthesis of kojic acid, an industrially important compound from Aspergillus oryzae.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>Glucose can be converted to kojic acid, perhaps by only a few steps, but no genes for the conversion have thus far been revealed.</Species>
<Species>Using a DNA microarray, gene expression profiles under three pairs of conditions significantly affecting kojic acid production were compared.</Species>
<Species>All genes were ranked using an index parameter reflecting both high amounts of transcription and a high induction ratio under producing conditions.</Species>

<Species>After disruption of nine candidate genes selected from the top of the list, two genes of unknown function were found to be responsible for kojic acid biosynthesis, one having an oxidoreductase motif and the other a transporter motif.</Species>
<Species>These two genes are closely associated in the genome, showing typical characteristics of genes involved in secondary metabolism.</Species>
<Species>Increasing burden of liver disease in patients with HIV infection.</Species>
<Species>Chronic diseases and injuries in India.</Species>

<Species>Chronic diseases (eg, cardiovascular diseases, mental health disorders, diabetes, and cancer) and injuries are the leading causes of death and disability in India, and we project pronounced increases in their contribution to the burden of disease during the next 25 years.</Species>
<Species>Most chronic diseases are equally prevalent in poor and rural populations and often occur together.</Species>
<Species>Although a wide range of cost-effective primary and secondary prevention strategies are available, their coverage is generally low, especially in poor and rural populations.</Species>
<Species>Much of the care for chronic diseases and injuries is provided in the private sector and can be very expensive.</Species>

<Species>Sufficient evidence exists to warrant immediate action to scale up interventions for chronic diseases and injuries through private and public sectors; improved public health and primary health-care systems are essential for the implementation of cost-effective interventions.</Species>

<Species>We strongly advocate the need to strengthen social and policy frameworks to enable the implementation of interventions such as taxation on bidis (small hand-rolled cigarettes), smokeless tobacco, and locally brewed alcohols.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also advocate the integration of national programmes for various chronic diseases and injuries with one another and with national health agendas.</Species>

<Species>India has already passed the early stages of a chronic disease and injury epidemic; in view of the implications for future disease burden and the demographic transition that is in progress in India, the rate at which effective prevention and control is implemented should be substantially increased.</Species>
<Species>The emerging agenda of chronic diseases and injuries should be a political priority and central to national consciousness, if universal health care is to be achieved.</Species>
<Species>One size does not fit all: flexible models are required to understand animal movement across scales.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>Large data sets containing precise movement data from free-roaming animals are now becoming commonplace.</Species>
<Species>One means of analysing individual movement data is through discrete, random walk-based models.</Species>
<Species>2.</Species>

<Species>Random walk models are easily modified to incorporate common features of animal movement, and the ways that these modifications affect the scaling of net displacement are well studied.</Species>

<Species>Recently, ecologists have begun to explore more complex statistical models with multiple latent states, each of which are characterized by a distribution of step lengths and have their own unimodal distribution of turning angles centred on one type of turn (e.g. reversals).</Species>
<Species>3.</Species>
<Species>Here, we introduce the compound wrapped Cauchy distribution, which allows for multimodal distributions of turning angles within a single state.</Species>
<Species>When used as a single state model, the parameters provide a straightforward summary of the relative contributions of different turn types.</Species>
<Species>The compound wrapped Cauchy distribution can also be used to build multiple state models.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>We hypothesize that a multiple state model with unimodal distributions of turning angles will best describe movement at finer resolutions, while a multiple state model using our multimodal distribution will better describe movement at intermediate temporal resolutions.</Species>
<Species>At coarser temporal resolutions, a single state model using our multimodal distribution should be sufficient.</Species>

<Species>We parameterize and compare the performance of these models at four different temporal resolutions (1, 4, 12 and 24 h) using data from eight individuals of Loxodonta cyclotis and find support for our hypotheses.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>5.</Species>

<Species>We assess the efficacy of the different models in extrapolating to coarser temporal resolution by comparing properties of data simulated from the different models to the properties of the observed data.</Species>

<Species>At coarser resolutions, simulated data sets recreate many aspects of the observed data; however, only one of the models accurately predicts step length, and all models underestimate the frequency of reversals.</Species>
<Species>6.</Species>
<Species>The single state model we introduce may be adequate to describe movement data at many resolutions and can be interpreted easily.</Species>
<Species>Multiscalar analyses of movement such as the ones presented here are a useful means of identifying inconsistencies in our understanding of movement.</Species>
<Species>Cleavage of resveratrol in fungi: characterization of the enzyme Rco1 from Ustilago maydis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Ustilago maydis, the causative agent of corn smut disease, contains two genes encoding members of the carotenoid cleavage oxygenase family, a group of enzymes that cleave double bonds in different substrates.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>One of them, Cco1, was formerly identified as a Beta-carotene cleaving enzyme.</Species>
<Species>Here we elucidate the function of the protein encoded by the second gene, termed here as Ustilago maydis Resveratrol cleavage oxygenase 1 (Um Rco1).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In vitro incubations of heterologously expressed and purified UM Rco1 with different carotenoid and stilbene substrates demonstrate that it cleaves the interphenyl Calpha-CBeta double bond of the phytoalexin resveratrol and its derivative piceatannol.</Species>
<Species>Um Rco1 exhibits a high degree of substrate specificity, as suggested by the lack of activity on carotenoids and the other resveratrol-related compounds tested.</Species>
<Species>The activity of Um Rco1 was confirmed by incubation of U. maydis rco1 deletion and over-expression strains with resveratrol.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, treatment with resveratrol resulted in striking alterations of cell morphology.</Species>
<Species>However, pathogenicity assays indicated that Um rco1 is largely dispensable for biotrophic development.</Species>
<Species>Our work reveals Um Rco1 as the first eukaryotic resveratrol cleavage enzyme identified so far.</Species>

<Species>Moreover, Um Rco1 represents a subfamily of fungal enzymes likely involved in the degradation of stilbene compounds, as suggested by the cleavage of resveratrol by homologs from Aspergillus fumigatus, Chaetomium globosum and Botryotinia fuckeliana.</Species>

text: <Species>The redox-sensitive transcription factor SoxR in enteric bacteria senses and regulates the cellular response to superoxide and nitric oxide.</Species>
<Species>In other bacterial groups, however, it may respond to redox-active small molecules, as demonstrated for pyocyanin sensing in pseudomonads.</Species>

Species

text: <Species>Using the E. coli SoxR binding sequence, we predicted five candidate genes of the SoxR regulon and demonstrated that SoxR binds to their promoter regions and activates their expression concurrently with the production of the blue antibiotic actinorhodin (a benzoisochromanequinone).</Species>

text: <Species>These genes encode a probable NADPH-dependent flavin reductase (SCO2478), an NADPH-dependent quinone reductase (SCO4266), an ABC transporter (SCO7008), a monooxygenase (SCO1909), and a hypothetical protein (SCO1178).</Species>
<Species>Addition of actinorhodin to exponentially growing cells activated the expression of SoxR target genes in an SoxR-dependent manner.</Species>

<Species>The secreted gamma-actinorhodin was over 10-fold more effective in activation than the intracellular form of actinorhodin, suggesting that SoxR is specified to respond more to exogenous signals than to intracellular metabolites.</Species>

<Species>Shrinking by numbers: landscape context affects the species composition but not the quantitative structure of local food webs.</Species>
<Species>1.</Species>
<Species>With habitat fragmentation spreading around the world, there is a pressing need to understand its impacts on local food webs.</Species>
<Species>To date, few studies have examined the effects of landscape context on multiple local communities in a quantitative, spatially realistic setting.</Species>

<Species>2. To examine how the isolation of a food web affects its structure, we construct local food webs of specialist herbivores and their natural enemies on 82 individual oaks (Quercus robur) growing in different landscape contexts.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>3.</Species>

<Species>Across this set of webs, we find that communities in isolated habitat patches not only contained fewer species than did well-connected ones, but also differed in species composition.</Species>
<Species>4.</Species>

<Species>Surprisingly, the effects observed in terms of species composition were not reflected in the quantitative interaction structure of local food webs: landscape context had no detectable effect on either the interaction evenness, linkage density, connectance, generality or vulnerability of local webs.</Species>
<Species>5.</Species>
<Species>We conclude that the quantitative structure of food webs may be stable in the face of habitat fragmentation, despite clear-cut impacts on individual species.</Species>
<Species>This finding offers hope-inspiring news for conservation, but should clearly be verified by empirical studies across both naturally and more recently fragmented systems.</Species>
<Species>General factors important for the formation of structured biofilm-like yeast colonies.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>The lifestyle of wild and laboratory yeast strains significantly differs.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>In contrast to the smooth colonies of laboratory strains, wild Saccharomyces cerevisiae strains form biofilm-like, strikingly structured colonies possessing distinctive traits enabling them to better survive in hostile environments in the wild.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Here, comparing three sets of strains forming differently structured colonies (fluffy, semi-fluffy and smooth), each derived from ancestors with distinct genetic backgrounds isolated from natural settings (BR-88, BR-99 and BR-103), we specified the factors essential for the formation of structured colonies, i.e. for the lifestyle most likely to be preferred in the wild.</Species>
<Species>The ability to form an abundant extracellular matrix (ECM) is one of the features typical for structured colonies.</Species>
<Species>ECM influences colony architecture and many other physiological properties, such as the capability to retain water in a 2-fold surplus to wet cell biomass.</Species>
<Species>ECM composition, however, differs among distinct strains, depending on their particular genetic background.</Species>
<Species>We further show that the expression of certain genes (AQY1, FLO11) is also strictly related to the particular colony morphology, being highest in the most structured colonies.</Species>

<Species>Flo11p adhesin, important for cell-cell and cell-surface adhesion, is essential for the formation of fluffy colonies and thus significantly contributes to the phenotype variability of wild yeast strains.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>On the other hand, surprisingly, neither the cell shape nor budding pattern nor the ability to form pseudohyphae directly influences the formation of three-dimensional fluffy colony architecture.</Species>

label: Species

text: <Species>Early detection of resistant mutations of hepatitis B virus (HBV) is important for patients on nucleos(t)ide analog therapy.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>An assay based on the PCR-Invader technology was developed to detect resistant mutations with high sensitivity.</Species>
<Species>The assay specifically detects mutations at codons 180, 181, 184, 202, 204, and 250 of the HBV polymerase reverse transcriptase domain.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>These mutations result in resistance to lamivudine and entecavir.</Species>
<Species>In mixtures of plasmids containing wild-type and resistant mutants, fold-over-zero values for resistant mutations were detected in 2% of the total.</Species>
<Species>Seventy-five serum samples from patients, whose treatment had been switched from lamivudine to entecavir, were examined by the PCR-Invader assay and direct sequencing.</Species>
<Species>The PCR-Invader assay detected all resistant mutations that were detected by direct sequencing and even detected the presence of mutants that direct sequencing could not.</Species>
<Species>Cloning sequencing confirmed those mutations found by the PCR-Invader assay and not by direct sequencing.</Species>
<Species>The PCR-Invader assay is a useful tool for the early detection of drug-resistant mutations.</Species>
<Species>Genomic evidence of repeat-induced point mutation (RIP) in filamentous ascomycetes.</Species>
<Species>The genomes of 49 filamentous ascomycetes (subphylum Pezizomycotina) were examined by two independent methods for evidence of multiple C->T transitions typical of RIP.</Species>

<Species>At least one transposable element or other repeat family was identified in each genome, and members were assessed for transition and transversion mutations relative to a model of their intact progenitor.</Species>
<Species>Occurrence of RIP was indicated where family members differed by excess of directional transitions over transversions.</Species>
<Species>Transition mutations were quantified by an algorithm taking double mutations in CpG and CpC dinucleotides into account.</Species>

<Species>A second method assessed dinucleotide frequency distribution anomalies in whole genomes, a procedure that allowed quantification of fractions of the non-coding genome that had been subject to extensive directional mutation.</Species>
<Species>The results of both methods revealed that RIP-like activity varied greatly, both in extent of mutation and in dinucleotide context for C->T transitions.</Species>

text: <Species>Many genomes carried both intact repeats as well as others that had suffered heavily from transitions.</Species>

text: <Species>Chikungunya virus induces IPS-1-dependent innate immune activation and protein kinase R-independent translational shutoff.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Chikungunya virus (CHIKV) is an arthritogenic mosquito-transmitted alphavirus that is undergoing reemergence in areas around the Indian Ocean.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Despite the current and potential danger posed by this virus, we know surprisingly little about the induction and evasion of CHIKV-associated antiviral immune responses.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>With this in mind we investigated innate immune reactions to CHIKV in human fibroblasts, a demonstrable in vivo target of virus replication and spread.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>We show that CHIKV infection leads to activation of the transcription factor interferon regulatory factor 3 (IRF3) and subsequent transcription of IRF3-dependent antiviral genes, including beta interferon (IFN-Beta).</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>IRF3 activation occurs by way of a virus-induced innate immune signaling pathway that includes the adaptor molecule interferon promoter stimulator 1 (IPS-1).</Species>
<Species>Despite strong transcriptional upregulation of these genes, however, translation of the corresponding proteins is not observed.</Species>

<Species>We further demonstrate that translation of cellular (but not viral) genes is blocked during infection and that although CHIKV is found to trigger inactivation of the translational molecule eukaryotic initiation factor subunit 2alpha by way of the double-stranded RNA sensor protein kinase R, this response is not required for the block to protein synthesis.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Furthermore, overall diminution of cellular RNA synthesis is also observed in the presence of CHIKV and transcription of IRF3-dependent antiviral genes appears specifically blocked late in infection.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We hypothesize that the observed absence of IFN-Beta and antiviral proteins during infection results from an evasion mechanism exhibited by CHIKV that is dependent on widespread shutoff of cellular protein synthesis and a targeted block to late synthesis of antiviral mRNA transcripts.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>Possible contributions of TERMINAL FLOWER 1 to the evolution of rosette flowering in Leavenworthia (Brassicaceae).</Species>

<Species>Leavenworthia crassa is a rosette flowering species that differs from inflorescence flowering species, such as Arabidopsis thaliana, in having elongated pedicels and shortened interfloral internodes on the main axis.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>Based on previous experiments, we hypothesized that changes to the L. crassa TFL1 ortholog, LcrTFL1, were important in the evolution of rosette flowering.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We isolated LcrTFL1 and introduced a genomic construct into tfl1 mutant A. thaliana plants.</Species>
label: Species

text: <Species>We also generated and analyzed EGFP-LcrTFL1 reporter-fusion lines, and LcrTFL1/LcrLFY doubly transgenic lines.</Species>
<Species>The transgene rescued the mutant defects, but manifested gain-of-function phenotypes.</Species>
<Species>However, LcrTFL1 lines differed from 35S:TFL1 lines in several regards.</Species>
<Species>Defects in floral meristem identity establishment were observed, as was the production of flowers with extra petals.</Species>

<Species>We also noted features that resemble rosette flowering: LcrTFL1 lines produced significantly shorter interfloral internodes and significantly longer pedicels than either wild-type or 35S:TFL1 plants.</Species>
<Species>Our data show that there are substantive differences in the regulation and/or function of TFL1 orthologs between A. thaliana and L. crassa.</Species>
label: Species
Species

text: <Species>These may reflect changes that occurred during the evolution of rosette flowering in Leavenworthia, but, if so, our results show that additional, as-yet-unidentified genes were involved in this instance of architectural evolution.</Species>
